div.p: e)bou/lonto—‘the word is here (as in Xen. Hel. III. 4, 2, and elsewhere) used not so much of will as of intention (Bloomfield). This is not accurate. Trans. ‘felt a wish.’ bou/lomai expresses a vaguer wish than dianoou=mai: it never means ‘make up one's mind,’ and consequently cannot, like dianoou=mai, be constructed with a fut. infin.
au)=qis—with e)pi\ *sikeli/an pleu/santes. It is the habit of Thuc. to place the prominent word early in its clause. For the previous A. expeditions see Intr. p. x.
mei/zoni paraskeuh=|—the numbers that sailed under Laches are not known. [Pythodorus and] Eurymedon took forty ships with them.

*aa/xhtos—in Sicily 427-426 B.C.; replaced in winter of 426 by Pythodorus. He was a supporter of Nicias in arranging the peace of 421. Plato's Laches is named after him. It has been conjectured that he is represented under Tydeus in the Supplices of Euripides (produced circ. 420 B.C.). He is the dog Labes in Aristoph. Wasps. He was attacked by Cleon.

kai/—joins the names of two commanders who were not in power at the same time. Hence the full form would be th=s
meta\ *la/xhtos kai\ th=s meta\ *eu)r.: but it is worth noticing how with the second of two expressions joined by kai/ it is possible to omit (1) the article, (2) the preposition. Such omissions are common even when the connected expressions are quite distinct.

*eu)rume/dontos—on returning to Athens from Sicily in 424, he had been tried on a charge of taking bribes (grafh\ dw/rwn or dwrodoki/as), and was fined. He was not strathgo/s again until 414 B.C. This long period of retirement is probably connected with his trial and condemnation.
e)pi\ *s. pleu/santes katastre/yasqai—it is regular to construct the common object of a partieiple and verb so as to suit the participle.
a)/peiroi oi( polloi/—in limiting apposition to *)aqhnai=oi. Thuc. enlarges or contracts the subject at will.

tou= mege/qous . . tou= plh/qous—chiasmus is so common in Thuc. as to amount to a mannerism. Cf. V. 61 th/n te tou= tei/xous a)sqenei/an kai\ tou= stratou= to\ plh=qos. (On me/geqos and plh=qos tw=n e)noikou/ntwn in reference to the City see Aristot. Pol. 1326 a, with Fowler's City-State, p. 276.)

kai\ o(/ti—a clause introduced by o(/ti in either of its meanings is often co-ordinated to a noun, as in VII. 58, 4 dia\ me/geqo/s te po/lews kai\ o(/ti (‘because’) e)n megi/stw| kindu/nw| h)=san. Cf. Demosth. VIII. 71 ou)de
 a)
 tou/twn ei)/toimi, a)ll) o(/ti . . ou)de
 politeu/omai. (1) A similar use of ‘and that’ is common in eighteenth-centnry English prose; as also is (2) the habit of using together two constructions after a single verb or governing expression—here tou= mege/qous . . kai\ o(/ti after a)/peiroi o)/ntes. Thus in VIII. 4, 1 we have pareskeua/zonto de\ . . th/n te nauphgi/an kai\ *sou/nion teixi/santes: Addison has ‘It was his design to marry her to such a gentleman, and that her wedding should be celebrated on such a day’; ‘They believe the same of all works of art . . and that, as any one of these things perish, their souls go into another world’; Cowper has ‘The fine gentleman would find his ceilings too low, and that his casements admitted too much wind’; Johnson, ‘They think veneration gained by such appearances of wisdom, but that no ideas are annexed to the words.’ Thackeray, Carlyle, and Ruskin also indulge in this and similar constructions.

ou) pollw=| tini—Hudson wrongly says ‘tini videtur pleona/zein.’ Greek has three words for our ‘very,’ ‘really,’ or ‘actually’ (quidam with adjeetives)—(1) tis (generally with adjectives of degree); (2) pa/nu and sfo/dra (often with words other than numcrals which cannot be compared. See Class. Rev. VIII. p. 152b). With negatives tis or pa/nu or both together can be used. (See Stein on Herod. V. 33.)
u(podee)steron—antithesis to mege/qous kai\ plh/qous, as in II. 89, 6 e)k pollw=| u(podeeste/rwn . . me/ga ti th=s dianoi/as to\ be/baion e)/xontes: V. 20 u(podee/steron o)\n ta\ me/gista timh/sei.

a)nh|rou=nto—the pres and imperf., especially of -gi/gnomai and -di/dwmi, often express intention or attempt; as Aristoph. Pax 408 prodi/doton th\n *(ella/da: Eur H. F 538 kai\ ta)/m' e)/qnh|ske te/kn), a)pwllu/mhn d' e)gw/ liberi mei morituri erant, ego autem peritura.

*sikeli/as—here follows a description of Sicily, in which Thuc., ‘like Herodotus, retains the spirit of the older geographers and logographers,’ and writes with something of the grace that characterises the style of Herodotus. It has been commonly supposed since Nicbuhr that Thuc. borrows from his contemporary Antiochus of Syracuse—so Goller, Wolfflin, Classen, Mahaffy,—but there is no certainty (see Freeman, Hist. Sic. I. p. 456). Thuc. probably visited Sicily during his exile.

e)/lasson—not e)la/sswn: the adverbs ple/on, e)/lasson are regularly used in such cases. Cf. c. 95, 1 e)pra/qh tala/ntwn ou)k e)/lasson pe/nte kai\ ei)/kosi. The repetition of ou) pollw=| tini emphasises the vastness of the undertaking.

h(merw=n—so II. 97, 1 peri/plous tessa/rwn h(merw=n. The length of the coasts of Sicily is 512 miles. In ancient times, astronomy not being applied to navigation, distance round the coasts of a country of which the measurements were unknown, could be reckoned only by the time occupied in the voyage.

tosau/th ou)=sa—Thuc. ‘seems to think that there is a geographical incongruity in so large an island being separated from the mainland by so narrow a channel’ (note in Jowett); or rather, he adds as a second proof of the geographical importance of the island—and consequently of the magnitude of the new undertaking—the fact that Sicily, in addition to its size, is so close to the mainland as to be almost part of the continent. Athens was in the habit of reducing islands— pleu/santes katastre/yasqai—but she had not the means for reducing a large continental country. (Stein explains similarly.)

e)n . . me/trw|—a difficult use of e(n in its quasi-instrumental sense, ‘res in qua aliqua actio vel qualitas cernitur.’ c. 16, 5 e)/n tinos lampro/thti proe/sxon is the same use. It is from this use that adverbial phrases like e)n ta/xei come.
to\ mh/—Soph. Phil. 1141 e)/stin tis e)/stin o(/s se kwlu/sei to\ dra=n. M.T. 811: Wecklein on Agam. 1588. It is internal accus.

ei)=nai—see crit. note. Poppo defended ou)=sa here as a confusion between two constructions; but Classen is probably right in thinking that ou)=sa got in from tosau/th ou)=sa above.
Among recent critics, only L. Herbst defends ou)=sa: he thinks that to/ does not affect the construction here and in other places, but is used as a demonstrative particle. Would mh/ then be possible?

w)|ki/sqh de/—answering to peri/plous me/n above. cc. 2-5 are generally described as a digression; but the passage is perhaps rather a continuation of the description of the greatness of Sicily. ‘The greatness of Sicily,’ Freeman says, ‘was essentially a colonial greatness, the greatness of communities which did not form whole nations but only parts of nations, nations of which other parts remained in their elder homes.’
to\ a)rxai=on—distinguish from kata\ to\ a/rxai=on (‘in the ancient manner’).

e)/sxe—sc. au)th/n. ta\ cu/mpanta is nom., agreeing with e)/qnh. When the art. precedes pa=s and its compds., the whole is regarded as the sum of its component parts. (To take ta\ cu/mpanta as accus. is wrong. A complete list of tribes is what Thuc. gives; their geographical distribution is also described, but that is already referred to in w)=de w)|ki/sqh. Cf, the last sentence of c. 2, where the same ideas recur in inverse order.) le/gontai—le/gomai used personally or impersonally is regularly constructed with an infin.
*ku/klwpes—Homer does not say that the Cyclopes dwelt in Sicily (Od. IX); but the scene of his story was always localised by later writers (as by Euripides) in Sicily.
*laistrugo/nes—mythical beings (Od. X. 81) like the Cyclopes, dwelling, like them, in fairy-land. The story that they lived in Sicily is the product of Greek fancy. (See Freeman l.c. pp. 100, 106.)
poihtai=s—esp. Homer. Observe that the perf. pass., when the subject is non-personal, regularly has the agent in dat.
w(s e(/kastos gignw/skei—so in II. 48, of the origin of ‘the Plague.’

peri\ au)tw=n—Classen takes au)tw=n as neut., ‘these questions,’ i.e. ge/nos, o(po/qen e)sh=lqon k.t.l. Of this rather vague use of au)ta/ Thuc. is fond. But met' au)tou/s below is strongly in favour of making au)tw=n masc.
*sikanoi/—some modern critics, including Holm, think that *sikanoi/ and *sikeloi/ are ‘simply dialectal differences of the same name.’ Freeman combats this view l.c. pp. 472 fol.

e)noikisa/menoi—‘settled there.’ The next words mean ‘or rather (kai/=immo) before them, according to their own account.’ There is an instance of the sarcastic humour of
which Thuc. is rather fond in e)noikisa/menoi . . au)to/xqones: if ‘original inhabitants,’ they could not be ‘settlers.’
w(s me\n au)toi/ fasi—this is placed early in order to bring out the antithesis sharply. It is a very common trick of order in Thuc.

dia\ to\ . . ei)=nai—the inf. with dia\ to/ is very common in Thuc. (63 cases according to Behrendt), but dia\ tou= with inf. is not found. The inf. with art., commoner in Thuc. and Demosth. than in any other author, is in Thuc. found chiefly in the speeches and the loftier parts of narrative. The construction and usage of the Eng. inf. in -ing (as distinct from the verbal noun) are precisely similar to the Gk. inf. with art., except only that the Eng. inf. can be qualified, not only by the def. art., but by a pronoun and by a substantive in the possessive case.

*)/ibhres—great value attached to a well-authenticated claim to be au)to/xqones: hence Thuc. marks the antithesis to dia\ to\ au/. ei)=nai, instead of writing u(/steroi in contrast with pro/teroi. Stein reads <u(/steroi>, *)/ibhres.
*sikanou=—has been thought to be the Sègre or even the Seine, but it is unknown. It is not certain from what quarter these Iberians really immigrated to Sicily. 14

*trinakri/a—Freeman points out that this name, derived from trei=s a)/krai, is probably a mere corruption of the Homeric *qrinaki/h, with which island Sicily was identified, the supposed reference being to the triangular shape of Sicily. Ov. Fast. IV. 419 Trinacris a positu nomen adepta loci.

kaloume/nh—this tense of the partic. (imperf.) is invariably used when a name now obsolete is referred to. klhqei/s= ‘called’ (timeless), or ‘having received the name,’ and is used of names given under some definite circumstances referred to, as in c. 4, 1 tou\s *(u. klhqe/ntas, and c. 4, 5.
ta\ pro\s e(spe/ran—adverbial. For the expression cf. ta\ pro\s borra=n § 5 and to\ pro\s no/ton III. 6. pro\s e(spe/ran also means ‘towards evening,’ sub vesperum.

a(liskome/nou—Classen makes this historic pres.; but it cannot be shown that the historic pres. is used in any mood but the indic. Stahl takes it with diafugo/ntes—‘escaped at the time of the capture.’ This is possible; but Goodwin (M.T. § 27) classes a(li/skomai with a)dikw=, feu/gw, nikw=, etc., so that the pres. may here resemble a perf.: but observe (1) when the pres. indic. of a(l. refers to the past, it appears to he historic pres.; (2) a(lisko/menos is either (a) coincident in time with the main verb, or (b) approaches to the perf., like a/dikw=. (An imperf.
partic. in gen. abs. joined to a historic pres. sometimes gives the cause of the verb; as I. 136 dedie/nai fasko/ntwn *kerkurai/wn e)/xein au)to/n, diakomi/zetai e)s th\n h)/peiron.)
a)fiknou=ntai—verbs of ‘going’ and ‘sending’ are especially common in the hist. pres.

cu/mpantes me/n—Jowett renders ‘they settled near the Sicanians, and both took the name of Elymi’; but Freeman says ‘I certainly always understood this simply to mean that the whole people were called E. . . . but that there were two separate Elymian cities.’ Freeman is clearly right. The Sicanians had given their name to the island, and they remained quite distinct from the Elymi. Also, is J.'s rendering of cu/mpantes possible? c. is often contrasted with kata\ po/leis, whereas it never means in Thuc. ‘they with the others.’ And Thuc. is clearly giving the name and the cities of the new settlers.
*)/eruc—the story of the Trojan origin of Eryx is accepted and elaborated by Virgil m Aeneid V.; but Freeman shows that the older legend did not assign to it a Trojan origin.

*)/egesta—this is the Greek name; but the native name, retained by the Romans, was Segesta. It is the Acesta of Aen. v. 718. To the Romans is due the tradition that it was founded by Aeneas, who named it after Acestes.

proscunw/|khsan de\ . . kai/—a characteristic anaphora of o(/moroi . . oi)kh/santes. Thuc. does not in narrative balance the clauses exactly by anaphora, whereas in Xenophon such balance is very frequent. Cp. c. 20, 4.

*fwke/wn—the statement that Phocians settled in Sicily receives no support except from a single passage in Pausanias. And this testimony is really of slight value, as P. is enumerating the Greek settlers in Sicily, as distinct from the barbarians, among whom he places the Elymi (Phrygians, i.e Trojans). The correction *frugw=n is not really supported, because when later writers speak of Phrygians in Sicily they mean Trojans. It looks as if in tw=n *trw/wn tine/s above Thue. refers to that arrival which appears under a much-developed form in Dion. Hal. as the return of Acestes. Whether in *fwke/wn tine/s we have an early form of the legend that reappears in the story of Aeneas, is much more doubtful. Dion. Hal. assigns an Areadian origin to Aeneas: and it should be borne in mind that the Trojans are barbarians in Thuc. and Pausanias, but Hellenes in Dion. Hal. and Virgil. Dion. Hal. speaks of the Trojans under Aeneas as ta\s po/leis sunoiki/zontes toi=s *)elu/mois e/n *sikeli/a|. These faets only show how great was the confusion
in the stories concerning the settlement of the Elymi, and how impossible it is to correct *fwke/wn with any confidenee.
to/te—refers back to diafugo/ntes (Stahl).

e)s *libu/hn—it is not impossible that this suggested to Virgil the bringing of Aeneas to Carthage. prw=ton, e)/peita—prw=ton without me/n is always followed by e)/peita without de), unless kai/ follows e)/peita, when de/ is always added, as in VII. 23 to\ me/giston prw=ton, e)/peita de\ kai/ ktl.

a)p) au)th=s—this pronoun, referring to a preceding noun or pronoun, corresponds to is in Lat There is in Thuc. a use of au)ta/ which corresponds to haec omnia, ‘our empire,’ as in Cic. pro Sul. § 28.
katenexqe/ntes—cf. IV. 120 ple/ontas d' a/po\ *troi/as sfw=n tou\s prw/tous katenexqh=nai e)s to\ xwri/on tou=to tw=| xeimw=ni w(=| e)xrh/santo *)axaioi/.
*sikeloi/—it is generally agreed among ancient writers that the Siculi were Italian, and had been driven into Bruttium from Latium.

*/itali/as—i.e. only the modern Calabria, in ancient times the peninsula reaching to the Laus on W., and to Metapontum on E. Dion. Hal. I. 12 defines Italy in this sense as a/po\ a)/kras *)iapugi/as me/xri porqmou= *sikelikou=.
*)opikou/s—identified by Strabo with the Oscans. They were enemies of the Latins, who regarded them as barbarous. Cf. Jovenal's opici mures.
w(s me\n ei)ko/s—there are two uses of ei)ko/s—(1) to introduce what is probable, but is incapable of proof; (2) of the reasonable conduct of persons.
e)pi\ sxediw=n—cf. on c. 101, 3. In this use, the gen. with e)pi/ differs from the dat. in that it expresses the means as well as the place.

thrh/santes=fula/cantes, as III. 22, and Demosth. 28, 1 thrh/sas th\n teleutai/an h(me/ran. porqmo/s generally in prose= ‘strait,’ but ‘passage’ suits thrh/santes better ‘Watching for the passage when the wind blew,’ means that they waited till the wind blew from Italy. The danger of the porqmo\s *sikeliko/s is proverbial. Cf. the mare Siculum of Roman poets.
katio/ntos—technical word. <e)s> to\n p. Stein.

ta/xa a)/n—sc. die/bhsan, M.T. § 244. The contrast is between what they probably did and what they may possibly have done. de/—ta/xa d' a)/n would be more usual, but expressions like ta/x) a)/n occasionally displace de/. Thus Andocides has dh=lon o(/ti de/ for dh=lon d' o(/ti.
a)po\ *)italou=—this remark is of no value as history. Cf. Aen. I. 532 nunc fama, minores | Italiam dixisse, ducis de nomine, gentem.
ou(/tws—referring back to a)po\ *)italou= after the parenthetical remark tou)/noma t. e)/.

strato\s polu/s—predicate, =h)=lqon polloi/. kratou=ntes—kratw= with ma/xh| or maxo/menos—or when one of them is clearly implied—takes accus. in Thuc., otherwise gen. Cf. Demosth. 8, 32 o(\n krath/santes toi=s o(/plois, ib. 19, 319 *fwke/as e)kra/thse (sc. ma/xh|). kratw= with gen.=krei/sswn gi/gnomai. [Demosth.] 13, 17 e)n toi=s o(/plois kratei=n tw=n e)xqrw=n is wrong.
ta\ kra/tista th=s gh=s—‘the best parts’; cf. VII. 19 tw=| pedi/w| kai\ th=s xw/ras toi=s krati/stois.

e)pei/—‘from the time that.’ The edd. compare e)peidh\ e)pau/santo I. 6, and note that the sense is the same as that of a)f) ou(=, e)c ou(=. The use is characteristic of tragedy and early prose. See L. & S.; in I. 14, 3 o)ye/ te a)f) ou(= is doubtful.

ta\ me/sa kai\ ta\ pro\s borra=n—comparing ta\ meshmbrina\ kai\ e(spe/ria above, we notice that ta/ is inserted a second time. For the repetition see note on kai/ in c. 1, 1. The omission is impossible when the first member is an adj.—me/sa —and the second is a participial expression—pro\s borra=n Cf. Hyperides I. xxi. 19 e)/cw tw=n basilikw=n kai\ tw=n par' *)aleca/ndrou. Thuc. I. 18 oi(/ te *)aqhnai/wn tu/rannoi kai\ oi( e)k th=s a)/llhs *(ella/dos. Isocr. 3, 22 e)n toi=s e)gkukli/ois kai\ toi=s kata\ th\n h(me/ran e(ka/sthn gignome/nois.
ta\ pro\s borra=n—c. 2 § 2 Cf. Demosth. 18, 301 oi\ pro\s *pelopo/nnhson to/poi.
w)/|koun—it should be noticed, (1) that the object of the Phoenician settlements was trade with the Sicels; (2) that the Phoenicians were the earliest to send out colonists to Sicily.

e)pi\ th=| qala/ssh|—of points on the coast, whereas para\ (th\n) qa/lassan implies extent along the coast. But the distinction is not carefully observed. II. 9 *kari/a h( e)pi\ qala/ssh|: Isocr. 5, 21 (*)illuri/wn) tw=n para\ to\n *)adri/an oi)kou/ntwn.

a)polabo/ntes—the constant use of participle and verb in the sentences that describe the various settlements lends a special character to these chapters. Whether or not the whole is based on Antiochus of Syracuse, the style is simple and annalistic.
e)pikei/mena—the Aegatian Islands are meant.

e(/neka—MSS. e(/neken, but the form in -n is very doubtful in older Attic. The order of e(/neka allows of (1) th=s pro\s tou\s
*s. e(/neka e)mpori/as, (2) e(/neka th=s pro\s tou\s *s. e)m., (3) e)m. e(/neka th=s pro\s tou\s *s. On the other hand, e(/neka is not placed last in a phrase of this kind, where the epithet contains a preposition— th=s pro\s t. *s. e)pese/pleon—e)p-, as in e)pa/gesqai, =insuper, Sta., who adds that kata\ qa/lassan lacks point. But it has often been noticed that a simple word (ple)w), when compounded, loses something of its force. Hence, to show that it was by sea that the Gks. came, and not by migration from their settlements—the sea being all-important in the struggle between Gk. and Phoenician —kata\ q is naturally added. This kind of tautology is to be met with in English: e.g. Johnson, Idler 48 ‘Mons. Le Noir is made miserable . . by every account of a privateer caught in his cruize.’ Burke, Mr. Fox's East India Bill, ‘I have been long very deeply engaged in the preliminary enquiries, which have continued without intermission for some years.’
e)klipo/ntes . . cunoikh/santes—Thuc. joins two and even three unconnected participles to a verb, provided that the participles are not absolutely parallel.
ta\ plei/w—referring to peri\ pa=san th\n *s. This vague use of the neut. is very common.

*motu/hn—an island about five miles N. of Lilybaeum. It was joined to the mainland by a mole, which, though under water, is still used as a track. In 397 the Carthaginians were driven from Motye by Dionysius and founded Lilybaeum.

*solo/enta—Soloeis, the Roman Soluntum, became the eastern stronghold of the Phoenicians against the Greeks. It was a fortress, not a mere trading station. The present remains go back only to Roman times.

*pa/normon—the modern capital Palermo, ‘la felice.’ The following list gives the principal events in the history of this famous city:— 254 B.C. Taken by the Romans from the Carthaginians. 409 A.D. Sicily conquered by Alaric. Belisarius recovers Sicily and takes Palermo by siege. The Byzantine Period begins. The Saracen Period. Palermo made capital of Sicily. Conquered by Norman adventurers. The Norman Period. The Sicilian Vespers at Palermo end the dominion of the French. The Spanish Period, leading to the attachment of Sicily to the kingdom of Naples. Garibaldi takes Palermo. Sicily united with Italy.
cunoikh/santes—Stahl points out that this is contrasted with w)/|koun peri\ p. th\n *s. The three towns were not new settlements of the Phoenicians.
kai\ o(/ti—cf. c. 1, 1. Two causes are constantly given in different constructions by Thuc.; a clause with o(/ti is sometimes joined to a prep. (dia/, kata/, pro/s) and case.

*karxhdw/n—the tradition generally accepted at a later time was that Rome and Carthage were founded on the same day; but there is good evidence that Carthage was founded shortly before 800 B.C. Freeman shows that the Phoenicians were probably confined to the three towns after the Gk. settlement of Selinus, i e. after 628 B.C.
tosoi/de—the violation of the rule that these forms refer to what follows, occurs most commonly in speeches.
*(ellh/nwn—the following tables exhibit the Gk. cities:— I. CHALCIS in Euboea (Ionian)
The above dates are not to be considered as more than approximate.

*na/con—never an important town. It was destroyed in 403 by Dionysins, who founded Tauromenium in its place. Though the site of N. is now occupied by orange-groves, there are remains of the ancient walls. Pausanias exaggerates when he says that there were no traces of the city in his day. (Such exaggeration by Pausanias is found in other cases.)
*)apo/llwnos—thus Naxos remained the spiritual centre of Greek Sicily, though it was not the political centre. Freeman well compares the position of Canterbury.

o(/stis—a strange use of o(/stis, the ordinary rules for which as a relative are as follows:—1. Referring to an indefinite antecedent: (a)=such that, as in ou)dei\s ou(/tws h)li/qios o(/stis ou)/xi ka)
 prw=tos ei)sene/gkai. (Thus o(/stis often replaces w)/ste after ou(/tws.) (b)=whoever, as in o(/stis a)
 h)=|. 2. Referring to a definite antecedent: (a)=quippe qui. (b)=of the kind that, any that. It has been supposed that Thuc. took at least this note from Antiochus of Syracuse, because Dion. Hal. I. 12 quotes from him the expression th
 gh=n tau/thn h(/tis nu=n *)itali/a kalei=tai, and the inference is that Antiochus used o(/stis for o(/s. On the other hand, Dion. Hal. is scarcely to be trusted in a minute linguistic point, and it is strange that Thuc., even though he may have used Antiochus, should follow him in such a use of o(/stis. Stein on Herod. IV. 8 collects exx. of o(/stis for o(/s after ou(=tos in Herod. We may compare with this the use of sfw=n in Thuc. for e(autw=n or sfw=n au)tw=n, and of o(/de, toio/sde, toso/sde referring to what precedes (cf. c. 2 end). All these uses are charaeteristic of Ionic rather than of Attic.
th=s po/lews—Naxos no longer existed after 403 B.C., and Tanromenium did not stand on the same site. Hence this appears to have been written before 403.
qewroi/—to festivals and to distant shrines.
*surakou/sas—the brevity of this notice of the foundation and growth of S. is in striking contrast with the prolixity of modern historians when they introduce the antagonists of ancient powers
tou= e)xome/nou e)/—an unusual phrase, found only here. Thuc. generally writes tou= e)pigignome/nou e)/.
*(hrakleidw=n—of these one branch, the Bacchiadae, had recently established an oligarchy at Corinth, and it is probable that Archias was himself a Bacchiad.
nh/sou—Ortygia, to which modern Syracuse is confined. Livy, XXV. 24 insula quam ipsi Nason vocant.

perikluzome/nh|—about 540 B.C. Ortygia was joined to the mainland by a mole. Cf. the lines of Ibyeus of Rhegium quoted
by the Schol. on Pind. Nem. I. 1 . . para\ xe/rson | li/qinon e)klekto\n pala/maisi brotw=n . . But in Cicero's day the mole had been replaced by a bridge. At the present day the junction is a mole. Freeman, Sicily II, Note XV.

h( e)/cw—Achradina, a name first found in Polybius. It probably included the ‘eastern part of the hill and the low ground between the hill and the island.’ (The precise extent of Achradina is a matter of dispute. See Freeman II. Note V. It was joined to the island by Gelon (485-478), the ‘second founder’ of Syracuse.)
prosteixisqei=sa—‘this prosteixismo/s I understaud to be the work of Gelôn. He joined Ortygia and Upper Achradina by fortifying Lower Achradina.’ Freeman II. p. 447.

polua/nqrwpos—cf. [Demosth.] and c. Neaeram 75, a speech that contains imitations of Thuc., *qhseu\s sunw/|kisen au)tou\s kai\ dhmokrati/an e)poi/hse kai\ h( po/lis polua/nqrwpos e(ge/neto: Xen. Vect. 4, 50 i)sxurw=s ga\r a)\n kai\ au(/th polua/nqrwpos ge/noito po/lis.

*qouklh=s de\ kai\ oi( *xalkidh=s—this passage is introduced as separate from the previous statement about Thucles. Hence the article is not required with *q.: on the other hand, the article is always inserted with proper names when any special definiteness attaches to them, as here where a special class of Chalcidians is meant, viz. those who had founded Naxos. o(rmhqe/ntes—o(rmw=mai, like many other verbs with pass. aorists, is really passive. See Rutherford, New Phryn. p. 188.
e)/tei pe/mptw|—the art. is generally omitted with e)/tei and mhni/.

meta\ *s. oi)k—Index S.V. meta/: this predicative use of the partic. after a prep. is much less common in Gk. than in Lat. It is generally found in expressions indicating time, and oftenest with e)pi/ (gen.) or a(/ma. M.T. § 829. (See some characteristic remarks by Prof. Gildersleeve in A.J.P. July 1892, p. 358.)
*leonti/nous—close to the modern Lentini. It was the only Gk. city of Sicily that was inland. For its opposition to Syracuse see c. 6 § 2.
*kata/nhn—the modern Catania, which dates only from the earthquake of 1693. The city has survived many terrible disasters, due partly to its wars, and partly to its proximity to Aetna.

oi)kisth\n e)poih/santo—presently oi)kista\s poih/santes, the active being used of the founders who make the appointment for a colony, the mid. of the citizens who choose for themselves ‘Some distinction,’ says Freeman, ‘is here hinted at between
the foundation of Leontinoi and the foundation of Katanê. It may point to some possible dissension or secession.’
kata/—a common use of kata/, and one which is not confined to words denoting time.
to\n au)to\n x—Megara was encouraged no doubt by the reports of the foundation of Syracuse by Corinth.

u(pe\r *pantaku/ou potamou=—(1) for this use of u(pe/r ‘on,’ e)pi/ w. dat. is an alternative; (2) the rule in Attic prose is that, when potamo/s is added to the name of a river, the art. is inserted before the name. But Herod. does not use the art. in such a case, and in four passages of Thuc. it is wanting. (So also in the MSS. of Isocr. 7, 80 e)nto\s *(/aluos potamou=, and Xen. Anab. IV. 7, 18 e)pi\ *(/arpason p.)
*pantaku/ou—now the Porcari. Trotilon, Leontini, Thapsus, Megara all lay between Catana and Syracuse.

o)/noma—cf. II. 37 kai\ o)/noma me\n . . dhmokrati/a ke/klhtai. This adverb. accus. is commoner than o)no/mati, for which see n. on c. 10, 2. xwri/on—xwri/on, po/lis, nh=sos, etc. regularly follow the proper name when they have no article. For the order of words Classen compares I. 45, 3.
cumpoliteu/sas—i.e. metoikh/sas e)s *leont. kai\ e)kei= cumpoliteu/sas toi=s *xalk.

*qa/yon—a low-lying peninsula, now known as Magnisi, but scarcely occupied, except for its salt-works. Freeman quotes Aen. III. 688 vivo praetervehor ostia saxo | Pantagiae Megarosque sinus Thapsumque jacentem.
a)poqnh/|skei—the historic pres., esp. common with such verbs as ti/ktw, gi/gnomai, qnh/|skw, may be co-ordinated with another tense—w)/|kisan—which may equally well precede or follow it.

parado/ntos—Freeman says: ‘The M. were helped by a Sikel king who betrayed the place to them’; but Stahl with the older edd rightly explains th\n xw/ran as the region in which M. was situated. Bloomfield, keeping the MSS. prodo/ntos, renders ‘having conceded,’ and probably Hyblon granted the land because he was unable to defend it. Classen's correction para- is almost certain, being in accordance with the language of Thuc., whereas pro- th\n xw/ran is a most unusual phrase.

*megare/as—the city, which was never important, was destroyed by Gelon (see c. 5, 3), but was rebuilt after the Sicilian expedition and made an outpost of Syracuse. Gelon had intervened in a civil war at Megara. (The single sentence of which this section consists illustrates the great power of the Gk. participle. oi)ki/sas kai\ cumpoliteu/sas kai\ e)kpesw\n kai\ oi)ki/sas
expresses a succession of events that are detailed in the briefest and simplest form of words possible. The style is periodic, though the period is not worked up in the rhetorical manner. Observe that te belongs to the first kai/, the two longer participial phrases making one pair, and the two shorter a second pair. Although this cumulation of participles is of course impossible in English, yet the outline of the whole sentence resembles the modern English period, strictly so ealled, rather than the more artificial Gk. period.)

u(/steron h)\ . . oi)ki/sai—M.T. § 655. This is the only passage in Attic in which u(/steron h)/ is constructed like pro/teron h)/ (=pri/n). Poppo compares Plut. Luc. 5. It is well known that pro/teron h)/ is very rare outside Herod., Thuc., and Antiphon, but reappears in late authors such as Plut., Pausan., Arrian. 15

au)pou/s—the accus., in spite of the faet that the subject of kti/zousi is the same. This is apt to happen when a contrast is implied, as here between the building of Megara and the building of Selinus. Cp. Isoer. Ep. 9, 16 oi)=mai kai\ le/gein e)moi\ prosh/kein . . kai\ kalw=s bebouleu=sqai pro/s se poiou/menon tou\s lo/gous. When a plur and subject of infin. includes the subject of the main verb, the nom. and aeens. are used indifferently with the infin.

oi)ki/sai—sc. *megare/as. Classen reads oi)kh=sai, but most recent edd. follow Ullrich in reading oi)ki/sai after CG. kti/zousi favours oi)ki/sai, for which, by a common device of composition, it is a substitute; and, though oi)kh=sai gives good sense as ingressive aor., it is awkward after oi)kh/santes in another sense.

*selinou=nta—captured by Carthaginians in 409, when the diums of columns that still lie in the quarry of S. were abandoned. At least two of the seven temples of which there are splendid remains were built soon after 628. Hermocrates of Syracuse, when exiled, refounded a city here in 407; but it was destroyed in the first Punic War, and the site has since remained deserted. 16

kai\ . . cugkatw/|kise—this is added by way of explanation, so that kai\ . . au)toi=s might have been oi(=s. For the abrupt change of subject, ef. II. 2, 4 gnw/mhn e)poiou=nto . . (kai\ a)nei=pen o( kh=ruc . .), nomi/zontes . . For the explanatory kai/ Stahl compares IV. 52, 3 e)pi\ *)/antandron, strateu/santes . . lamba/nousi th\n po/lin. kai\ h)=n au)tw=n h( dia/noia . . e)leuqerou=n . . th\n *)/antandron, where kai\ au)tw=n might be w(=n. [The sequenee would be considerably improved by metape/myantes for pe/myantes, i.e. ‘sending home for P.’ We should have expected kai\ e)k *mega/rwn . . to be a parenthesis, as commonly with the explanatory kai/. So with et; as Livy, 23, 1 ubi fines
intravit, Numidas partim in insidiis—et pleraeque cavae sunt viae sinusque occulti—quacumque apte poterat, disposuit]
au)toi=s—with ou)/shs and e)pelqw/n (Sta.). Cf. VII. 64 oi(=s au)toi\ i)/ste oi(/a| gnw/mh| e)ph/lqete. e)pelqei=n is ‘to come to with a purpose’ either friendly or hostile.

*ge/lan—the first Gk. city founded on the south coast of Sicily. Hippocrates, its tyrant, raised it to great prosperity: see c. 5, 3. Aeschylus died there 456 B.C. Gelon moved half of its citizens to Syracuse.
*ge/la—the Gelas, so called from its coldness by the Sicels, whose language was akin to Latin.

xwri/on—Freeman says: ‘It would seem that Gela was a later, perhaps in its beginning only a popular, name. To the first spot which the Rhodian settlers occupied and fortified, the spot which became the akropolis of the later city, they gave, in memory of one of the four cities of their own island, the name of Lindioi.’ Cf. Herod. VII. 153 ktizome/nhs *ge/lhs u(po\ *lindi/wn tw=n e)k *(ro/dou.
h( po/lis—i.e. acropolis; but the change of meaning is awkward.

kai\ o(/—‘attende rariorem syntaxin,’ says Stahl. It would be more usual if o(/ were omitted. Were the pronoun in an oblique case, the ordinary form would be that of II. 4, 5 o( h)=n tou= tei/xous kai\ ai( qu/rai a)new|gme/nai e)/tuxon au)tou=: but even then Thuc. sometimes omits the pronoun altogether in the second clause, as in VII. 29, 5 o(/per me)giston h)=n au)to/qi kai\ a)/rti e)/tuxon oi( pai=des e)selhluqo/tes, sc. es au)to/. If, however, the first clause be neg. and the second positive, the rel. must be repeated; as II. 43, 2 ou)k en w=| kei=ntai ma=llon, a)ll' e)n w(=| h( do/ca au)tw=n . . katalei/petai. II. 44, 2 lu/ph ou)x w(=n a)/n tis . . a)gaqw=n oteri/skhtai, a)ll) ou(= a)\n . . a)faireqh=|. In Lat. the same omission of or snbstitution for the rel. is frequent in Cic.; and cf. Livy XXIII. 8 cum quo . . steterat, nec eum . . patria majestas sententia depulerat. In Eng. cf. Hooker, Eccles. Pol., ‘Whom though to know be life, and joy to make mention of His name.’ Johnson, Tour in the Heb., ‘We treated her with great respect, which she received as customary and due, and was neither elated by it, nor confused.’ Macaulay, Warren Hastings, ‘He hired musicians to whom she seemed to listen, but did not hear them.’

kaleu=tai—B was thought to have originally contained kalou=ntai, but this seems doubtful. Herw., in support of the plur., quotes IV. 102 to\ xwri/on tou=to, o(/per pro/teron *)enne/a o(doi\ e)kalou=nto, V. 49 h( katadi/kh disxi/liai mnai= h)=san But it is clear that the verb is not necessarily plur: cf. Herod. VI. 47 metacu\ *ai)nu/rwn te xw/rou kaleome/nou: I. 168 e)/ktisan po/lin *)/abdhra, th\n
. . ou)k a)po/nhto: V. 115 tw=n poli/wn a)nte/sxe . . poliorkoume)nh *so/loi th\n . . ei(=lon: VII. 193 (*pagasai\) e)/sti xw=ros: IV. 20 to\ e)mpo/rion to\ kale)etai *krhmnoi/: VII. 201 kale)etai de\ o( xw=ros . . *qermopu/lai.

no/mima *dwrika/—introduced from Crete (Aristot. Pol. II. 7, 3 e)/xei d' a)na)logon h( *krhtikh\ ta/cis pro\s th\n *lakwnikh/n), and perhaps from Rhodes, though of Dorian institutions in the latter nothing is heard elsewhere. But the Tripolis of Rhodes —Lindus, Ialysus, Cameirus—belonged to the Dorian Hexapolis, which had a common centre in the temple of Apollo at Triopium (Herod. I. 144). There is nothing against the assumption that before Athenian influence was felt in Rhodes, the Dorian institutions had prevailed. In later times the constitution of the island was generally democratie. The family of the Eratidae, who formed a Dorian aristocracy in Ialysus, were banished between B.C. 428 and 412.
e)ggu/tata—e)ggu/s is used four times in these opening chapters in plaee of the ordinary ma/lista. This use is found nowhere else.

*)akra/ganta—Girgenti, ‘fairest of mortal cities,’ kalli/sta brotea=n poli/wn, *fersefo)nas e(/dos (Pind. Pyth. XII. 1). It was destroyed by the Carthaginians in 406, but restored subsequently. The river from which the town was named is S. Biagio, the smaller of two streams that flow into the sea through one mouth.

o)noma/santes . . poih/santes . . do/ntes—these aorists do not refer to things that occurred before the action of the main verb, w/)|kisan, but express merely the manner of the foundation. That this is so is elear from do/ntes. (Cf. Forbes, Thuc. I. 2 p. 143.) no/mima de/—me/n . . de) . . de) serve rather to co-ordinate the details than to contrast them.

*za/gklh—now Messina, a city which, after suffering from every form of calamity in both aneient and modern times, is now second only to Palermo as a commercial centre. Thuc. gives no date for the foundation of Zancle and Himera (Freeman, Sicily, I. 586).
*)opiki/a|=Samnium and Campania.

lh|stw=n—‘As regarded the Sikel inhabitants all Greek settlers were alike pirates. . . What is meant is that these settlers were private adventurers who were not sent forth under an aeknowledged founder, with the traditional ceremonies observed in the sending forth of a colony’ (Freeman).
a)po\ *ku/mhs—in the second and formal foundation.
*xalki/dos—as mother-eity of Cumae.
o)/noma—accus, according to FI. Muller, cf. II. 37 o)/noma me\n . . dhmokrati/a ke/klhtai. But Kruger rightly takes it as nom.; sc. au)th=s from above.

h(=n . . klhqei=sa—translate, ‘its name was at first Zancle, having received the name from the S. because . .’; i e. this is not a periphrastic form for e)ke/klhto, but the passage is the same as Plat. Crat. 412 a)ndri\ h)=n o)/noma *sou=s: Aristoph. Av. 1293 *meni/ppw| h)=n xelidw\n tou)/noma: Demosth. 21, 32 ou/deni\ qesmoqe/ths e)/st' o)/noma, and many others. The dat. is usual with o)/noma e)/sti, but the gen. is also found, as in Demosth. 21, 32, after the passage above. For klhqei=sa we might expect klhqei/shs (au)th=s), but, as au)th=s=th=s *za/gklhs, the attraction to *za/gklh is quite natural. For the partic. following h)=n in this manner, cf. II. 67, 1 ou(= h)=n stra/teuma tw=n *)aqhnai/wn poliorkou=n.
*sikelw=n—therefore Z. was not occupied for the first time by Gks.

drepanoeide/s—‘The sickle-shaped peninsula is the distinguishing feature of the place; this natural breakwater has enabled the city under all changes to keep up its character as a haven of the sea’ (Freeman).
th\n i)de/an—slightly pleonastic after -eide/s, but wrongly suspected by Haacke. This meaning of i)de/a is not common.
za/gklon—the Etym. Mag. quotes Callimachus for za/gklon in the sense of dre/panon. The coins of Z. before the name was changed bear the forms dank, dankl, danklh.
au)toi/—the Chalcidians.

*sami/wn—the story is told in Herod. VI. When Miletus and Samos fell to Persia in 494, the Ionians were invited by Scythes, tyrant of Zancle, to settle in Sicily. Fugitives from Samos and Miletus adopted a suggestion of Anaxilas, tyrant of Rhegium, that they should seize Z. while Scythes and his army were absent, being occupied in the siege of some Sicel city. Cf. Aristot. Pol. 1303a *zagklai=oi *sami/ous u(podeca/menoi e)ce/peson au)toi/.

*)anaci/las—made himself tyrant of Rhegium 494 B.C., and quarrelled with Scythes of Zancle, though hitherto the two cities had been closely connected. Between 493 and 476 he drove out the Samians in turn.
cummei/ktwn a)nq—taken with oi)ki/sas, which is constructed like plhrw/sas (Clas.). Widmann compares Eur. Hec. 875 *lh=mnon a)rse/nwn e)cw/|kisan.
*messh/nhn—Freeman, Sicily II. Appendix IX. gives reasons for thinking that the change of name may have been later than the time of Anaxilas.
th=s e(autou=—Rhegium was peopled soon after Zanele by Chaleidians and by settlers from Peloponnesian Messene.
a)ntwno/mase—Class. supports this word from Dio Cass. (I. 55), from whom also Bloomfield quotes a)ntwnoma/sqh, with the note that the word is extremely rare.

l. 1. *(ime/ra—marks the western limit of Gk. eneroach ment on the N. coast. It was apparently intended as a stronghold against Phoenician Solus and Panormus. It disappeared for ever in 408, when Hannibal, grandson of the Hamilcar whom Gclon had defeated at Himera in 480, eaptured the town and utterly destroyed it.
*eu)klei/dou—probably these founders came from Chaleis, as metropolis of Zancle.
sta/sei—Aristot. Pol. 1303 b speaks of early factions in Syr. The banished clan, as Frceman points out, is strong enough in numbers to affect the dialect of Himera.
fwnh\ metacu\ . . e)kra/qh—this is the only place in Thuc. in which metacu/ applies neither to place nor to time. The construction would be more regular if metacu/ were e)k.
th=s te *xalkide/wn kai\ *d—it is usual to omit the 2nd art. after metacu/ when the gender is the same. *dwri/s, *(ellhni/s, *persi/s are the ordinary forms with glw=ssa or fwnh/.
e)kra/thsen—this probably hints at some difficulty that arose between Ionian and Dorian settlers.
*)/akrai—a fortified outpost of Syr. against the Sicels. It was not a separatc city. Freeman, Sicily II. p. 20 f.
*kasme/nai—the foundation of this second outpost of Syr. came but four years after that of Himera. The exact site is doubtful.
*kama/rina—its foundation marks the extension of Syracusan power in the S.; Syr. retained some sort of control over it.
a)nasta/twn—the revolt in favour of independence occurred in 553 B.C. (Scymnus).

xro/nw|—viz. 492 B.C. The war between Hippoerates of Gela and Syr. is mentioned by Herod VII. 154. Syr. was defeated at the Helorus; H. restored the Syr. prisoners in return for the cession of Camarina. He then restored C. as an outpost of Gela against Syr.
*(ippokra/ths—tyrant of Gela 498-491 B.C.
lu/tra—for the plur. form in the pred. noun, Bloomfield quotes Ov. Met. II. 695 nitidam cape pracmia vaccam.

geno/menos—this use of the aor. partic., for which see c. 4,
4 l. 27, is not infrequently found after another partic., labw/n, so that the first partic. is in sense subordinate to the second— ‘when he had received . . he made himself founder’—and the two are accordingly not usually co-ordinated.

u(po\ *ge/lwnos—tyrant of Gela 491-485, and of Syracuse 485-478. He seized the tyranny of Gela on the death of Hippocrates. Camarina would not accept the wrestler Glaucus, of the famous Enboean city Carystus, whom Gelon set over it, and Camarina was consequently destroyed, and its citizens transferred to Syracuse. This destruction occurred about the same time as that of Megara. See c. 4, 2.

to\ tri/ton—this occurred about 461 B.C. The Olympic victory of Psaumis of Camarina, assigned to 452, is celebrated by Pindar, Olymp. 4 and 5. This lends point to the words of Pindar: a)p' a)maxani/as a)/gwn e)s fa/os to/nde da=mon a)stw=n, and again, ai)th/swn po/lin eu)anori/aisi ta/nde klutai=s daida/llein.
*gelw/|wn—see critical note.

tosau=ta ktl—observe the chiastic form of the summary: *(ellh/nwn=c. 3, 1; barba/rwn=c. 2, 6; tosau=ta e)/qnh=c. 2, 1; tosh/nde ou)=san=c. 2, 1 (previous senfence). The same arrangement occurs in II. 7, 8, 9.

profa/sei—in one other passage of Thuc. of the real motive, I. 23, th
 me
 ga a)lhqesta/thn pro/fasin, a)fanesta/thn de\ lo/gw|. Cf. Demosth. de Cor. 201 o(/ti th
 me
 a)lhqh= pro/fasin tw=n pragma/twn a)pekru/pteto. In this use pro/fasis is the excuse which the writer gives as the true one in contrast with the alleged cxcuse. C. D. Morris quotes Bacon's ‘the truest cause of this war, though least voiced.’
a)/rcai—ingressive, as often with the aor. of a)/rxw.
a(/ma—i.e. Thuc. admits this as a secondary motive, and says that it was the one avowed in order to attract (eu)prepw=s).
toi=s e(autw=n c—i.e. the Chalcidians of Naxos, Catana, Leontini, as Ionians.

prosgegenhme/nois—Kruger, Hude, Stein, Sitzler accept this reading against pro-. ‘The allies who had jomed them’ in addition to their kinsmen. Thus in III. 86 we have ai( *xalkidikai\ po/leis kai\ *kama/rina aiding Leontini in 426; in v. 5 Phaeax in 422 persuades Acragas and Camarina to join with the allies of Athens against Syr. The Sicels also had joined in 426, III. 103. For Segesta see § 2.

te]—those who retain te—Classen, Böhme, Muller, Sitzler—assume an anacolnthon, supposing the construction to be broken by o(/moroi ga/r, and to be resumed at § 3 w(=n
a)kou/ontes: so that Thuc. intended *)egestai)wn te pre\sbcis . . kai\ oi( cunagoreu/ontes. But, as Stahl points out, if this were so, the parenthesis would be added from a wish to say something about *)egestai/wn pre\sbeis as distinct from oi( cunagoreu/ontes. But, in fact, the explanation applics to both, as § 3 shows. It often happens in the MSS. of Thuc. that te is found in some MSS. and not in others. Each passage has to be dealt with on its own merits.
proqumo/teron—‘earnestly.’
gamikw=n tinwn—‘Notwithstanding difference of origin, not withstanding frequent quarrels, a right of connubium must have existed between the Greek and the barbarian city’ (Freeman).
gh=s a)mfisbhth/tou—the Mazarus formed a boundary between the lands of the two cities.
w(/ste—quamobrem, a use of w(/ste and indic. common in Thuc. and other prose authors, and by far the commonest use of w)/ste with indic. in Soph. and Eurip.
e)pi\ *la/xhtos—see on c. 1, 1. This alliance with Segesta is not mentioned before; but an alliance is here plainly implied. [

*leonti/nwn]—has been taken with pole\mou, which is not a proper definition of the war of 426, and with cummaxi/an, which is contrary to fact, since the alliance with Leontini—as is known from an inscription—was made in 433, not in the previous war.

a)namimnh/|skontes—with two accus., as Demosth. 45, 34 tou=q) u(ma=s a/namnh/sw. au)tw=n—tw=n *)aqhnai/wn. Syr. had already destroyed Leontini in 422. The only remaining question was whether the act was to go unpunished: if it was not punished, then Syr. might proceed to destroy the other Athenian allies as well, and so get possession of all Sicily.

diafqei/rantes—this is much better than the pres. partic. (see crit. note), which would mean time concurrent with sxh/sousi. Clas. explains the pres. of the successive conquests But this use of the pres. partic. to express a process not contemporary with the time of the main verb can only be shown to exist where the time of the partic. is absolutely past (see the exx. in M. T. § 140), as in II 51 e(/teros a)f) e(te/rou qerapei/as a)napimpla/menoi w(/sper ta\ pro/bata e)/qnh|skon, whereas diafqei/rontes would refer to time absolntely future. Krüger understands ‘they will get possession of the whole power of S. while destroying’; but this is scarcely satisfactory. Moreover, the order th\n a(/pasan shows that the sum of all the items that
make up the power is meant; and it is illogical to combine this with a distributive expression. ki/ndunon ei)=nai—le/gontes has here the infin.; cf. vii. 21 le/gwn . . ei)=nai: but in II. 5 le/gontes o(/ti . . The pres. partic. with infin. is found in I. 38; II. 13; III. 70; IV. 22, 70; v. 49 le/gontes mh\ e)phgge/lqai pw ta\s sponda/s, 46; VI. 52, 58 le/gontes ou)de\ e)paggei=lai th\n a/rxh/n, 79; VIII. 70, 93. In v. 49 the mh/ is due to a)nte/legon mh/ . . preceding. In none of these passages does le/gw mean ‘to command.’ There are at least as many instances in Thuc. of le/gwn=‘saying’ with infin. as of le/gwn with o(/ti or w(s.

*dwrih=s te *d—the figure called polyptoton. It is a common means of emphasising an idea both in Gk. and Lat. e)kei/nwn—tw=n *)aqhnai/wn, so that it applies to the same persons as au)tw=n above. Cf. c. 61 kate/gnwsan au)tou= te kai\ tw=n met' e)kei/nou, where see n. to/n—to\n me/llonta, Schol.

a)kou/ontes—the pres. is used because the partic. is influenced by e)n tai=s e)kklhsi/ais. There were several meetings of the Ecclesia specially held (cugklhtoi\ e)kklhsi/ai) to hear the arguments. Cf. Demosth. 3, 4 pollw=n de\ lo/gwn kai\ qoru/bou gignome/nou par' u(mi=n, e)yhfi/sasqe trih/reis kaqe/lkein.
tw=n cunag—Alcibiades and his followers. These gens. are absolute.
prw=ton—before finally deciding.

ta\ tou= pole/mou . . pro\s tou\s *selinounti/ous—unless po/lemos can be considered as (a) a verbal noun, this order is impossible, because there is (b) no other epithet to pole/mou than pro\s tou\s *sel. Cf. (a) II. 52 h( cugkomidh\ (verbal noun) e)k tw=n a)grw=n: (b) I. 110 ta\ kata\ th\n mega/lhn stratei/an *)aqhnai/wn.

oi( cum. plh\n *korinqi/wn—the relations between Corinth and Sparta since the Peace of Nicias, early in 421, had been somewhat complicated: Corinth stood ont of the Peace. Autnmn of 421, Corinth initiated a new leagne under Argos, v. 27, on the ground that Sparta was arming at ‘enslaving the Peloponnese.’ In May 420 Athens concluded an alliance with Argos, Elis, and Mantinea; from this Corinth held aloof, v. 48, and was inclined to join Sparta. In 418 Corinth joined Sparta against Argos, v. 58. But Corinth was never a cordial ally of Sparta after 421.

th\n *)argei/an—in June 417 there had been a democratic revolution at Argos, which had then again joined Athens. In
the antumn of both 417 and 416 the Spartans had invaded Argos.
tina—Stahl takes this with si=ton, Clas. with zeu/gh. If it be genuine (see crit. note), it probably belongs to si=ton. z. komi/santes ‘having brought waggons (for the purpose).’
*)ornea/s—formerly an ally of Argos, but occupied by Sparta as a fort (e)pitei/xisma) from which to threaten Argos. For the capture of Orneae cf. Aristoph. Av. 395.
fuga/das—oligarehs who fled at the time of the revolution at Argos, and had since been living at Phlius.
parakatalipo/ntes—a a(/pac leg.
w(/ste—‘on condition that,’ a use of w(/ste and infin. common in Thuc., who uses e)f) w(=|, e)f) w(=|te only with fut. indie. Cf. M. T. § 110.

e)kdidra/sk. oi( e)k—a common case of attraction of preposition. Cf. Andoe. oi( e)k th=s a)gora=s e)/feugon. If the text is sound, Cie. ad Fam. vii. 1 has ex illo cubiculo, ex quo . . tempora consumpseris.
w(s h)/|sqonto—a favourite substitute for ai)sqo/menoi in the vicinity of another partic.
*meqw/nhn—the addition is made in order to distinguish this M. from the M. in Messenia, which was attacked by the Athenians in 431 B.C., II. 25.
fuga/das—they had been supporters of Perdiccas' brother Philip, whom Perdiecas had expelled from Upper Macedonia.

th\n *perdi/kkou—P. II. of Macedon, son of Alexander the Philhellene. His relations with Athens are not elearly explained by Thuc., and the omission is serious, as we cannot without such explanation understand fully the political position in the north-cast. The following table is compiled from Thuc.:— (1) Perdiecas was in alliance with Athens before 432. (2) In 432 he encouraged Potidaea to revolt. (3) 431: reconciliation with Athens. (4) 429: Athens projected an expedition against him. In 427 and 425 we know from inscriptions that Athens negotiated with him to prevent him from injuring Methone. (5) 424: he encouraged Brasidas to go to the north. (6) 424 autumn: he made terms with Athens. (7) 418: he joined Sparta after Mantinea. 417: the Athenians blockaded him ineffectually. (8) The present incident. (9) 414: he is again on good terms with Athens.

*x. tou\s e)pi\ *q—it is unknown when the truce was
made between A. and the Chal., but it was probably in 417.

dexhme/rous—Clas. explains ‘renewable every ten days’; but such relations between A. and eities so distant are surcly impossible. Grote is probably right in explaining it ‘an armistice terminable at ten days' notice.’

e)teleu/ta—the anaphora of this word is remarkable; but we have almost the same form of expression: ‘and winter ended, and with winter ended the year.’ Procopius imitates this expression of Thuc.; but for the second e)teleu/ta he regulaily substitutes e)/lhge. The object of Thuc. in thus repeating e)teleu/ta is doubtless to mark the fact that the end of winter and the end of the year of war coincide.
h(=kon—‘returned,’ as often.
w(s—with misqo/n. According to the figures, each member of the crew of 200 is to receive one drachma a day, which was double the ordinary pay.

e)k. poih/santes—cf. Andoc. I. 82 e)k. poih/santes e)bouleu/sasqe kai\ e)yhfi/sasqe. Technically only the pruta/neis could summon the Assembly, the technical phrase being progra/fein th\n e)kklhsi/an. (Aristot. Ath. Pol. c. 43; Schomann de Com. Ath. p. 53; Gilbert, II. p. 269.)

pre/sbewn—this must have oceurred either at the third or the fourth Ecclesia of the seventh Prytany, in the latter part of the month Anthesterion, Ol. xcii. (Cf. Aristot. l.c.) Four meetings of the Eeclesia were held in each Prytany.

*)alkibia/dhn—Intr. p. xii. au)tokra/toras does not, as is often asserted, imply that the generals were released from the obligation to render accounts (eu)/qunai), but only that the details were left to them. It was apparently—and quite naturally— usual to give to one or more generals such extended powers for distant and important expeditions (Gilbert, Bcitrage, p. 39). Aristot. Ath. Pol. c. 61, speaking of the Strategi gencrally, says ku/rioi de/ ei)sin, o(/tan h(gw=ntai, kai\ dh=sai/ tin' a)taktou=nta kai\ e)kkhru=cai (expel) kai\ e)pibolh\n e)piba/llein (fine). Lys. 13, 67, says that Lamachus during the expedition executed a soldier who was deteeted signalling to the enemy. This may have been an exercise of his special powers.
cugkatoiki/sai—inf. of purpose, M T. § 770.

h)/n ti perigi/gnhtai—observe the tense: the aor. would express the sense, but the pres. gives the meaning ‘if they should find that they were succeeding.’ M.T. § 88. ti goes with tou=. p. Stein renders ‘if they had anything left from.’
e)kklhsi/a . . kaq' o(/ ti—for kaq' o)/ ti=how cf. I. 69 skopei=n kaq' o(/ti a)munou/meqa.

toi=s strathgoi=s—another object of the mecting. This dat. depends directly on e)kklhsi/a e)gi/gneto—cf. Andoc. I. 11 h)=n me\n ga\r e)kklhsi/a toi=s strathgoi=s toi=s ei)s *sikeli/an—and the inf. yhfisqh=nai, subject ei)/ tou prosde/ointo, is added as an epexegcsis. (It is absurd, as Hude points out, to make yhfisqh=nai depend on xrh/, as though they were to discuss ‘how’ to vote. But the insertion of tou= is unnecessary.) yhfisqh=nai is not inf. of purpose, but depends on e)kklhsi/a e)gi/gneto, which is constructed like e)/doce: it gives the terms of the resolution proposed.
braxei/a|—‘slight.’

mega/lou e)/rgou—this is taken as in apposition to *sikeli/as, though in sense belonging to e)fi/esqai th=s *sik. Stahl refers to Eur. Herc. 323 w(s mh\ te)kn' ei)si/dwmen, a)no/sion qe/an, yuxorragou=nta, which is quite different, because te/kna yuxorragou=nta=qe/a a:no/sios is possible, whereas *sikeli/a=e)/rgon me/ga is impossible except as a brachylogy. Hence perhaps e)/rgou mega/lou was in apposition to <a)/rcai> (ingressive) th=s *sikeli/as.
a)potre/yai—on the action of Nicias see c. 14.
e)/ti—‘further.’
a)/meinon=‘prudent.’
kai\ mh\ . . a)/rasqai depends on xrh=nai. For the sentiment cf. Eur. Phoen. 455 ou)/toi to\ taxu\ th\n di/khn e)/xei.
a)llofu/lois—Segestaeans, who in c. 11, 7 are called ba/rbaroi. See c. 2, 3.
kai/toi—N. might naturally desire war, for he obtains ti/mh in the shape of a command e)k tou= po/lemon a)/rasqai.

h(=sson e(te/rwn=minime )( ma=llon e(te/rwn. peri\ tw=| . . s.—peri/ with dat. is rare in Attic outside Thuc.: it occurs only once in the orators, twice in the senarii of Aristophanes (once after pi/ptw, once after de/doika). In Thuc. it often occurs with verbs of fearing, de/doika, fobou=mai, o)rrwdw=: in vii. 84 we have peri\ toi=s dorati/ois diefqei/ronto: cf. ptai/ein, sfa/llesqai peri/ with dat. sw/mati ‘life.’ The antithesis of sw=ma and ou)si/a is common. nomi/zwn is concessivc: Stahl notes that these words are added because Nicias does not wish to reflect on the older men whom Alcibiades accused of fear.
o(/mws—antithesis to kai/toi.
ou)/te nu=n—sc. e)rw= para\ gnw/mhn. h(=| a)\n gignw/skw be/ltista is in antithesis to para\ gnw/mhn, and be/ltista is an adverb; cf. a)/rista in c. 8, 2. See crit. n.

pro\s me\n tou\s tro/pous—it is generally not noticed
that tro/poi is here contrasted with ou)/te e)n kairw=| speu/dcte ou)/te . . w(rmh=sqe. ‘To produce any influence on your character, my speech would be impotent, were I to urge you . . : but that your eagerness is ill-timed and that . . I will proceed to show.’ The idea of instruction runs all through the passage. It would be impossible to persuade the A. to renounce in this instance their tro/poi,—the character proverbial for its restless energy and its light-hearted impulsiveness.

sw/|zein—this and u(pa/rxonta, e(toi/mois, a)fanw=n, mello/ntwn, kinduneu/ein, are all words that suggest business transactions. u(pa/rxonta=‘balance in hand’; sw/|zein=‘to keep in safe deposit,’ as in Plat. Rep. 333 C parakataqe/sqai kai\ sw=n ei)=nai: e(toi=ma=‘ready money’; a)fanh= (not in its technical sense, ‘personal property,’ but)=‘what is merely conjectural’; kinduneu/ein=‘to stake’ or ‘invest.’

katasxei=n—‘to secure.’ Kruger takes r(a/|dia as=r(a/|dion: but it may be that e)f) a(\=e)kei=na e)f) a(/, so that the trans. is ‘the objects for which you are eager are not easy of attainment,’ and so Bloomfield takes it.

deu=ro—i.e. you have not to think only of the enemies you will find in Sicily. Already before the Pel. war Sparta had applied for help to Sicily: now the friends of Sparta there would be provoked to send it.
e)pagage/sqai—a vox media, being used equally of inviting in good and evil.

sponda/s—the Peace of Nicias; Thuc. has more than once pointed out that it was delusive; but considering the enthusiasm felt for Nicias at Athens in 421 when the Peace was signed, it is curious to find Nicias admitting his failure.
e)/xein ti be/baion—‘afford you some security’ (Bloomf.), because, if the Spartans refused to break the peace, no enemy from Sicily could come to attack Athens.

ai(/—‘so long as you refrain from action, the treaty will last as a nominal treaty—thanks to the action of certain persons at home and on the other side.’ h(suxa/zein, quiesco, is often contrasted with polemw=:
o)no/mati—‘as far as the name goes’: it will not be a reality.

a)/ndres—at Athens Alcibiades, at Sparta certain of the ephors. e)/pracan au)ta/—pra/ssw not infrequently suggests the bad side of diplomacy, au)ta/=ta\ tw=n spondw=n, the matters connected with the treaty. The use of au)ta/ referring to things connected
with what has been mentioned is common; e.g. II. 43, 1 th\n du/namin . . au)ta/, Eur. Bacchae 202 paradoxa\s . . au)ta/.

sfale/ntwn—sc. h(mw=n, the gen. abs. as often in spite of the proximity of another case having the same reference. This has the effect of strongly emphasising the participial clause. a). duna/mei with sfale/ntwn.
e)pixei/rhsin poih/sontai—see Index s.vv. poiei=sqai and gi/gnomai.
dia\ cumforw=n—‘in a condition of’=dia\ c. o)/ntes: cf. 34, 2; 57, 3. h\ *lakedai/mwn, says Thuc., ma/lista dh\ kakw=s h)/kouse kai\ u(perw/fqh dia\ ta\s cumfora/s (v. 28) just after the Peace.
e)k tou= ai)sxi/onos—‘in a manner more disereditable than we, that is, of necessity.’ We accepted peace voluntarily; they perforce. There is not much ground for this boast.

e)n au)th=| tau/th|—‘while the treaty is actually in force’ we have many disputes; referring to the omission to carry out certain clauses of the treaty These disputes were concerned mainly with Amphipolis, Pylus, and Panactum.—A principal sentence is co-ordinated with a rel. clause.
ou)de\ tau/thn—partial and unsatisfactory as it is.
oi( me/n—the Corinthians. See c. 7, 2 n.
oi( de\ kai/—the Boeotians and Chalcidians of Thrace. It is not uncommon to find kai/ thus inserted after oi) de/ to emphasise the antithesis. kai\ au)toi/=‘similarly.’
di/xa—part being in Sicily.

pro\ pollw=n—sc. a)nqrw/pwn. ‘Aliter enim pro\ pollou= aut pro\ pollw=n xrhma/twn dicendum erat’ (Stahl); cf. Andoc. 2, 21 e)deca/mhn d' a)
 a)nti\ pa/ntwn xrhma/twn. Isocr. 13, 11 has e)gw\ de\ pro\ pollw=n a)
 xrhma/twn e)timhsa/mhn thlikou=ton du/nasqai th
 filosofi/an.
tina—instead of h(ma=s. Cf. vii. 61 h)\n krath/swmen . . e)/sti tw| th\n . . po/lin e)pidei=n. This use of tis increases the solemnity of a statement.
au)ta/—cf. § 2

th=| po/lei—see crit. n.: ‘verba metew/rw| th=| po/lei bene exponit Schol., dicens: th=s po/lews h(mw=n ou)k e)n tw=| a)sfalei= o(rmou/shs metenh/nektai de\ to\ o)/noma (‘the metaphor is taken’) a)po\ tw=n mh/pw w(rmisme/nwn’ (Stahl). For the sentiment cf. Aristides 30, 35 th=s paroimi/as ou) po/rrw qe/omen to\ nu=n<*> e)piqumi/a| ga\r tw=n pleio/nwn kai\ a)po/ntwn—a)ll) e)a/sw to\ bla/sfhmon. See c. 13, 1.
pri\n . . bebaiwsw/meqa—pri/n without a)/n appears four times in Thuc. with subjunct., but in other Attic prose writers the use is doubtful. See M.T. § 648.
e)/th—sixteen years.
kata\ ta\s h)pei/rous—this is purposely left vague. The subject allies showed great readiness to revolt after the disaster in Sicily.
e)ndoiastw=s—this word does not occur in any Attic prose writer except Thuc.

h(mei=s de/—this clause does not, as Classen thought, depend on ei) . . ge, but clearly stands in antithesis to xrh\ skopei=n tina, as Stahl explains. What we are doing is quite different from what we ought to be doing. The contrast between skopei=n and o)ce/ws (metaxeiri/sai) is repeated in c. 12, 2.

dh/—with bohqou=men *)egestai/ois. The verbal contrasts between ou)=si cumma/xois and pa/lai a)festw/twn, a)dikoume/nois and au)toi) a)dikou/meqa, bohqou=men and a)mu/nesqai are good examples of antithesis in the enthymeme, or rhetorical inference. The enthymeme, which is very common in the speeches of Thuc., is ‘a syllogism drawn, not from the premisses proper to any particular seience—such as medicine—but from propositions relating to contingent things in the sphere of human action’ (Jebb): thus here:—proposition 1, we aid Segesta; proposition 2, we neglect our revolted subjects. The inference is that we are neglecting the city's interest in not reducing the revolted to obedience. The most approved form of enthymeme according to later rhetoricians is this, which Cieero calls sententia ex contrariis conclusa: e.g. Cic. pro Sulla § 22 an vero clarissimum virum generis vestri ac nominis nemo reprehendit qui filium suum vita privavit . . : tu rempublicam reprehendis, quae domesticos hostes . . necavit? One of the two premisses is often omitted, in which case the enthymeme becomes a mere statement backed up with a single reason.
kai/toi . . katerg. ka)\n kat—the alliteration renders the assertion more incisive.
dia\ pollou= kai\ pollw=n—cf. below § 6 peri\ plei=ston kai\ dia\ plei/stou, and c. 87, 4 e)n panti\ ga\r pa=s xwri/w|. The ge gives a causal force to the partic.
w(=n—common object to krath/sas and katasxh/sei, following, as usual, the coustruction of the partic.
kai\ mh/—the rel. is not repeated in this clause, but the second mh/ carries on its force.

mh\ e)n tw=| o(moi/w|—cf. II. 60 e)n i)/sw| ei)=nai, III. 22 e)n a)po/rw| ei)=nai, and many others. kai\ pri\n e)pi.—kai/ ‘as’; so after i)/sos (e.g. III. 14, 1) and other similar words. Failure to capture a city by assault or siege was an experience of the Athenians: it had not hitherto led to
disastrous consequences. But a failure in Sicily would mean a combined attack from Sparta and their Sicilian friends, an invitation to doubtful allies to revolt, and great loss of treasure and prestige.

*sikeliw=tai d' a)/n ktl—this is explained in two ways: (1) After w(/s ge nu=n e)/xousi supply ou) deinoi\ ei)=nai by an ellipse such as Herbst thinks characteristic of Thuc. and calls ‘beautiful.’ Clas. thinks that there is a lacuna after e)/xousi. The Schol. and others support this view. Cf. note in Jowett. (2) ‘Looking at the actual state of Sicily, I should say that the island would be even less formidable to us’: so Arnold, Bloomf., Stahl, etc. This version misses the antithesis between w)/s ge nu=n e)/xousi and ei) a)/rceian which is carried on in nu=n . . e)kei/nws. Now it is not certain that nu=n me
 ga/r . . is epexegetic of w)/s ge nu=n e)/xousi: for kai\ e)/ti a)
 h(=sson may quite well=kai\ e)/ti a)
 h(=sson h)\ nu=n ei)si. The real difficulty is to settle the meaning of w)/s . . e)/xousi. According to Stahl ‘the present state of the S.’ means ‘their state while they are independent.’ Much more probably ‘uninvaded as they are by us’ is the sense. Should we invade Sicily, the conditions would be altered. If we won, we should not gain: if we lost, then Syracuse might get the upper hand, and of course then would join Sparta. Cf. Class. Rev. July 1895.
a)/rceioin—ingressive.
o(/per—internal acens. to e)kfobou=si.

e(/kastoi—‘separately.’ The statement is put vaguely, because after the experience of Sparta with regard to her Sicilian allies there could not be much ground for Athens to fear that the Siceliots, if undisturbed, would send help to Sparta. Observe that w(/s ge nu=n e)/xousi is still implied both with nu=n me\n ga/r and with e)kei/nws d). e)kei/nws—ei) a)/rceian au)tw=n *sur.

ei)ko/s—generally takes aor. inf., occasionally present. The argument (pi/stis) from to\ ei)ko/s is common in Thuc. Antiphon, Tetral. A, a, 4 is an example of a charge resting on to\ ei)ko/s, probabile.

a)rxh\n e)pi\ a)rxh/n—the argument is not that it is unnatural for one empire (Syracuse) to attack another (Athens); but that if the Athenian power, the common enemy of Sparta and Syracuse, were destroyed, Sparta would soon come to regard the Syracusan power as the successor of the Athenian, and would grow jealous of it.
tw=n au)tw=n—the Peloponnesians.
sfete/ran—the (secondary) reflexive, not e)kei/nwn or au)tw=n, because the thought of the Syracusans is represented.

dia\ tou= au)tou=—neut.=‘similar means,’ i.e. by combination with other states. For the change from the dat. w(=| a)\n tro/pw| to the gen. with dia/, cf. Isocr. 15 tou/tw| (tw=| lo/gw|) e)cele/gxomen kai\ e)gkwmia/zomen: dia\ tou/tou paideu/omen kai\ dokima/zomen.
h(ma=s de/—after explaining that A. has nothing to fear from a Syracusan empire, Nicias proceeds to explain by what means A. may inspire the Siceliots with most fear.
e)/peita de\ kai/—the less desirable course.
di' o)li/gou—temporal, with a)pe/lqoimen.
dia\ plei/stou—the edd. quote the maxim aseribed to Tiberius (Tac. An. 1, 47) major e longinquo reverentia, Virgil's minuit praesentia famam, etc. See crit. note.

pei=ran h(/kista—‘and whatever affords least opportunity for testing its reputation.’ Cf. Pericles' remark, II. 41 tw=n e)/rgwn th\n u(po/noian h( a)lh/qeia bla/yei. Nicias in making this remark is making a point against the party of Alcibiades. Cf. c. 13, 1.
dia\ to/—asyndeton after a demonstrative (which is here replaced by o(/per) is fairly common. Cf. II. 60, 4 o(\ nu=n u(mei=s dra=te: tai=s kat' oi)=kon kakopragi/ais . . a)fi/esqe.

para\ gnw/mhn=par' e)lpi/da, ‘contrary to your expectation’; contrast c. 9, 2. au)tw=n probably belongs to perigegenh=sqai, but is put early in order to contrast it with *sikeli/as. Stein thinks para\ g. au)tw=n=praeter vestram ipsorum opinionem.

pro\s a(\ e). to\ prw=ton—this use of pro/s, ‘in comparison with,’ is commoner in Thuc. than in other Attic prose writers. (These words are inserted because Nicias does not mean ‘having, contrary to your expectation, attained the mastery,’ as Bloomfield renders: but, on the contrary, that the success of Athens has been considerable if viewed in the light of her fears at the beginning of the war, in the days when Pericles strove to calm her fears)

mh\ pro\s ta\s tu/xas—ta\ th=s tu/xhs, or ai( tu/xai are the manifestations of the inscrutable tu/xh that so often thwarts human gnw/mh. According to Thuc. events are the outcome of ascertainable causes, except when tu/xh comes in. Nicias himself in VII. 61 expresses a hope that to\ th=s tu/xhs may side with the Athenians: he seems to think that the conduct of the gods may be reasoned about (VII. 77, 4), but that tu/xh is unaccountable. The context here gives to t. the sense ‘misfortunes.’ ta\s dianoi/as krath/santas q.—dianoi/ai=‘designs,’ the results of dianoi/a. If ta\s d. goes with krath/santas, it is strange
that the gen. is not used, in accordance with the otherwise invariable rule of Thuc., except when ma/xh is expressed or implied. Clas, takes ta\s d. as accus. of ‘respect,’ and supplies au)tw=n to krath/santas. It is better to take ta\s dianoi/as as object of qarsei=n, and to render ‘to defeat (the enemy) and (then) to have no fear of his (further) plans.’ For the sentiment, cf. Demosth. proem. 32, 2 ou)k e)pi\ tw=n lo/gwn qrasu/n, a)ll) e)pi\ th=s paraskeuh=s i)sxuro\n ei)=nai dei=, ou)d' e)pi\ tw=| tou\s e)xqrou\s mh\ dunh/sesqai qarrei=n, a)ll) e)pi\ tw=| ka)\n du/nwntai krath/sein.

mhde\ *lakedaimoni/ous—the paraphrase of the Schol. is a good example of the skill with which a good scholiast imitates the diction of Thuc.: “mh\ nomi/zete *lakedaimoni/ous a)/llo ti skopei=n h)/, dia\ to\ ai)sxrw=s e)spei=sqai, speu/dein o(/tw| tro/pw| du/nai/nto (!) e)/ti nu=n kaqelo/ntes h(ma=s a)namaxe/sasqai th\n pro/sqen a)doci/an.”
eu)= qe/sqai=‘to settle satisfactorily.’

o(/sw|—‘in so far as’: ‘a point upon which their anxiety is proportioned to their long and passionate pursuit of military glory’ (Wilkins). o(/sw| is thus used with comparatives or superlatives, and with precisely the same freedom with regard to the presence or absence of a correlative (tosou/tw|), or of the comparative (or superl.) in one or the other clauses as it appears in Tacitus in the case of eo . . quo, tanto . . quanto. Cf. c. 78, 1 tosou/tw| a)sfale/steron o(/sw| . . a)gwniei=tai. peri\ plei/stou =‘above everything.’ For peri/ see Index.
a)reth=s—here in its earlier sense, ‘courage,’ not in the sense that it has already in Thuc., ‘virtue.’
o( a)gw/n—sc. e)sti/.

di' o)ligarxi/as—‘by means of an oligarchy.’ Nicias had experienced the cunning of the Spartan government in the matter of the peace. It had been reduced to a name (c. 10, 2) through Spartan diplomacy aided by those in Athens who played into the hands of Sparta. This is a direct appeal to the extreme democrats, who were eagerly supporting the expedition. Cf. Demosth. 15, 30 ei(=s a)gw/n e)stin o( pro\s tou\s prodh/lous e)xqrou/s. Stein thinks di' o).=o)ligarxikw=s.
fulaco/meqa—M.T. § 339.
lelwfh/kamen—lwfa=|: pau/etai Hesych.: lwfa=| th=s o)du/nhs, Plat. Phaedr. 251 C; cf. II. 49, 5 meta\ tau=ta lwfh/santa, of symptoms abating.

xrh/masi kai\ toi=s sw/masin—for the rather unusual art., cf. Demosth. 16, 12 kai\ xrh/mat' ei)sfe/rein kai\ toi=s sw/masi kinduneu/ein: 22, 55 ei)s xrh/mata th\n di/khn prosh/kei lamba/nein. o( de\ ei)s ta\ sw/mata . . e)poih/sato ta\s timwri/as. Clas. thinks the art. is added to give prominence to the more important item.
hu)ch=sqai—the perf. infin. is rare after w(/ste, but it is here required to express a state in the present.

di/kaion—sc. e/sti/. It is probably right to omit ei)=nai after e)nqa/de with C; for, apart from the awkwardness of construction, it is far more pointed to state dogmatically that justice (to ourselves) demands that we should use what we have recovered for ourselves, than to say that we should think it just to do so: and di/kaio/n (e)sti) is in antithesis to xrh/simo/n (e)sti) below.
e)nqa/de—within the limits of our own empire.
a)nalou=n—old form of a)nali/skein.
fuga/dwn—an exaggeration: only the Leontines could be ealled fuga/des. Cf. c. 6, 2.
to/ te yeu/sasqai—‘whom it suits to lie plausibly,’ by promising help and advantage to those who would help them.

tw=| tou= p. k—‘while others face danger, and they themselves provide nothing of their own but pretenees, either, if they succeed, to make no adequate return, or, if they fail at all, to involve their friends in disaster.’ xrh/simon belongs to cunapole/sai, and the sentiment that ‘there are states which it suits to involve their friends in their own failure’ is in aceordance with a maxim well known in ancient times that trouble is lighter when the burden is shared by many. It was at least recognised in the ease of individuals, and nothing is clearer than that Nicias here, as elsewhere—as he did apparently throughout his career—confuses the political attitude of states with the ethics of the individual. There is therefore nothing strange in xrh/simon. Nor is there a zeugma in tw=| tou= pe/las kindu/nw|: it belongs equally to katorqw/santas and to ptai/santas —whether they succeed or fail, the danger to their friends is the same.
tis—Alcibiades, as eager to accept the command as Nieias was reluctant.

a)/rxein—sc. stratia=s, chosen from the board of ten strategi to command the army. Nicias does not mean, as is generally assumed, elected strategus. Alcibiades had held that office, (1) July 420-419, (2) July 419-418, (3) July 416-415, and had at this time been elected to hold office a fourth time, 415-414. Jokes had been made, especially by the comic poet Eupolis, about Alc.'s youth in 419. He was now about thirtysix, but was ‘young for his age.’ For e)s sec Index.
mo/non—instead of the interests of the state. This, says N., is what Alc. is doing, and one reason is that he is too young for so responsible a post.

qaumasqh=| me/n—from the rather strange expression we must
assume N. to mean that Alc. wanted the command in order to increase his establishment and to get means to pay for it. There is nothing ‘disordeily’ in this sentence, as is sometimes said.

i(ppotrofi/as—‘so expensive was the keeping of horses in most parts of Greece (see Pind. Isth. iv. 49, Aesch. Pr. V. 475, Aristot. Pol. VI. 7), that such was regarded as an evidence of ample fortune, and, when attached to any one's ancestors, of high gentility. In Hdt. vi. 35 it is mentioned as a proof of Miltiades' gentility, that he was descended oi)ki/hs a)po\ teqrippotro/fou’ (Bloomfield). Cf. Isocr. 16, 33 of Alc., i(ppotrofei=n e)pixeirh/sas o(\ tw=n eu)daimonesta/twn e)/rgon e)sti/n: and the no/sos i(ppikh/ of Aristoph. Nub.
mhde\ tou/tw|—‘do not allow him either,’ any more than Segesta.
e)llampru/nesqai—i.e. lampru/nesqai e)n tw=| . . kindu/nw|.
mh\ oi(=on newte/rous b—‘not one for young men to decide and to carry out in a hurry.’ oi(=os=toiou=tos w(/ste, as often.

parakeleustou/s—Goller quotes Photius s.r., oi( e)k parakeleu/sews kai\ paraklh/sews sullamba/nontes. It was deemed contrary to order (eu)kosmi/a) in the Ecclesia to appeal (parakeleu/esqai) to persons, except of course while making a speech, and it appears that there were penalties for any interruption of the kind. (The evidence for this is Aeschines 1, 61, where parakeleu/htai is surely misunderstood by Schomann de Com. Ath., E T. 119.) It was the business of the pruta/neis, on whom see c. 14, 1, e)pimelei=sqai eu)kosmi/as.
a)ntiparakeleu/omai—‘appeal in turn,’ and in the regular manner, not irregularly as Alc. has done.
kataisxunqh=nai . . o(/pws mh/—‘i.e. not to be shamed into fear lest he may seem to be weak,’ M.T. § 370.
mhd' . . ei)=nai—co-ordinate with mh\ kataisxunqh=nai.
au)toi/—i.e. even without Alc. to encourage them.
duse/rwtas—this word is found in Lysias and Xenophon; then not in prose until Lucian, Aristides, Plutarch, Dio Cass., Aelian.
me/giston dh\ tw=n pri/n—as I. 1 a)ciologw/taton tw=n progegenhme/nwn, and several other cases in Thuc. There are familiar imitations in Milton. Cf. w)kumorw/tatos a)/llwn.

a)narriptou/shs—Phrynichus in Bekker's Anecdota, p. 18, 1 a)narri=yai ki/ndunon, para\ to\ a)narri=yai ku/bon, peri\ tw=n a)feidw=s e(autou\s ei)s kindu/nous a)fie/ntwn. After Herod. and Thuc. the phrase does not occur in Gk. prose until Aristides and Aelian.

ou) memptoi=s—we have no fault to find with legard to boundaries. This is a thrust at the envoys of Segesta; cf. peri\ gh=s a)mfisbhth/tou c. 6, 2. The boundaries are those ‘which nature has fixed’ (Freeman). *)io/nios ko/lpos=either the whole of the Adriatic, or, as here, the southern part of it (Poppo). *sikeliko\s ko/lpos=the sea S. of the Ionian, from the E. eoast of Sicily to Crete. (Horacc, however, gives to Siculum mare a different sense. See edd. on Odes II. 12, 2. A Roman naturally understood by mare Sic. the sea between Italy and the north coast of Sicily. In Acts c. 28 *)adri/a=*)io/nios ko/lpos.)
dia\ pela)gous—sc. h)/n tis ple/h|. It was not usual to take this route to Sicily, but, as Freeman says, it is assumed as possible.

kaq) au(tou/s—a common use of kata/ with reflexive pron., esp. with e(auto/n (-ou/s). Sometimes a further definition is added, such as mo/nos, i)di/a|, au)to/s. Aristoph. Vesp. 786 kat' e)mauto\n kou) meq) e(te/rou.
toi=s d' *)e. ei)pei=n—depends on a)ntiparakeleu/omai.
a)/neu—without consulting the Athenian Ecclesia, a)/neu th=s h(mete/ras gnw/mhs.
kai\ cunh=yan . . kai\ kat—the double kai/ serves to balance the clauses.
w)feli/as de/—cf. on c. 11, 1.

l. 1. pru/tani—i.e. the e)pista/ths tw=n pruta/newn who presided both in boulh/ and e)kklhsi/a, the president chosen by lot from the fifty bouleutai/ of that fulh/ which happened to be on duty in the current Prytany. In the case before us the Prytany lasted thirty-five days (Aristot. Ath. Pol. c. 43).
kh/desqai—for the day and night during which the e)pista/ths was on duty, he was in charge of the state seal, and held the keys of the temples in which state funds and documents were kept,

e)piyh/fize—it should be noticed that the pru/tanis was in 404 B.C. bound by law a(/panta ta\ lego/mena peri\ th=s swthri/as e)piyhfi/zein (Ath. Pol. c. 29); and probably N. is here urging the claim of his proposal. viz. lu/ein ta\ e)yhfisme/na to be reckoned as peri\ th=s swthri/as. It is to be observed that the A. could always be persuaded to take any measure however exceptional if it could be shown that h( swthri/a th=s po/lews requned it. See below on
gnw/mas proti/qei—Ath. Pol. c. 44 u(pe\r w)=n dei= xrhmati/zein protiqe/asin The phrase for ‘to allow a debate’ is lo/gon or gnw/mas protiqe/nai.

to\ lu/ein tou\s no/mous—if right, this is subject of ai)ti/an sxei=n
The phrase ai)ti/an e)/xw is very common: it is regularly used of the persons who are blamed for any act, which is expressed by the gen., the inf., or, less commonly, tou= and inf. If the subject is inanimate, the meaning is that the thing is blamed, as though it were a person. If lu/ein tou\s no/mous ktl. means, as is usually supposed, ‘to act illegally will not involve blame,’ it is extraordinary that Alc. in his reply should make no use of the most obvious argument against rescinding the decree. But N. probably only means that the president might have some doubt whether it was legal a)nayhfi/sai, and not that he himself thought the action would be illegal. The question of legality, however, could not possibly be raised, because too many persons were witnesses that to\ a)nayhfi/sai was the right course. Trans. ‘that illegal action would not be blamed where there are so many witnesses to its innocence.’
bouleusame/nhs—the aor. partic. does not here denote time past relatively to gene/sqai a)/n, but=‘in her resolution.’

tou=t' ei)=nai, o(\s a)/n—cf. II. 44 to\ d' eu\tuxe/s, oi(\ a)/n . .; 62, 4 katafro/nhsis o(\s a)/n . .; Hom. Il. 14, 81 be/lteron, o()s feu/gwn profu/gh| kako\n h)e\ a:lw/h|; Xen. Hel. II. 3, 51 nomi/zw prosta/tou e)/rgon ei)=nai oi(/ou dei= o(\s a)\n o(rw=n tou\s fi/lous e)capatwme/nous mh\ e)pitre/ph|.
h)/—‘or at least.’

to\ kalw=s a)/rcai ktl and indeed the whole of the closing passage of the speech, contains unmistakable references to the o(/rkos bouleutiko\s (for which see Ath. Pol. c. 22, 2 with Sandys' note) e)n w(=| h)=n kata\ tou\s no/mous bouleu/sein. The e)pista/ths might think that he would be violating the spirit of the oath. But bla/ptein th\n po)lin cannot be consistent with an oath ta\ be/ltista sumbouleu/sein th=| po/lei (Lys. 31, 1).
kai\ e)s ta)=lla—since the Peaee of Nicias, which Alc. had opposed.
diabo/lws e)mnh/sqh—‘he had made a disparaging reference to him.’
strathgh=sai—see c. 12, 2 n. on a)/rxein.
di' au)tou==dia\ tou= strathgh=sai.
*karxhdo/na—according to Plutarch, Per. 20 and Alc. 17, it was already in the time of Pericles a dream of many to conquer Sicily, Etruria, and Carthage, Cf., probably, Aristoph. Eq. 174.
a(/ma—with w)felh/sein. eu)tuxh/sas=‘by succeeding’: the word is often used of strategi.

w)
