 e)n a)ciw/mati u(po/=timw/menos u(po/: cf. pollh
 th
 ai)ti/an ei)=xon u(po\ tw=n stratiwtw=n c. 46, 5.

ou)si/an—Alc. had recently married Hipparete, sister of
Callias, son of Hipponicus, ‘the richest of the Greeks’ (Andoc. 1, 130), and by her dowry had added to his wealth, which before was computed at 100 talents. The era of Callias and Alc. is spoken of both by Andoc. and by Demosth. as h( eu)daimoni/a. Both of them were outrageously extravagant. Callias married a first cousin of Andocides.
o(/per kai/—the haughtiness and extravagance of Alc. brought Athens to ruin, because they deprived Athens of the services he might have rendered and led to his joining the enemy at a critical time.

fobhqe/ntes ga/r—‘fearing the greatness of the lawlessness with which he indulged his whims in private life, and of the spirit that he showed in his behaviour in whatever situation he might find himself.’

kai\ kra/tista diaqe/nti—‘and though he administered the war (in Sicily) excellently, yet the citizens became indignant with him because of his behaviour.’ (So Bohme-Widmann, rightly, I think, supposing the text be sound. Stahl takes kai\ . . a)xqesqe/ntes with pole/mioi kaqe/stasan, and explains kai/ as concessive. Stein reads a)xqesqe/ntes <kate/pausan>. Only Stahl is satisfied. Kruger thinks that after pole/mou some word like eu)=noi has fallen out. Herbst, keeping diaqe/nta, thinks that a)felo/menoi is lost after a)xqesqe/ntes, and that the construction is dhmosi/a| a)felo/menoi ta\ tou= pole/mou (au)to\n) kra/tista diaqe/nta.)
i)di/a|—his ability as a statesman is contrasted with the disgust that he caused as an individual. Cf. Bolingbroke.

e)pitre/yantes—sc. th\n po/lin. The Schol. says ta\ tou= pole/mou, but (1) this would be a charge against the other generals in Sicily such as Thuc. nowhere makes; (2) the sense is not so forcible; (3) the order of words is against it.

ou) dia\ makrou==di' o)li/gou, i.e. u(/steron of § 3. It should be noticed that Thuc. traces the ruin of Athens, not to the incapacity of Nicias, but rather to the measures taken by the Ecclesia after the departure of the Expedition.

kai\ prosh/kei moi—the speech displays with great power (1) the temperament of Alc., (2) the reckless energy of the advanced democrats. The expedition to Sicily would not have been rash had it not been for the difficulties that were unsolved in Greece. Such seems to be the view of Thuc. (II. 65; VII. 28), who seems to think too that the forces should have been reealled when Nicias wrote home in the winter of 414. So too Isocrates, who has a long passage about the expedition (8, 85). ‘The terms prosh/kei m. and a)/cios ei(=nai are not convertible; the former having referenee to his
right to the office, on the score of his birth, wealth, and lavish expenditure for the benefit of the state (in which view cf. Plato, p. 491 D tou/tous prosh/kei tw=n po/lewn a)/rxein)’ (Bloomfield). Many passages (Gilbert, Bcitrage, pp. 2-5) show that in the fifth century B.C. the strathgi/a was associated with such advantages.
ma=llon e(te/rwn=ma/lista.
a)/rxein—as in c. 12, 2, though the claims of birth, etc. only cntrtled a man to hope for the office, not necessarily the command abroad.

toi=s me\n progo/nois—thus he reverses the ordinary idea that a man gains do/ca from, rather than confers it on his ancestors. So Statius, Silv. 1. 4, 68 genus ipse suis, praemissaque retro | nobilitas. Nec origo latet, sed luce sequente | vincitur.

u(pe\r du/namin mei/zw—‘greater even than her (real) strength warranted’; compared with the notion they had before, their respect for her was increased, and went even beyond what the facts justified. (There is no ‘mixture of constructions’ here: there is only an instance of the polu/nous braxulogi/a of Thuc.) In 420, the probable date referred to, there were not wanting ‘spiteful rumours, that A. had been so much impoverished by the war, as to be prevented from appearing with appropriate magnificence’ (Grote).

tw=| e)mw=| d—‘by my display as one of the embassy to O.’ There are many stories connected with this embassy and the private display of Alc. on the occasion: some of them are given by Grote. The edd. compare II. 61, 2 tw=| u(mete/rw| a/sqenei= th=s gnw/mhs.
a(/rmata me\n e(pta/—Isocr. 16, 34 zeu/gh kaqh=ke tosau=ta o(/sois ou)d' ai( me/gistai tw=n po/lewn h)gwni/santo.
kaqh=ka—demittere in certamcn.

e)ni/khsa—‘won the (first) prize.’ Pliny, N.H. 34, 19 mentions a group by Pyromachus— ‘Alcibiades driving a chariot.’ Aglaophon the artist painted two pictures to celebrate the victories (Athenaeus), and Euripides (Plut. Alc. c. 11) wrote the ode.
ta)=lla—Isocrates speaks of the magnificence of Alc. e)n tai=s qusi/ais kai\ a)/llais tai=s peri\ th\n e(orth\n dapa/nais. Athenaeus says that he gave a magnificent banquet.

no/mw| . . e)k tou= drwme/nou—‘a new disgnise of the old opposition between lo/gw| and e)/rgw|’ (note in Jowett). ‘Custom regards such success as an honour, and what is done leads men to infer power as well.’

xorhgi/ais—orators constantly claim credit for the lh|tourgi/ai that they have fulfilled. The Choregia was the
most important of the ordinary, or encyclic, liturgies; cf. Ath. Pol. c. 56 § 5, of the Archon, xorhgou\s tragw|doi=s kaqi/sthsi trei=s, e)c a(pa/ntwn *)aqhnai/wn tou\s plousiwta/tous. lampru/nomai—o(/sa is internal accus.

kai\ au(/th—assimilated to the complement, as often in Lat., but not when there is a definition. Thus GK. can say pa/ntes ou(=toi no)moi ei)si\n ou(\s to\ plh=qos e)/graye (Xcn.), whereas Lat. has quod ita erit gestum, id lex crit (Cic.). With au(/th i)sxu\s fai/netai cf. quae apud alios iracundia dicitur, ea in imperio superbia appellatur (Sall. Cat. 51: Riemann, § 25).
h(/d' h( a)/noia—sarcastic; but the description was not applied by his enemies to the lh|tourgi/ai or to the display at Olympia.
te/lesi=dapa/nais.

e)f) e(autw=| me/ga fronou=nta—cf. Isoer. Ep. 9, 16 ou(/tws e)p' e)mautw=| me/ga fronw=, w(/st' oi)=mai le/gein e)moi\ prosh/kein ma/lista. ‘It is not at all unfair that he should have a high opinion of himself, and should not be on an equality, since he who is in trouble shares his adversity with no one.’ The noun to fronou=nta and i)/son ei(=nai is to\n . . w)felou=nta; the man who has a light to think much of himself is he who benefits the state as well as himself: such a man is entitled to indulge in the self-satisfaction of a prosperous benefactor. This is fair, says Alc., because no one shares his misfortunes with others so as to be equal with them. There is not much real value in this rather quibbling (as to i)/sos) enthymeme.
prosagoreuo/meqa—salutamur.
h)\ ktl ‘or else let him claim equality (with the prosperous) by grauting it (to the unfortunate).’
tou\s toiou/tous—tou\s eu)pragou=ntas kai\ o(/soi ‘and in fact all who surpass others through distinction in anything.’
e)n lit.=‘in respect of.’ Cf. Isocr. 10, 197 proe/xein e)n tou/tois, and diafe/rein e)n often.
e)n tw=| kat' au)tou\s b=lit. ‘in the life of their own time.’
toi=s o(moi/ois—‘their equals’ are more jealous than others who do not aspire to rival their distinctions.
cuno/ntas ‘while they are with them’

prospoi/hsin cug.—‘a claim to relationship even when the claim is fictitious.’ Some persons go so far as to invent a claim to descent from him. This must refer to such persons as tried in the time of Alc. to make out a relationship with the tyrants, e.g. with the Pisistratids: cf. Andoe. 2, 26. where he claims that his great-grandfather Leogoras might have
married into the family of the tyrants. Alcibiades was descended on the mother's side from Cleisthenes of Sicyon.
au)/xhsin . . peri/—the noun taking the construction of au)xw=. The partiality of Thuc. for verbal nouns in -sis has been often noticed.
katalipo/ntas—gnomic, M.T. § 159.

a)llotri/wn—hints at a)timi/a in the case of certain offences against the constitution, which involved a complete loss of rights, so that the a)(timos was said ou) mete/xein th=s po/lews. Similarly a(marto/ntwn probably refers to ostracism.
metaxeiri/zw—referring to what Nicias said in c. 12, 2. The active is an Ionic use.
ta\ dunatw/tata—viz. Argos, Elis, and Mantiuea in 420 B.C.
u(mi=n—belongs to custh/sas=u(mw=n cumma/xous e)poi/hsa (Isocr. 16, 15) as well as to kindu/nou k. d.
kindu/nou—Alc. is described v. 52 as taking with him to the Pel. only a few Ath. hoplites and archers.

e)s mi/an h(me/ran—‘in one day’: cf. Aristoph. Pax 366 e)co/lwlas . . ei)s au)ti/ka ma/la, answering ei)s ti/n' h(me/ran; to be joined with a)gwni/sasqai, which is governed by kate/sthsa—‘I made them fight.’
e)c ou)=—with qarsou=sin. Though they won in 418, yet even in 415 their confidenee is not fully restored. This boast is of no value.
h( e). neo/ths kai\ a)/noia—joined also by Andoc. 2, 7.

para\ f. dokou=sa ei)=—with a)/noia only, which is added as an alternative for neo/ths. ‘This was the way in which my . . in dealing with the power of the Pel. was associated with reasonable arguments, and by its vehemence won credence and persuaded men.’ For the readings see crit. n. The antithesis in a)/noia and lo/gois pre/pousi contains the chief point of the sentence.
e)s . . du/namin means the hostile power of Pel., not the alliance formed by Alc.
o)rgh/ is ‘impulse’ rather than ‘anger.’ au)th/n—neo/thta, which throughout is uppermost in the speaker's mind.
pefo/bhsqe—M.T. § 107.
dokei= ei)=nai—carries us back to dokou=sa ei)=nai, and is somewhat sarcastic. Nicias worshipped eu(tuxi/a.

cummei/ktois—referring, not to the immigrations, but to the ehanges among the inhabitants under the Sicilian tyrants or at their fall. ‘Observers in Old Greece did not fail to contrast these constant changes with the comparative stability of things in their own cities. . . No man looked on the land in which he dwelled as really his country; each man in his schemes
reckoned on the chance of having to leave the city where he lived, and of finding house and lands elscwhere’ (Freeman).
e)pidoxa/s—the acceptance of new constitutions means really the acceptance of democracies, which in 415 were not so unstable as Alc. represents.

kai\ ou)dei/s—‘the result is that no one has obtained a supply of arms for his personal equipment or of suitable (nomi/mois = i(kanai=s Schol.) defences for the public property.’ kataskeuai/=permanent works, for which no proper provision has been made since the fall of the tyrants.
e)ch/rtutai—mid.

o(/ ti de/—‘but each man seeks to get only that which either by persuasive argument or by political strife he hopes to obtain and in case of failure to settle (with it) in another land.’ The money which ought to go in o(/pla and kataskeuai/ goes instead into the pockets of individuals: the politicians there think only of providing themselves with funds in view of the chance that they may be driven out. tau=ta after o(/ ti is a slight anacoluthon of a common kind.

e)k tou= le/gwn pei/qein—an allusion to the rise of rhetoric and oratory in Sicily. Diodorus 11, 87 speaks of the number of demagogues at Syracuse, circ. 450 B.C., kai\ lo/gou deino/ths u(po\ tw=n newte/rwn h)skei=to. If the pieture as given in Diod. is at all accurate, the deseription of Alc. contains much truth, at least as applied to the Syracuse of a somewhat earher time.
stasia/zwn=e)k tou= stasia/zein. Diod. l.c. sta/sewn gignome/nwn pa/lin . . h( po/lis ei)s sunexei=s kai\ mega/las e)ne/pipte taraxa/s.
o(/milon—this word is confined to poetry, to Herod., Thuc., and late authors.
w(s with e(/kastos and e(ka/teros without a verb, after Herod. and Thuc., first reappears in Aristotle.
kaq) h(donh/n—i.e. would be ready to join any one who could show by argument that he could serve them.

ou)/te oi( a)/lloi *(/ellhnes—‘neither did the rest of . . prove to be so numerous as the forces of the several states reckoned themselves to be; on the eontrary G., finding she was greatly deceived about their number, was with difficulty provided with an adequate force of hoplites in this war.’ As Alc. is not referring only to Athens and Sparta, and there were certainly hostilities in the Peloponnese, there is no difficulty in tw=|de, nor is there any ground for rejecting kai\ mh\n . . w(pli/sqh as spurious with Classen. Alc. himself was no believer in the Peace of Nicias.
kompw=—is an Ionie word.
barba/rous ga/r—explaining eu)porw/tera. The Sicels did in fact join the A. in large numbers.
oi( ga\r pate/res—i e. from 478 to 449 B.C.
a)ne/lpistoi—active, ‘despondent.’
nu=n is aecommodated to ei)/ te . . e)/rrwntai, where te corresponds to ou)/te, ‘even if they are ever so confident, to invade us is in their power.’
to\ me\n e)sba/llein is aecus. of ‘respect,’ as in II. 53 to\ me\n prostalaipwrei=n ou)dei\s pro/qumos h)=n (M.T. § 795).

bla/ptein—the real question is, Would Athens still have a fleet large enough to retaliate on the Pel. in ease of an invasion by making effective deseents on the coast of Pel.? e)stin means after subtracting the fleet for Sicily: but a)nti/palon begs the question.

ti/ a)\n le/gontes—‘by what reasonable assertion can we hold back ourselves or make excuse to our allies there for refusing to aid them?’ Thus ti/ a)\n ei)ko/s belongs to both clauses. au)ta/ is somewhat artificially contrasted with pro\s tou\s e)kei= cum.
mh\ bohqoi=men—the mh/ because prevention is implied (M. T. § 292).

kai\ cunwmo/samen—‘we actually exchanged oaths with them.’ Classen says this refers to the palaia\ cummaxi/a, for which see on c. 6, 2. The A. cannot have bound themselves by any oath which was unconditional, and they would be false to their oath only if they could not show that it was impossible for them to send help.

a)ntitiqe/nai—this sense of the verb may be compared with its noun a)nti/qesis, Quintihan's contrapositum. h(mi=n sc. e)ph/munan. Muller notes that Thuc. is very fond of compounds of a)nti/, which are well adapted to his style.
proseqe/meqa—se. pro\s th\n cummaxi/an.
e)xqroi=s—Sparta had applied for ships from her allies in Sicily at the beginning of the war, but without result.
ou(/tws—explained by paragigno/menoi.
h)=rcan is ‘ingressive’ aor.
h(suxa/coien—like quiescere, often opposed to armed intervention.
fulokrinoi=en—this rare verb, besides being explained by Hesychius and Pollux and in Bekker's Anecdota, is used twice by Aristides, and, according to Bloomfield, by other late authors.

braxu\ a)/n ti—‘while making only a small addition to the empire, we should be more likely to lose what we have already’; i.e. we, the Athenians, oi( prou/xontes, should soon find ourselves isolated if all Athenians were to act on the prineiples re
commended by Nicias; and thus in any undertaking, however slight, we should be more likely to lose than to gain. (This sentence is generally wrongly rendered.)

to\n ga\r prou/xonta—‘for against a superior power men not only defend themselves when attacked, but to eseape being attacked take action beforehand’; i.e. against a promincnt state which is isolated, smaller states can combine, and do so from fear of an attack, when they see that the superior power is bent on increasing its influence.

tamieu/esqai—Bloomfield quotes three instances of this verb used in this metaphorical sense by Xen. ‘We cannot regulate at will the limits that we choose for our empire, but being established in the position we occupy (i.e. as a ruling state) . . and not relax our hold on others.’
a)nie/nai with personal object, though not found elsewhere in Thuc., is common.
dia\ to\ a)rxqh=nai a)/n—either we must retain our own rule or fall under the rule of others. This statement is true of the ancient city-states, but would not hold nowadays.

e)k tou= au)tou=—with toi=s a)/llois=o(moi/ws w(/sper toi=s a)/llois: ‘you cannot regard inaction from the same point of view as others, unless you mean to alter your methods to the pattern of theirs.’

to\ h(/suxon is the general conception of h(suxi/a apart from special circumstances; but much more often the neut. adj. expresses the idea of the corresponding noun under special circumstances, the noun being the universal concept.
e)pithdeu/mata are the concrete outcomes of e)pith/deusis.
ta/de—ta\ e)ntau=qa pra/gmata Schol., in antithesis with e)p' e)kei=na.

store/swmen—met. from quelling a storm at sea. The edd. quote Aeseh. P.V. 190 th\n d' a)te/ramnon store/sas o)rgh/n, and Bloomfield compares the same use of sternere, as in Aen. VI. 858 sternet Poenos Gallumque rebellem.
u(perido/ntes—i.e. that we stand in no need of the present rest from hostilities.
tw=n e)kei=—neut.
e)n w)=|=‘while,’ as often.

to\ d' a)sfale/s—obj. to pare/cousi, kai\ me/nein kai\ a)p. being epexegetic of a)sfale/s. M.T. § 749. The suppression of the alternative to h)/n ti prosxwrh=| is in accordance with the Gk. love of avoiding distinct allusions to misfortune.
kai\ cumpa/ntwn—i e. all the Siceliots together. This is an answer to the argument of Nicias, c. 11, 4, that in case of any reverse the Siceliots would despise them.

*niki/ou—depends on tw=n lo/gwn: the speech of N. was characterised by or contains (1) a)pragmosu/nh, (2) dia/stasis toi=s ne/ois e)s tou\s p. This is one of the passages in Thuc. that prove that not only the possessive gen. is placed between the art. and noun. See e. 62, 5 n. The dat. toi=s ne/ois is somewhat unusual: ‘the difference for the young with the old’ is the lit. meaning; for there is no ground for taking dia/stasis as causal. a)pragmosu/nh= ‘avoidance of trouble’ for all the citizens, and dia/stasis, ‘a dispute for the young,’ are the two jarring notes of the speech. ‘Let not the avoidance of effort and the dispute . . which N. sets out in his speech . .’
w(/sper kai\ oi( pate/res—Classen notes that these words recall sentiments expressed by Pericles.
e)s ta/de—deictie.
au)ta: applies to the matter being discussed, as in c. 10, 2.

to/ te fau=lon—‘Bauer says there is reference to the three ages of man—the juvenilc, the virile, and the senile; thus understanding fau=lon to denote the first. . . There is an allusion to the position they may be thought to occupy in the exercise of counsel—the raw, the mature, and the quite consummate judgments’ (Bloomfield). It is supposed that Alc. is speaking sarcastically, himself meaning rather the old by fau=lon. But all this ingenuity is needless. Alc. only means that it is wrong to imply, as N. did, that only the old are fit to settle the matter. The right way is for all—young or old— whether their ability be ‘inferior,’ ‘average,’ or ‘consummate,’ to take part in affairs. The best result is obtained by this fusion of abilities.
cugkraqe/n is conditional. Cf. VIII. 97 metri/a h)/ te e)s tou\s o)li/gous kai\ e)s tou\s pollou\s cu/gkrasis.

tri/yesqai—passive, also in VII. 42, 5 au/tou\s peri\ e(autou/s occurs in the same sense in VIII. 46. Poppo, I. 1, 192 gives a collection of fut. mid. used by Thuc. in pass. sense; cf. a)dikh/somai c. 87, bla/yomai c. 64. Alc. argues as though Athens had not already enough to occupy her energy in counteracting the infiuence of Sparta within her empire: e)a\n me\n h(suxa/zh| begs the question. Kr.'s e)a/n is probably right.

pa/ntwn th\n e)pisth/mhn e)gghra/sesqai—the position of te after tri/yesqai and proslh/yesqai shows that th\n po/lin is the subject of all the infinitives. Hence trans. ‘as regards her knowledge of everything, she will grow old therein.’ pa/ntwn is neut.; e)gghra/sesqai=ghra/sesqai e)n (th=| e)pisth/mh|), the compound being one of several compounds of e/n that require a personal or quasi-personal subject. The construction is the same as in Eur. Bacchae 508 e)ndustuxh=sai tou)/nom' e)pith/deios ei)=. See Sandys' note. According to Stahl e)gghra/sesqai=ghra/-
sesqai e)n tw=| tri/besqai; but this construction cannot be got out of the passage.

kai\ to\ a)mu/nesqai—‘and will be more accustomed to defend herself by action rather than by mere words.’ ou) lo/gw| a)ll) e)/rgw| belongs to to\ a)mu/nesqai, the policy of Nicias being described as to\ lo/gw| a)mu/nesqai.

gignw/skw . . moi dokei=n—‘on the whole I judge that in my opinion a state accustomed to activity would quickly be ruined by a change to inactivity.’ For gignw/skw with infin, see M.T. § 915. moi dokei=n is not superfluons, but is intended to emphasise the contrast between the views of Alc. and Nic.
kai\ tw=n a)nqrw/pwn ktl—this sentiment has become a commonplace, but is capable of being variously applied. The datives go with diafo/rws.
fuga/dwn—this and the rel. clause belong to *aeonti/nwn only.
o(rki/wn—see e. 6, 2.
sfi/si—being the indirect reflexivc, this refers to the subject of i(ke/teuon.
ei) pollh\n e)—this hope of N. was, as Freeman says, ‘not quite honest.’ It is strange that he did not resign.
au)toi=s au)=qis—with parelqw/n.
e)pi\ tw=| paro/nti—‘under the circumstances.’ Cf. e)pi\ tou/tois c. 45.

ou)/q) u(phko/ous . . ou)de\ deome/nas—their internal freedom is here insisted on. It is not possible for Athens to raise the cry of e)leuqeri/a in Sicily as Sparta had done in Greece. With one or two exceptions, says Freeman, such as that of the relations between Syr. and Leontini, ‘this is a perfectly true description of the politieal states of the Greeks of Sicily at the time. Since the fall of the tyrants, the great body of the Siceliot cities had been truly free and independent.’
e)s . . xwroi/h—expressing eagerness, as in e)xw/rhsan e)pi\ th\n a)/ntikrus e)leuqeri/an VIII. 64.
ou)/t' a)\n th\n a)rxh/n—their foreign relations are now contrasted with their internal condition.

to/ te plh=qos—‘as for their number, the cities of Greek origin are many for a single island.’ ta\s *(ellhni/das is added emphatically at the end. po/lis is the only noun with which Thuc. uses the adj. *(ellhni/s.

e(pta/—Selinus, Syracuse, Gela, Acragas, Messene, Himera, Carnarina. Acrae and Casmenae are not reckoned, as
being merely outposts of Syracuse, using the same coinage and possessing no separate history.
toi=s pa=sin—cf. II. 36 th\n po/lin toi=s pa=si pareskeua/samen.
o(moiotro/pws ma/lista—‘so as to closely resemble our own power.’

duna/mei is not ‘the armanent’ that is to be sent out, but includes all the details that make up the power of A., in the same sense as du/namin of c. 21. Cf. VII. 55 po/lesi . . o(moiotro/pois e)pelqo/ntes, dhmokratoume/nais te w)/sper kai\ au)toi\ kai\ nau=s kai\ i(/ppous kai\ mege/qh e)xou/sais.
e)/neisi—i.e. in Selinus and Syracuse.
o( plhrw/swn—M.T. § 826; II. 51, 5 a)pori/a| tou= qerapeu/sontos. 20
e)n toi=s i(eroi=s—public money stored in temples and the sacred treasures of the temples themselves.

e)/sti *selinounti/ois, *surakosi/ois de\ kai/—the first clause refers specially to Selinus; but the kai/ of the next shows that Syracuse is not excluded from the statement. ‘Selinus has money . .: Syracuse receives in addition . .’

a)parxh\ e)sfe/retai—‘first-fruits are contributed.’ Some of the Sicels were dependent on Syracuse, and lived on their land on sufferance, paying a rent in kind. Hence in c. 45 to the dependent Sicels fu/lakes are seut by Syr. to seeure them ou the coming of the Athenians. Some Sicels had even become serfs at Syracuse in the earliest times of the city, under the title kallu/rioi (Freeman, Sic. II. Appendix II.) For the variant a)p' a)rxh=s fe/retai see not, crit.

i(/ppous—cf. Pindar, Pyth. II. 1 *megalapo/lies w)= *sura/kosai, baqupole/mou te/menos *)/areos, a)ndrw=n i(/ppwn te sidaroxarma=n daimo/niai trofoi/. Soph. O.C. 507 gunai=x' o(rw= | stei/xousan h)mw=n a)=sson, *ai)tnai/as e)pi\ | pw/lou bebw=san. Athens, on the contrary, had to buy her horses from Boeotia and elsewhere.

si/tw|—Sicily has always been famed for its corn. (See Freeman, Sic I. pp. 67, 91.) On the contrary, Athens had to import corn, mainly from the ports of the Euxine, also from Euboea, and shortly after this time from Cyprus. She was on several occasions in great straits on this account when an enemy controlled the sea.

fau/lou—the sense cannot be ‘mean,’ ‘poor,’ as L. & S. say, since N. would appear to be disparaging the A. naval power by the connexiou with nautikh=s. o( dh=mo/s e)stin o( e)lau/nwn ta)s nau=s kai\ o( th\n du/namin peritiqei\s th=| po/lei ([Xen.] Ath. Pol. init.). fau=los strati/a is the ordinary or conventional force required for a naval expedition. It is a feature of the
Sic. expedition that there were soldiers in unusual numbers on board.

dei=—constructed with infin. in the clauses that follow. It is a recognised principle that a verb that admits of two constrnctions may appear in the same sentence with both: e.g. VIII. 4 pareskeua/zonto . . th/n te nauphgi/an . . kai\ *sou/nion teixi/santes, where we have paraskeua/zomai constructed first with the accus. and theu with the partic.
ei)/per—‘that is if,’ or ‘assuming that.’ Cf. Xen. Oec. 1, 8 ou) xrh/mat' au)tw=| e)stin o( i(/ppos; *ou)/k, ei)/per ta\ xrh/mata/ g' e)sti\n a)gaqo/n. o( pezo/s=o( p. strato/s is Ionic.
a)/cion . . dra=n—equivalent to a)/cio/n ti dra=n. Cf. II. 91 a)cu/mforon drw=ntes.

u(po\ i(ppe/wn—N. ‘fears that the eities will combine, and that Segesta alone will be left to give auy help against the horsemen. But he says nothing about bringing together auy force of cavalry on the A. side. That Segesta was likely to supply horse appears from c. 37, 1; 62, 9; 98, 1’ (Freeman).

a)/llws te ka)\n custw=sin—all the good MSS. give ei) with subj. here only in Thuc. It occurs occasionally in tragedy, and is frequent in Lucian. Probably a)/llws te ka)/n should be read, as in I. 141.
w(=| a)munou/meqa—final rel. sentence: sc. i(ppe/as pollou/s.
au)to/qen—‘at once,’ at the start, instead of waiting to send for reinforcements.

ou)k e)n tw=| o(. strateuso/menoi—co-ordinate with a)po\ th=s h(mete/ras au)tw=n. Hence to strateuso/menoi supply me/llomen plei=n. The lit. rendering is ‘we are about to make a voyage to serve in a campaign not as you served, where among your subjects here you attacked any one as allies.’ The contrast is between an offensive alliance near home and an offensive alliance in a distant country; and the difference lies in the placc. When the neighbourhood is friendly, there is no such difficulty as will be encountered in Sicily. cu/mmaxoi does not mean that A. was in the habit of making an alliance specially to attack a place (as Aruold thought), but is used for the sake of the antithesis of the ordinary relation existing between A. and her u(ph/kooi, which is cummaxi/a, with the unusual cummaxi/a in Sicily.
kai/—‘as,’ so that e)strateu/sasqe is implied from strateuso/menoi. On the readings see crit. n.
o(/qen—sc. h)=san. The copula is frequently omitted after rel. words, esp. after o(/sos. In Lat. prose the corresponding omission is rare before the silver period.
prose/dei—necessary in addition to what had been taken au)to/qen.

a)parth/santes—sc. strateuso/menoi. The word is explained by the Schol.: a)parthqe/ntes, a)pelqo/ntes, kai\ polu\ th=s oi)kei/as xwrisqe/ntes. The only passage that supports the supposed intrans. use of the act. is Dio Cass. 51, 4, 2 quoted by Pape and Clas. Now to a)parth/santes supply a)po\ th=s h(mete/ras au)tw=n from above—the main point being that the armament is separated from, cut off from home, and transferred to a distant land. Thus e)s . . a)parth/santes repeats with an addition polu\ . . me/llomen plei=n. The object of a)parth/santes (th\n paraskeuh/n) is implied in the preceding words, and its omission is no more than the ordinary omission of an object with military words. The phrase e)s gh=n a)parta=n is a brachylogy for ‘to cut off (and place) in a country.’

ou)de/—misplaced, if the sense is—what it is always assumed to be—‘from which not even a messenger can easily come in the four winter months.’ But what no onc can tell is why N., if he means this, should say ‘from which not even within four months, I mean in the winter months, is it easy for a messenger to come.’ Surely N. means what he says. He puts the case in its worst light. Should it be required to send at beginning of winter, it would be difficult for a messenger to go, and he might have to wait for spring, or put into an Italian or even a Libyan port for refuge. The months are Maimacteriou, Posideon, Gamelion, Anthesterion, corresponding roughly to November, December, January, and February, and they are taken not singly, but as together making up the time when voyaging was dangerous.

tw=n xeimerinw=n—by no means a gloss on tessa/rwn, as some have supposed, but absolutely necessary; for without them the statement made by N. would be a manifest absurdity. With them the statement is a debater's argument of a quibbling character.
o(pli/tas te—answered by kai\ toco/tas.
cumma/xwn—these are divided into (1) tw=n u(phko/wn, (2) h)/n tina ktl.
pei=sai—the Argives and Mantineans joined thus. See on c. 29, 3 n. The Areadians joined misqw=|, being in the habit of serving as mercenaries (VII. 57).
nausi/ te—te adds the third particular, as often in Thuc.

to
 de/—Stahl renders ‘and take other supplies from home,’ as though we had above si=ton to
 me
 e)skomi/zesqai. This rendering accounts satisfactorily for the order of kai\ au)to/qen, which
belongs to a)/gein, and appears to be right. Stahl quotes several parallels. e)pith/deia and si=ton mean the same thing; and nausi/, ships in general, is contrasted with e)n o(lka/si.

pro\s me/ros—with e)k tw=n mulw/nwn, i.e. in proportion to the number of bakers in the several mills These slaves are to be requisitioned by the state (h)nagkasme/noi); but, as they belong to private owners, they are to receive pay for their services, like state slaves.

pollh\ ga\r ou)=sa—with the personal construction used here Fr. Muller well compares II. 36 au)ta\ ou)k a)\n a)preph= ei)=nai lexqh=nai. Cf. Soph. O.T. 393 to/ g' ai)/nigm' ou)xi\ tou)pio/ntos h)=n | a)ndro\s dieipei=n.
ta\ par' *)e. . . e(toi=ma ei)=nai—as in I. 69 ta\ par' u(mw=n a)ci/ws proapanth=sai. ‘The support of Segesta’ is that promised in c. 8, 2.
le/getai—the passive is used both personally and impersonally, and regularly with infiu.
kai\ lo/gw|—there is a play on the double meaning of le/gw, lo/gos—statement and pretence.
au)toi/—belougs in seuse to a)nti/palon paraskeuasa/menoi: ‘with a force of our own not merely equal to that of the enemy’ (Jowett).

plh/n ge—if to\ o(plitiko/n is made part of the parenthesis, the meauing is open to grave doubt. (a) The note in Jowett explains: ‘While exhorting the A., he is secretly discouraging them. “You must do all you can to be a match for your opponents” is the general drift of the previous chapter, and yet he throws in by the way, “but in the great arm of war [the hoplites] you caunot be a match for them.”’ But (1) Nicias nowhere introduces this disparity of hoplites, of which so much might have been made as an argument against the expedition. (2) How, after an exception so vital, could he add u(perba/llontes toi=s pa=si? (3) How in c. 31 could Thuc. say of the A. force that its superiority over that of the euemy was conspicuous, if in the great arm of war N. can assert that it will of course be inferior? Would not such a statement from a responsible general be ridiculous? (b) Classen makes to\ o(plitiko/n refer to the A. hoplites, and makes the sense ‘except as regards our hoplites as compared with their whole fighting force’; but Stahl rightly objects that the comparison should then be between part and part, not between part and whole, of the rival forces. The remedy is not to read to\ i(ppiko/n with Urlichs,—for N. had proposed to take a force of sfendonh=tai and toco/tai which should be a)nti/palon to the enemy's cavalry,—but to make to\ o(plitiko/n the object of paras keuasa/menoi. Hence trans. ‘not only with a
force of hoplites a match for them, except when compared with their fighting strength (i e. with our hoplites equal to their hoplites), but actually surpassing them in every point.

to\ ma/ximon au)tw=n—this is the whole of the enemy's forces. The A. were in the habit of relying on their hoplites in the field: N. reminds them that there are other kinds of troops to be reckoned with besides hoplites. He is referring back to his remark in c. 22, 1. Not only must the hoplites be a match for them (excluding of course their cavalry), but hoplites and light-armed troops must be more than a match for their whole fighting force, and even thus it will be hard to deal with them. to\ o(plitiko/n is in an emphatic position, because it is contrasted with to\ e)kei/nwn i\ppiko/n, as in c. 22.

u(perba/llontes—the antithesis between this and a)nti/palon paraskeuasa/menoi to\ o(plitiko\n plh/n ge pro\s to\ ma/ximon au)tw=n is more formal than real: for the former words already imply that the A. hoplite force taken separately will be superior to the enemy's hoplite force taken separately.

toi=s pa=si—omnibus rebus. Of course A. cavalry are excepted after what has been said in c. 22. tw=n me\n kratei=n, ta\ de\ kai\ diasw=sai—tw=n me/n is neut.; but different explanations are given of the meaning. (a) Stahl renders ‘aliis potiri, alia (quibus potiti erimus) etiam in tuto locare,’ thus referring both tw=n me/n and ta\ de/ to the enemy; ‘to seize on some positions and to hold permanently others’ (Wilkins). (b) Classen accepts the Scholiast's note: tw=n me/n=tw=n e)kei= pragma/twn, ta\ de/=ta\ oi)kei=a; ‘to conquer Sicily, or indeed to preserve ourselves’ (Jowett). That (b) is right is shown by the sentence that follows. It will be hard, says N., to conquer what we require to conquer, and even to preserve what we require to preserve: we should consider ourselves to be men who have to found a city in a hostile land—who have to fight for the soil— tw=n me\n kratei=n—and to protect what we bring—ta\ de\ kai\ diasw=sai.
diasw=sai—not ingressive, but giving the result,=‘to bring safe through.’

po/lin te—‘and (further developing the previous idea) we must consider that it is a city among an alien and hostile population that our men are setting out to found.’ The warning that in setting out to make new conquests one runs the risk of losing what he has already in case of failure, is common in Thuc. To
i)e/nai supply tou/tous.
kata/sxwsin—sc. ta\s nau=s: appulerint.

kratei=n th=s gh=s—explains tw=n me\n kratei=n above, while
pa/nta pole/mia e(/cousin is a rcason for saying mo/lis oi(=oi t' e)so/meqa ta\ de\ diasw=sai.

xalepo\n de/—sc. polla\ eu)tuxh=sai. The edd. make xalepo/n depend on ei)dw/s, sc. o)/n; but it is better to supply e)sti/, and to regard the sentence as a parenthesis. This remark is very characteristic of N., who made eu)tuxi/a the chief object of life. Observe the personal tone of this section. N. betrays a fear that his spell of eu:tuxi/a may be broken.
paraskeuh=| . . a)sfalh/s—antithesis to th=| tu/xh| paradou/s. So in VII. 67 paraskeuh=s pi/stis is coutrasted with tu/xhs p.
a)po\ tw=n ei)ko/twn—i.e. so far as human calculation can ensure safety. Human gnw/mh is always liable to be crossed by divine tu/xh.

tau=ta ga\r . . bebaio/tata . . swth/ria—see Index II. fines, telika\ kefa/laia, i.e. the points on which a speaker insists in order to persuade. Here they are to\ be/baion and to\ swth/rion, and these may be considered varieties of to\ sumfe/ron.

ei) de/ tw|—i.e. if any of the ten strategi not appointed to the command takes a different view. It is indeed probable that other members of the board besides Nicias, Alcibiades, and Lamachus were going to Sicily, but with powers subordinate to theirs. Thus an inscription (Hicks, Gr. Ins. p. 96), referring to the official year July 416-July 415, mentions Antimachus among the strategi sent to Sicily along with Lamachus and Alcibiades.
tw=n pragma/twn—‘by the scale of the requirements’: cf. c. 19, 2 paraskeuh=s plh/qei. The second h)\ = ei) de\ mh/: the first is probably spurious.
ei) a)nagka/coito—if nobody would take the command instead.
a)sfalw=s—another of N.'s catch-words, to which there is a sarcastic reference below.

to\ me\n e)piqumou=n—the partic. used as a noun occurs fairly often in Thuc., especially in the speeches. Like thc articular infin., and the frequent use of nouns in -sis and -th/s, it is a mark of the semno/ths, ‘dignity,’ of Thuc. Very similar is Dr. Johnson's use of long nouns of Latin origin.

tou= plou=—this is not the geu. usually employed with the noun-participle: in the ordinary type the partic. expresses a quality belonging to the substantive, as in to\ h(su/xazon th=s nukto/s VII. 83; to\ qumou/menon th=s gnw/mhs VII. 68. a)sfa/leia—dokw=, ‘seem,’ usually has thc personal construction. Goodwin, M.T. § 754.
nu=n dh/—‘now there would be no risk,’ since N. had explained the measures by which even he admitted it could be avoided.
e)/rws e)ne/pese—cf. Aesch. Agam. 332 e)/rws de\ mh/ tis pro/teron e)mpi/pth| stratw=| | porqei=n a(\ mh\ xrh/.
toi=s me\n ga/r—sc. e)/rws e)ne/pese.
katastreyome/nois e)f) a(\ e)/pleon—cf. VII. 11 krath/santas *surakosi/ous e)f) ou(\s e)pe/mfqhmen.
h)\ (w(s) ou)de\n a)\n sfalei=san meg. du/namin—the accus. abs., which with personal verbs requires w(s or w(/sper. Goodwin, M.T. § 853.
h(liki/a|—i.e. the age for military service.
th=s a)pou/shs ktl = poqou=ntes i)dei=n kai\ qewrei=n ta\ a)/ponta, the expression being, as Bohme says, poetical. o)/yews kai\ q. = ‘sights and wonders,’ being passive in sense.

eu)e/lpides o)/ntes—anacoluthon, as though oi( de\ e)po/qoun had preceded. Cf. II. 53, 4 qew=n fo/bos . . ou)dei\s a:pei=rge, to\ me\n kri/nontes: III. 36 e)/docen au)toi=s . . e)pikalou=ntes: Eur. Hec. 971 ai)dw/s m' e)/xei . . tugxanou=sa.
o( de\ polu\s o(/milos—sc. eu)/elpis w)/n.

kai\ stratiw/ths—Kruger quotes Plut. Per. 12 to\n qhtiko\n o)/xlon kai\ i)diw/thn, and strat. is best taken as an adj., so that the phrase = oi( polloi\ kai\ stratiw=tai. Classen and Bohme object that this leaves kai/ unexplained, and take kai\ strat. as part of the pred. with Dobree. But o( polu\s o)/milos = that part of the o)/milos which was not so far stratiw/ths—had not, for whatever reason, served before. Thuc. makes two distinct points in the section: (1) all alike were eager to go, both young and old, and were confident; (2) the multitude and all those who had served before hoped to make money. These points would be much clearer if he had begun a new sentence after qewri/as.

a)i/dion misqofora/n—this is explained by editors to mean that the addition of Sicily to the empire would lead to continual campaigns; but Gilbert rightly paraphrases: ‘they hoped to get permanent employment out of the acquisition somehow’: misqofora/ is used loosely for pay for any services.
u(pa/rcein—the attraction of short rel. clauses into infin. in reported speech is less rare in Gk. than in Lat. Thuc. has nine instances.
kako/nous . . th=| po/lei—the application of the phrase here reminds us of Dr. Johnson's description of Patriotism as ‘the last refuge of a scoundrel.’

parelqw/n tis—Plutarch, Nic. c 12 says this was Demostratus the demagogue. He is attacked by Aristoph.
in the Lysistrata 387 f as an eager supporter of the Sicilian expedition.
diame/llein—Aristoph. Av. 639 ou)xi\ nusta/zein g' e)/ti | w)/ra 'sti\n h(mi=n ou)de\ mellonikia=n. Plut. Nic. 16 calls him tolmh=sai mellh/ths.
yhfi/swntai—deliberative: the recta being ti/na p. *)aqhnai=oi yhfi/swntai; M.T. § 289. The 3rd person is rare, except with tis.
a)/kwn me/n—sc. ei)=pe de/. Cf. the formula e)gw\ me\n oi)=mai without a de/ clause following.
kaq) h(suxi/an ma=llon—‘where there would be less interruption’ than in the assembly.

o(/sa . . dokei=n—this is not the attracted infin. of c. 24, 3; the recta is o(/sa dokei=n (M.T. § 759), and the infin. depends on the idea of sufficiency in o(/sa. See also M.T. § 778, where similar expressions with w(s and o(/son are collected.
e)/lasson—see c. 1, 2.
e(kato/n—a fleet of this number had been sent out by Athens in the first two years of the war to make descents on the coasts of the Peloponnese, and again in 428 for the same purpose.
pleuste/a—the plur. form of the impers. verbal, as in c. 50, 5.

au)tw=n d' *)aqhnai/wn—‘of the vessels belonging to Athens herself as many as they thought necessary would be transports, and they must send to the allies for more ships.’ For the o(plitagwgoi/ or stratiwti/des see c. 43, 2.
h)\n de/ ti du/nwntai—‘if they find any means of doing so.’

w(s kata\ lo/gon—two explanations are given of this phrase: (1) Classen and Stahl say it is the same as w(s e(/kastos (in Herod. and Thuc.) without a verb, so that the full form is w(s kata\ lo/gon e(toima/sainto a)/n: (2) Kruger compares w(s with numerals, so that the sense is ‘about in proportion.’ The former is apparently right, because the number of the hoplites is left uncertam, and the other numbers are to depend on the number of hoplites ultimately fixed.

e(toimasa/menoi—when a plural subj. of infin. includes the subject of the main verb as here, whether in whole or in part, it is put in the nom. or accus. at will. Cf. VII. 48, 1 o( *niki/as e)no/mize . . laqei=n a)\n . . poiou=ntes.

kai\ peri\ stratia=s plh/qous ktl—this vote shows how chary the Ecclesia was of delegating its authority even to the Strategi. Even this did not excuse them from their responsibility: they would still have to render an account
(eu)/quna) on laying down their office, and might be prosecuted if they made mistakes (VII. 48). Gardner and Jevons, Manual p. 470.
e)gi/gneto—see Index s. gi/gnomai.

katalo/gous—the men were selected by means of kata/logoi xrhstoi/ (c. 31, 3)—i.e. the generals made out lists of the best men from the lists of all those liable to service, which were engraved on the forty-two bronze sth=lai that stood before the Council chamber (Ath. Pol. c. 53; cf. Gardner and Jevons, p. 637). The kata/logoi or lists so formed were also set up in public. (The explanation of Gilbert that kata/logos means a list kept by the taxiarch of each tribe can no longer be maintained. kata/logos is simply the list of men who are to serve on a campaign, however formed.) In the present case both the number and the selection of the names were left to the Strategi.
tou= cunexou=s pole/mou—i.e. from 431-421; cf. II. 1 katasta/ntes cunexw=s e)pole/moun: v. 24 tau=ta ta\ de/ka e/th o( prw=tos po/lemos cunexw=s geno/menos.
e)s—‘with regard to,’ as often.
xrhma/twn—7000 talents had been stored in the Treasury during the Peace of Nicias, if Andocides and Aeschines are to be trusted.
a)/qroisin—cf. Ath. Pol. c. 24 xrhma/twn h)qroisme/nwn pollw=n.
o(/soi *(ermai= h)=san—Plutarch says tw=n *(ermw=n oi( presbu/teroi a)/xeires kai\ a)/podes. See Mayor on Juv. VIII. 53. Grote's account of the mutilation should be read.

e)n th=| po/lei—Plutarch says that Hipparchus the Pisistratid set up several of these figures. They were also put up from time to time by tribes, magistrates, and individuals, especially abont the Agora, through which ran the street of Hermes.
h( tetra/gwnos e)rgasi/a—‘the well-known square figures,’

oi( plei=stoi—according to Andocides (de Myst. § 62) the bust before his house was the only one that escaped, and this is repeated by Nepos, Alcib. 3; perhaps also by Philochorus (280 B.C.) ap. Schol. on Aristoph. Lys. 1094 th
 d' ai)ti/an oi( me
 toi=s peri\ *)alkibia/dhn prose/grafon, w(s *qoukudi/dhs, oi( de\ *korinqi/ois w(s *filo/xoros mo/non de/ [leg. d' ou)/] fhsi perikoph=nai to
 *)andoki/dou *(ermh=n.

mega/lois mhnu/trois—the reward was 100 minae according to a proposal of Pisander, 1000 drachmae according to a proposal of Cleonymus. The sums were snbsequently awarded to two informers by the Thesmothetae (Andoc. § 27).

e)yhfi/santo—from Andoc. we learn that the Ecclesia
delegated the duty of investigating the outrage to the Council— yhfisame/nhs th=s boulh=s, h)=n ga\r au)tokra/twr. The Council appointed (Andoc. 1.10) special commissioners (zhthtai/) to receive and examine the evidence. mhnu/ein—mh/nusis is an information given privately by a slave, metic, woman, or by a citizen who preferred not to raise an ei)saggeli/a (‘impeachment’) because he was implicated. It could be given either ei)s th\n boulhn or e)n tw=| dh/mw|. The matter, if serious, was settled in a court of heliasts. The mhnuth/s often received a reward if the accused person was convicted, and if a slave received freedom. If his information was proved to be false, he was put to death. ei)saggeli/a = delatio: mh/nusis = indicium.

a)dew=s—the a)/deia, i.e. impunitas, exempted a mhnuth/s from punishment in case he incriminated himself. Ordmarily the Ecclesia alone was competent to give the a)/deia: but the Conncil, when as here it was au)tokra/twr, could confer it on each individual mhnuth/s. (Cf. Goldstaub, De a)dei/as Notione et Usu p. 99.)
to\n boulo/menon—stereotyped phrase, as also kai\ a)stw=n kai( ce/nwn.
meizo/nws—the form is found in Herod., Plato, Eur., and Xenophon, often in Aristides. For
lamba/nein cf. c. 53, 3; 61, 1.
oi)wno/s—ominous of evil, because it was a gross insult to the protecting deity of market and home.
e)pi\ cunwmosi/a|—cf. c. 60, 1.
dh/mou kata/lusis is one of the crimes to which the no/mos ei)saggeltiko/s applied. The crime was first dealt with by Solon, and is often alluded to.
a)po/—cf. c. 45, 1 a)po\ tw=n katasko/pwn safh= h)g- ge/lleto: I. 20 e)k tw=n cuneido/twn memhnu=sqai: c. 36, 2.

metoi/kwn . . kai\ a)kolou/qwn—the informations were preceded by an ei)saggeli/a made in the Ecclesia by Pythonicus against Alcibiades, who produced a slave prepared to give information about the profanation of the Mysteries (Andoc. § 11). The other slaves and the metics here alluded to must have given information peri\ a)/llwn a)galma/twn perikopw=n. Nothing further is heard of these latter.
ta\ musth/ria—‘the memorable instance of Alcibiades shows how deeply the Athenian people resented any attempt to desecrate their much-loved Mysteries’ (Gardner and Jevons, p. 276).
e)f) u(/brei—‘in mockery’; cf Eur. Orest. 1581 ka)f) u(/brei le/geis ta/de.
kai\ to\n *)alkibia/dhn—‘A. among others.’ Andromachus gave ten names in his mh/nusis.
au)ta/—applying generally, as often, to what has been said before.
oi( . . a)xqo/menoi—foremost among these was Androcles the demagogue, who was put to death in 411.

ou)de\n ei)/h au)tw=n—it is generally agreed among modern writers that Alc. had nothing to do with the mutilation of the Hermae. The authors of the mutilation remain unknown, and various views are held; the most probable being that the outrage was the work of oligarchs, undertaken with a view to rnin Alcibiades, and used with the same purpose by some of the extreme democrats. In none of the lists of Hermocopids furnished by informers did Alcibiades's name occur.
ou) dhmotikh/n—‘unconstitutional.’

e(toi=mos h)=n . . kri/nesqai—i.e. he wished the ei)saggeli/a of Pythonicus to be tried in a court at once. But (by a vote of the Assembly) the case was postponed, everything being ready for the expedition to depart. [ei)/ ti tou/twn ei)r. h)=n]—this h)=n ought to be e)sti/, since the clause would necessarily be an indirect question. On the other hand ei) me\n . . ei)/rgasto below is an unusual form of condition, representing ei) me\n . . ei)/rgasmai (compare M.T. § 701).
ta\ th=s p—‘the details of the armament.’
a)/rxein—‘retain his command.’
e)pemartu/reto—(1) with infin. = ‘beseech’; (2) with o(/ti = ‘urge.’ a)po/ntos pe/ri au)tou=—a)po/ntos is placed first because it is emphatic.
pri\n diagnw=si—M.T. § 648; cf. c. 10, 5.

e)pi\ tosou/tw| s—‘in command of so large an army.’ This is the only instance of this use in Thuc.; but cf. Dinarchus I. 74 e)pi\ toi=s ce/nois . . e)ge/neto: Demosth. 54, 3 e(/wsper h)=men e)pi\ th=| froura=|.
to/ te stra/teuma . . o(/ te dh=mos—cf. II. 22 e)kklhsi/an te ou)k e)poi/ei . . th/n te po/lin e)fu/lasse. The double te is often thus used to introduce the details.

mh\ eu)/noun e)/xh|—i.e. the case would not be decided on its merits. There is no doubt that Alcibiades was guilty of profaning the Mysteries, but he trusted to the support of his political club (e(tairei/a) and of the army to gain a victory over the extreme democrats. Many of the oligarchs were doubtless as guilty as he.
di' e)kei=non—c. 16, 6.
a)pe/trepon kai\ a)pe/speudon—imperf. of attempt. Bloomfield quotes Herod. VII. 17 o\ a)pospeu/dwn *ce/rchn strateu/esqai . . a)potra/pwn to\ xreo\n gene/sqai.
e)nie/ntes = subornantes, not found elsewhere in Attic in this sense.
e)/legon = suadebant.
e)lqo/nta = ‘on his return.’

e)n h/me/rais r(htai=s—‘within a fixed time after his return’; cf. Demosth. 23, 72 ti/ ou)=n o( no/mos keleu/ei; . . e)/n tisin ei/rhme/nois xro/nois a)pelqei=n. Aeschines II. 109 bouleu/sasqai to\n dh=mon u(pe\r ei/rh/nhs e)n taktai=s h(me/rais.
e)k mei/zonos diabolh=s . . a)gwni/sasqai—as in Lys. 3, 48 e)k toiou/twn pragma/twn ei)s toiou/tous a)gw=nas katasth=nai.

qe/rous mesou=ntos h)/dh—cf. Isaeus 6, 14 th=| stratia| a)f) ou(= e)ce/pleusan ei/s *sikeli/an h)/dh e)sti\ du/o kai\ penth/konta e)/th, a)po\ *)areimnh/stou a)/rxontos. With this date the Schol. on Aristoph. Birds hypoth. 11 agrees. Arimnestus went out of office on the last day of Scirophorion (June-July) 415. Hence the date of the departure is about the end of June.
ei)/rhto—often used of military instructions.
*ke/rkuran . . *)iapugi/an—the regular route from Greece to Italy (see on c. 13 § 1) in the time of Thuc. The Durazzo (Epidamnus)-Brindisi route dates from about 200 B.C.
diabalou=sin—found only in Herod., Thuc., and tragedy in this sense, and in late anthors.

cugkate/bh—anaphora of kataba/ntes above. Cf. I. 115 e)pane/sths an . . a/pe/sthsan . . cunape/sthsan. It is most frequent with compounds of a)nti-, as in I. 30 e)stratopedeu/onto . . a/ntestratopedeu/onto.
a)/pas w(s ei)pei=n—‘almost all,’ the regular use of w(s (e)/pos) ei)pei=n being to limit a general statement.
oi( me\n e)pixw/rioi—answered by oi( de\ ce/noi ktl. in c. 31, 1.
prope/mpein = prosequi.

met' e)lpi/dos . . i)o/ntes—cf. VII. 57 paia/nwn meq) w(=n e)ce/pleon. It is strange that Xenophon almost always uses su/n in this particular sense. as le/getai su\n polloi=s dakru/ois a)poxwrh=sai (Cyrop. I. 4, 26), except with abstract nouns in -ia, with which he always writes meta/.
ta\ me\n w(s kth/sointo—‘(hoping) that they might gain Sicily.’ M.T. §§ 128, 136

tou\s d' ei)/ pote—‘(lamenting) that they might never see their friends again.’ This is the same use of ei) as appears after verbs of fearing, M.T. § 376; Eur. Med. 184 a)ta\r fo/bos ei)
pei/sw. But metus si = ‘fear lest,’ Tac. An. 1, 11 quibus unus metus si intellegere viderentur.

o)/yointo—this and c. 34, 5 ei) u(pode/cointo, are the only two examples of ei) with fut. opt. in Thuc., and they may both be regarded as interrogative uses of ei). In conditional sentences Thuc. almost invariably retains the indic. after ei) in O.O.
meta\ kindu/nwn—c. 72, 4; ‘in dangerous circuinstances.’
au)tou\s e)sh/|ei—‘in mentem venit periculorum.’
ta\ deina/ is commonly used of danger.

th=| parou/sh| r(w/mh| . . th=| o)/yei—cf. VII. 71 a)po\ tw=n drwme/nwn th=s o)/yews kai( th\n gnw/mhn . e)doulou=nto: ib. 75 th=| te o)/yei e(ka/stw| a)lgeina\ kai\ th=| gnw/mh| ai)sqe/sqai. In dia\ to\ plh=qos . . e(w/rwn, which explains r(w/mh|, we have the cause of the qa/rsos in a material form: ‘owing to the strength in which they were present, through the vastness of the forces that they saw, they were cheered by the sight.’ The addition of dia\ . . e(w/rwn is due to the fact that r(w/mh is not wholly a concrete word, but means ‘spirit’ as well as ‘strength’ and suggests high nervous tension. This inserted clause enables Thuc. to proceed naturally from th=| r(w/mh| to th=| o)/yei.
e(ka/stwn w(=n e(w/rwn—cf. II. 59 ai)/tion pa/ntwn w(=n e)/tuxon. The adj. is not often inserted before such noun-relative sentences.

oi( de\ ce/noi—strictly speaking, a participle parallel to prope/mpontes above ought to follow. Such an auacoluthon is not uncommon, and is to be found in Tacitus: e.g. Hist. IV. 2 nondum ad curas intentus, sed . . filium principem agebat.
kata\ qe/an h(=ken—as in v. 7, 3; cf. Isocr. 7, 32 e)kpe/mpein kat' e)mpori/an.
dia/noian—‘enterprisc’; cf. c. 21, 1.

paraskeuh\ ga\r au(/th ktl—‘this was the first expedition that sailed out from a single city with a Greek force that eclipsed all that had ever been sent out in costlmess and magnificence.’ For polutelesta/th dh\ . . tw=n e)s e)kei=non to\n xro/non cf. c. 13, 1. See on this passage Intr. p. XXXII.

h( e)s *)epi/dauron—this expedition was sent out in 430 B.C., and Epidaurus was the most important place the Athenians attacked. It lay on the route to Argos, which was then neutral. The attack failed. The fleet was then sent on to Potidaea, where the Athenians wished to concentrate a force large enough to carry the place by assault. But Hagnon was compelled to return because the plague broke out among the crews.

au)tw=n *)aqhnai/wn—comparing the numbers of the two forces, we get—(1) 430 B C, 4000 Athenian hoplites and 100 triremes, with large forees from the allies in addition; (2) 415 B.C., 51,000 hoplites inclusive of all contributions from allies, and 134 triremes, also inclusive. Hence the numbers of the earlier expedition must have been the greater.
fau/lh|—‘ordinary,’ as in c. 21, 1.
ou(=tos de/—sc. w(rmh/qh. Then to\ me\n nautiko/n and to\ de\ pezo/n are in apposition to sto/los

kat' a)mfo/tera—explained by kai\ nausi\ kai\ pezw=|. The phrase means, not ‘on both elements,’ but ‘in both ways,’ ‘in both respects,’ as in kata\ pollou\s tro/pous, kata\ pa/nta, kata\ polla/. Cf. Aristoph. Birds 451 dolero\n kata\ pa/nta dh\ tro/pon. Dinarchus 1, 50 kata\ du/o tro/pous poiei=sqai ta\s a)pofa/seis.

ou(= a)\n de/h|—Poppo takes this with e)cartuqei/s = ‘equipped with whatever was necessary’; but ou(= is better explained as local, ‘wherever they might be needed.’ The point is that the army and the fleet could operate separately, though in experience Nieias found that the absence of cavalry prevented his employing the army away from the fleet. The Athenians had not in previous expeditions contemplated the independent action of army and fleet.

mega/lais dapa/nais—Gardner and Jevons, p. 659. The trierarchs were selected by the Strategi. The expense to the trierarch came in the extras—the ornamentation of the ship and the comforts and extra pay of the crew.
draxmh/n—this is double the ordinary wage, and is the same as that paid at the siege of Potidaea.
u(phresi/ais—see Gardner and Jevons on the trireme, p. 650.
qrani/tais—(1) they rowed with the longest oars; (2) they were exposed to greater danger than the other sailors.

shmei/ois—‘he either means standards strictly, as in the case of armies, or, as some say, the figures outside the vessels’ (Schol.). There were also the shmei=a, figures of Athena as guardian of the ship, that stood at the stern. Such figures are often referred to; and cf Ovid, Met. XV. 697 Deus eminet alte, | Impositaque premens puppim cervice recurvam | Caeiuleas despectat aquas. See Conington on Vergil, Aen. X. 166. (Cf. Aristoph. Frogs 933.) The outside figures, properly para/shma, were at the prow. Surely all of these shmei=a are meant, the ornamentations being unusually elaborate. (Bloomfield misunderstands the Schol.) In the first explanation the Schol. probably alludes to flags, though the exaet meaning of the
shmei=a placed on the general's tent and on certain public buildings is, I believe, unknown.
kataskeuai=s—‘fittings.’
e)s ta\ makro/tata = e)pi\ to\ plei=ston (Schol.).
au)tw=| tini go together and = ‘each for himself.’

katalo/gois xrhstoi=s—see on c. 26, 2. The Strategi were careful to select the most efficient men from the names on the sth=lai. The lit, rendering is ‘by honest enrolments,’ for kata/logos = both ‘list’ and ‘levy.’ xrhstoi=s = a)lhqe/si (Schol.). The lists were not always drawn up xrhstw=s: Aristoph. Eq. 1369 o(pli/ths e)nteqei\s e)n katalo/gw| | ou)dei\s kata\ spouda\s (through influence) meteggrafh/setai (get his name placed lower on the list, with the hope of eseaping service), a)ll) w(/sper h)=n to\ prw=ton e)ggrafh/setai (see Kock's note). Cf. Pax 1179 tou\s me\n e)ggra/fontes h(mw=n, tou\s d' a)/nw te kai\ ka/tw | e)calei/fontes di\s h)\ tri/s, of the taxiarehs, who acted for the Strategi. Aelian 13, 12 has a story that Meton, the astronomer, was on the kata/logos for Sieily, and tried to get off by feigning madness. (On kata/logos H. Schwartz, ad Athen. rem militarem c. 1.) e)kkriqe/n—dokimasqe(n kai\ prokriqe/n (Schol.).
skeuw=n—‘clothing,’ or ‘uniform,’ skeuh/ being used for an official dress, as of soldiers or priests.
a(millhqe/n—the verb occurs only here in Thuc.: ‘vying with one another.’ The aor. is more commonly middle in form.
w)=| tis e(/. proseta/xqh—‘in their several stations.’ See next note

e)s tou\s a)/llous *(/e—Jowett renders: ‘While at home the Athenians were thus competing with one another in the performance of their several duties, to the rest of Hellas the expedition seemed to be a grand display of their power and greatness’; and the note says: ‘Thuc. presents the expedition under two aspects, of which the connection is not obvious.’ This is all wrong. With both gene/sqai and ei)kasqh=nai we must supply toi=s *)aqhnai/ois, and the sense is toi=s *)aqhnai/ois pro/s te sfa=s au)tou\s e)/ris e)ge/neto a(/ma kai\ e)s tou\s a)/llous *(/ellhnas e)pi/deicis h)|ka/sqh: ‘The result was that among themselves they fell to quarrelling over the expedition at their posts (as to who was best equipped), while to the Greeks at large (through the splendour of the equipment) a display was portrayed of their (internal) power and (external) influence, rather than a force equipped against an enemy.’ The edd. are mistaken in supplying a subject tou=to or to\n sto/lon to ei)kasqh=nai. See Intr. p. xxxiii.
ei) ga/r tis—the reason of the statement (toi=s *)aqhnai)ois) e)pi/deicis h)|ka/sqh ktl. is now given. The explanation of the previous clause—e)/ris e)ge/neto—had been already given in what preeeded.
proetetele/kei—i.e. in the preparations, before the expedition was ready.
kai\ trih/rarxos—sc. tis, ‘and, if a trierarch.’
xwri\s d)—‘and besides’; cf. II. 97 xwri\s de\ o(/sa u(fanta/ te kai\ lei=a. a)/neu, ‘apart from,’ ‘beside,’ opposite of cu/n, which = ‘including.’
e)fo/dion—viaticum. metabolh=|—w)nh/sews dh/ (Schol.), ‘for barter’: ‘not a few looked to profit in the distant land by trade as well as by warfare’ (Freeman). Nicias refers to this fact in VII. 13.
ta\ pa/nta—more commonly ta\ cu/mpanta in this sense.
kai/—‘in fact,’ giving the general result.

ou)x h(=sson to/lmhs te qa/mbei—‘no less through astonishment at its boldness, and through the splendour of its appearance, than the superiority of the foree in eomparison with those against whom they went.’ Cf. II. 65 of this expedition ou) tosou=ton gnw/mhs a(ma/rthma h(=n pro\s ou(\s e)ph=san. The to/lma is the courage shown in undertaking a new war before the Peloponnesian war was done with, as Thuc. explains in VII. 28 that the A. para/logon poih=sai toi=s *ellhsi th=s duna/mews kai\ to/lmhs.
kai\ o(/ti—see on c. 1, 1.

me/gistos dia/plous—‘this is said because, though Egypt (against which they had formerly gone [460 B.C.] was farther in direct distance, yet the circuitous navigation to Sieily made a greater distance’ (Bloomfield).

e)pi\ megi/sth| e). pro/s—‘with the greatest hopes in comparison with their present position.’ The note in Jowett misses the point, which is that they looked forward to an enormous extension of empire: ‘Had Athens succeeded . . she would soon have added to her dominions part of Italy, and perhaps Carthage—the whole of Greece, and perhaps Maeedonia and Thrace’ (Bloomfield). See c. 90, 2.
ta\s nomizome/nas pro\ th=s a)nagwgh=s—‘that were customary before the start.’ What is unusual is that the prayers were offered in common, and not by each ship independently.
u(po\ kh/rukos—‘praecone verba praeeunte.’

par' a(/pan—Diodorus says o( ku/klos a(/pas e)/geme qumiathri/wn
kai\ krath/rwn. On ordinary occasions it seems that the Strategus alone poured libations before the start of a fleet. Here ‘cups were first filled and drunk round, and then the officers and seamen made the libation’ (Bloomfield).

cunephu/xonto . . sfi/si—the sfi/si ought to refer to the subject of cunephu/xonto, but it goes back to the subject which is throughout the prominent one—i.e. those taking part in the expedition. It is best therefore to regard the sentenee as parenthetical.
e)pi\ ke/rws—‘in single file,’ opposite of metwphdo/n or e)pi\ metw/pon. Cf. kata\ mi/an and e)pi\ mi/an, ‘one behind another.’ When outside the harbour, they began raeing.

toioi/de—it is plain, as Stahl says, that the views expressed by Hermoerates differed from those generally put forward. But ‘speeches like this’ (of Hermoerates) need not mean more than speeches that expressed views on the situation and offered adviee.

*(ermokra/ths—leader of the aristocratie party, and ranked by later writers with Timoleon. His chief doctrine, compared by Freeman to the Monroe doctrine, was Sicily for the Siceliots. He had persuaded the Greek cities of Sieily to make peacc in 424, and thus had already dealt a heavy blow to Athenian designs in the island. Dionysius I. married his daughter.
w(/sper kai\ a)/lloi tines—referring to others who had spoken before him.

tou= e)pi/plou th=s a)—Thuc. often places the objective gen. first when it is specially emphatic. In other authors, except Herod, and Hippocrates, it is rarely found. Andoc. 1, 15 peri\ tw=n *(ermw=n th=s perikoph=s.

le/gontes—i.e. what they judge to be the case, as distinct from the information they have received. katafobhqei\s e)pisxh/sw—e)pe/xw is often used absolutely. In VII. 33 e)pe/sxon to\ e)pixeirei=n = ‘refrained from attacking.’ pei/qwn ge—ge gives a causal sense to a partic. Cf. Andoc. 1, 70 w(/s g' e)mauto\n pei/qw. The phrase occurs several times in Plato and the orators.
e(te/rou—often used with a compar. of an exceptional case. Cf. the common phrase ma=llon e(te/rwn. Here e(te/rwn would have applied rather to those who had already spoken.
pa/nu—gives a superlative force to qauma/zete = d qau=ma me/giston e)mpoiei=.

pro/fasin—the accus. also in III. 111. The dat. is also used.
cummaxi/a| . . katoiki/sei—c. is dat. of cause, k. of purpose.

ei) sxoi=en . . e(/cein—as this follows a principal tense, it must represent ei) sxoi=men . . e(/comen of the O.R., as e.g. in Antiphon *ga 4 ei) tou\s a)naiti/ous diw/koimen, deinou\s a)lithri/ous e(/comen. (This passage is wrongly explained by F. Roth, Oratio Obliqua bei Thuk. p. 16.) Cf. M.T. § 499.
a)po\ tw=n u(parxo/ntwn—with a/munei=sqe, ‘with the means at hand.’
a)/farktoi—not a)/oploi (Schol.), but ‘insufficiently protected.’
lhfqh/sesqe = ‘be caught.’
pista/—refers to a)pisth/santes: ‘monet ne ex summa incuria in extremum terrorem irruant’ (Oehler, In Herm. Orationem). Sc. au)ta/ e)sti.
h)\ pa/sxein—‘they will not be in a position to inflict more on us than they suffer.’
a)nwfele/s—‘is it disadvantageous.’ See crit. note.
h)\n a)/ra—‘if in the issue’ (Wilkins).
dh\ . . ge—these particles, as Herbst shows, are added to ou) ga/r or mh\ ga/r to increase their force.
ka/lliston e)/rgon—II. 42 kindu/nwn ka/llistos, VII. 68 kinspaniw)tatoi.
ka/lliston dh\ e)/rgon h(mi=n—the same number of syllables follows cumbh/setai kai/: this is called pari/swsis.
o)li/goi ga\r dh/—e.g. the expedition of Cimon to the Thracian coast in 469, and to Egypt in 460.

pa/nta ga/r—i.e. not only e)noikou=ntes but a)stugei/tones as well. The whole of this passage is general down to katalei/pousin. Hence it is wrong to explain e)pibouleuqei=sin = h(mi=n, as Classen does.

ka)
 peri\ sfi/sin au)toi=s—I. 69 to
 ba/rbaron au)to
 peri\ au)tw=| ta\ plei/w sfale/nta. Soph. Ajax 828 peptw=ta tw=|de peri\ neorra/ntw| ci/fei. Herod. 9, 101 mh\ peri\ *mardoni/w|. Aristoph. Pax 905 peri\ tai=si kampai=s . . peptwko/tes. The other ordinary prose use of peri/ with dat. is after verbs of fearing, as usually in Thuc. (cf. Aristoph. Eq. 27 peri\ tw=| de/rmati de/doika). ‘As examples of a striking deviation from his usual construction may be mentioned III. 102 dei/sas peri) au)th=s . . VIII. 93 e)fobei=to peri\ tou= politikou=, for elsewhere Thuc. has peri/ with dat, after verbs of fearing, according to the usual Attic construction (cf. Phrynichus in B.A.G. p. 37 de/doika peri\ tw=|de, kata\ dotikh
 w)s e)pi\ to\ polu\ oi( *)attikoi/)’ (Prof. C. F Smith). But Phrynichus speaks too strongly: the construction occurs but once in
Aristoph., never in the orators, unless in Antiphon, Fr. 77 we should alter dei=sqai peri\ tou=. But it is wrong to pronounce peri/ with dat. ‘poetical and Ionic’ with Du Mesml. (There is great variety in the use of prepositions in Attic, and in the dictum of the Alexandrine grammarians there is some truth: para\ *qoukudi/dh| e)nhllagme/nws pa/sas eu(rh/seis ta\s proqe/seis keime/nas.)
o(/per . . hu)ch/qhsan = h(/nper au)/chsin hu)ch/qhsan (Poppo).

e)pi\ tw=| o)—VII. 64 to\ me/ga o)/noma tw=n *)aqhnw=n: ‘owing to their reputation as the city that he had attacked.’ That o)/noma does not mean ‘fiction’ or ‘mere statement’ here is shown by kai\ h(mi=n to\ toiou=to: it has the same sense as o)/noma above. To have been the object of the Persian attack constituted that glory of Athens that led to her rise. h)/|ei, which is in O.O., represents h)/|ei of O.R.: men said, after the war, “e)p' *)aqh/nas h)/|ei o( *mh=dos.” Syraeuse too will grow great e/pi\ tw=| o)no/mati w(s e)f) h(ma=s h(/|ei o( *)aqhnai=os. See Index s.v. e)pi/.
tou\s me/n—i.e. tou\s u(phko/ous:

toi=s de/—i.e. toi=s au)tono/mois ‘The difference is clearly marked between the Sikels of the east coast, familiar to Syr. as subjects, neighbours, or enemies, and the Sikel towns of the interior, now fast beginning to advance in power and in Hellenic culture’ (Freeman).
th\n a)/llhn *s—i.e. the Siceliots.

h)\cummaxi/an poiw/meqa h(mi=n—Stephanus reads poiw=ntai and Classen revives the reading. If we keep the MSS. reading we must make h(mi=n = h(mi=n au)toi=s ‘for ourselves,’ as Thuc. sometimes uses sfi/sin for sfi/sin au)toi=s: cf. II. 71 ou) di/kaia poiei=te ou)/te u(mw=n ou)/te pate/rwn. The phrase is, however, very unusnal.
a)/meinon—e. 19, 1.

a)ne/lpiston—taken in two ways: (1) a)/fobon (Schol., Kruger), se. mh/ pote . . e)/lqwsin, i.e. they are expeeting an attack on Carthage; (2) ‘the invasion of Sicily will not surprise them’ (Poppo, etc.). But (3) surely the key to the passage is in a)/meinon ei)=nai pe/myai? To a)ne/lpiston supply to\ pe/myai h(ma=s. ‘Our mission will not surprise them.’
dia\ fo/bou ei)si/—c. 59, 2. The construction is frequent with exein, gi/gnesqai, i)e/nai, ei)=nai.
ta/de—‘our cause.’ proh/sontai, ka)\n . . ei=nai: O.R. prohso/meqa, ka)\n . . ei)=men. M.T. § 505.
h)/toi . . ge . . h)/—in Thuc. the more certain but less important alternative is put first when these particles are used. But this does not seem to be the case in other authors.

h)\ e)c e(no/s ge/ tou t—‘or by some means or other’; the Schol. remarks that h)/ is superfluous, there being no other way except
either kru/fa or fanerw=s. But the addition is not an unnatural inaccuracy, and the removal of h)/ by no means improves the sense. Aesch. Septem 202 h)/kousas h)\ ou)k h)/kousas h)\ kwfh=| le/gw: Plat. Laches 199 B ou) ga\r mello/ntwn mo/non pe/ri e)pai/ei, a)lla\ kai\ gignome/nwn kai\ gegono/twn kai\ pa/ntws e)xo/ntwn, where kai\ pa/ntws e)xo/ntwn is equally superfluous.
eu)porei=—‘by which war . . prospers’; cf. I. 83 dapa/nhs, di' h(\n ta\ o(/pla w)felei=. Nothing further is heard of this proposal of H. to send to Carthage. (Freeman, Sicily III. Append. vii.)
e)s th\n *l. kai\ e)s *k—Thuc. repeats the preposition where different things are elearly opposed to one another, omits it when they are thought of together. Contrast § 4.
to\n e)kei= po/lemon—cf. c. 36, 4. Freeman remarks that we should have looked for some more marked reference to Corinth, as metropolis of Syr.

dia\ to\ cu/nhqes h(/suxon—v. 68 to\ a)nqrw/peion kompw=des: and c. 55, 3 to\ pro/teron cu/nhqes fobero/n. ‘I will now tell you what I think would be most advantageous, though you with your habitual lack of cnterprise would by no means readily aceede to it.’ Cf. Plat. Laws p. 918 D geloi=on me\n ei)pei=n o(/mws d' ei)rh/setai: Demosth. 14, 24 para/docon me\n oi)=da le/gwn, o(/mws d' ei)rh/setai.

peri\ th=s *sikeli/as—it appears necessary to read the gen. here, because o( a)gw/n, a)gwni/zesqai, ma/xesqai, polemei=n in Thuc. always take peri/ tinos not peri/ tini elsewhere; and it certainly does appear that tou= peraiwqh=nai is also governed by peri/ here Thomas Magister connects o( a/gw/n direetly with tou= peraiwqh=nai, for which ef. Eur Sup. 665 nekrou\s o)/pisqen qe/menoi, w(=n e)/keit' a)gw/n. (The MSS. reading is defended by Herbst, and by C. F. Smith in A.J.P. 25 p. 67.)
e)s logismo\n katasth/saimen—cf. Isocr. 15. 169 ei)se/peson ei)s to\ logi/zesqai. The substance of the refleetions is given in all that follows down to the end of § 5.
e)k fili/as xw/ras—viz. Tarentum, as explained by the parenthesis—i.e. ‘we have the friendly haven of Taras as a base of operations and a place of shelter in case of need’ (Freeman).
fu/lakes—of Sicily. Notice
au)toi=s and

to\ de\ pe/lagos ktl—‘whereas they have before them a passage which is long for the whole of their armament, and it would be difficult owing to the length of the voyage to keep in line, and consequently their forees would be exposed to our attack, as they would come up with us slowly and in divisions.’ polu/ (e)sti) peraiou=sqai, as c. 42 r(a/|ous a)/rxein. Most edd. regard
xalepo
 de\ . . mei=nai as a parenthesis; but the clause leads up to kai\ h(mi=n . . ei)/h, and the whole = xalepo
 (a)
 ei)/h th= paraskeuh=|) e)n ta/cei mei=nai, kai\ eu)epi)qetos a)
 ei)/h h( paraskeuh/.

ei) d' au)=—‘on the other hand, if they transfer their baggage (to the transports), and attack us with their fast ships in a body’—i.e. if they leave behind the transports and do not attempt to cross from Corcyra meta\ pa/shs th=s paraskeuh=s.
ei) de\ mh\ dokoi/h—se. h\mi=n e)piqe/sqai, if we found that they had not been rowing hard, and so decided not to attack them.
e)/sti—so the Athenians would reflect when the Syr. were off Tarentum. e)/sti u(poxwrh=sai is equivalent to u(poxwroi=men a)\n ei) bouloi/meqa.
met' o). e)fodi/wn—the result of koufi/santes w(s e)pi\ naumaxi/a|.

kata\ xwri/a e)rh=ma—‘the enemy,’ says Freeman, ‘will have to shift for himself how he can along desert or unfriendly coasts, where the Sikeliots will be able to attack, or harass, or bloekade him at pleasure.’ By xwri/a e)rh=ma Bloomfield rightly says that the eoast from Tarentum to Rhegium is meant: ‘the country itself was doubtless then, what it is now described as being, alike uncultivated and savage.’ Finding themselves e)n a)pori/a| kata\ xwri/a e)rh=ma, they will have to choose between two eourses: (1) waiting for their transports, (2) trying to gain admission to eities—Thurii, Croton, Locri, Rhegium.

poliorkoi=nto a)/n—se. u(f) h(mw=n. The Syr. would of course not remain inaetive in the harbour of Tarentum if the Athenians lay off the coast awaiting the arrival of their transports. ‘The sanguine orator does not stop to discuss how or where the Athenian fleet is to be blockaded by any force which the Sieiliaus could bring against it’ (note in Jowett).

peirw/menoi paraplei=n—if, instead of waiting for the rest of the fleet, they try to continue their voyage along the coast (of the Gulf of Tarentum, it being necessary for them to get supplies, if not by waiting, then by sailing along the coast and seeking them), they would be disheartened by the uncertainty whether the cities along the coast would receive them.
ou)k a)\n ktl = ou)k a(\n be/baia e)/xoien kai\ a)qumoi=en (a)/n). “ou)k ei)do/tes bebai/ws ei) ai( po/leis u(pode)contai” (Schol.).
tou/tw| tw=| l—with a)poklh|ome/nous: ‘hampered by these eonsiderations.’ Cf. Plat. Rep. p. 487 B in the sense ‘to receive a cheek’ in playing.

e)cwsqh=nai a)/n—Arnold compares Herod. I. 31 e)kklhio/menoi th=| w)/rh|: cf. e)cana/gkesqai, e)cei/rgesqai. Caes. B.G. v. 24 anni tempore excludi; cf. in annum excedere. ‘Through spending time in prolonged indecision and in sending scouts to recon
noitre our numbers and our position, they would be overtaken by winter.’ The aorist partic, does not express time past, relative to xrw/menoi, but is timeless. There is no reason why xrw/menoi should not have been xrhsa/menoi, other than that with verbs like pe/mpw the pres. partic. is much affected.
pro/fasin—sc. tou_ karalu_sai to\n p.
a)cio/xrewn—‘some considerable action on our part.’
a)ggelloi/meqa—personal,=a)ggelloi/meqa plei/ous ei)=nai, ‘our numbers would be exaggerated by report’; cf. I. 10 e)pi\ to\ mei=zon kos mh=sai.
pro\s ta\ lego/mena . . i(/stantai—metaphor from sails set in any direetion. ‘Men's minds veer in the direction of what they hear.’
h)\ . . ge—‘or at least.’

i)sokindu/nous—discrimini pares, Haase; and so recent edd. The Schol. says ‘either e)n o(moi/w| kindu/nw| katasth/sontas au)tou/s, or i)sopalei=s’: in II. 39 we have h(mei=s a)neime/nws diaitw/menoi ou)de\n h(=sson e)pi\ tou\s i)sopalei=s kindu/nous xwrou=men, where some edd. explain ‘dangers as great as they face,’ others ‘struggles in which equal but not superior forces oppose us’; probably the first is right and here the sense is ‘equally ready to face danger.’ If so, ef. i)sotelh/s, contrast i)sa/rguros.

kategnwko/tes—‘looking down upon us because we did not support the attempt of the L.’ In 431 Sparta had appealed to Italy and Sicily for ships, but none had been sent, II. 7. Stein thinks the obj. to kat. is lost. para\ gnw/mhn—para\ th\n do/can au)tw=n (Schol.).

a)po\ tou= a)=a)lhqei=. Such phrases are used as adjectives with nouns, or as adverbs with verbs. Cf. a)po\ tou= i)/sou, tou= profanou=s, tou= a)dokh/tou. III. 43 ta)gaqa\ a)po\ tou= eu)qe/os lego/mena, ‘the best advice when offered in plain terms.’
pei/qesqe . . tolmh/santes—‘follow my advice, if possible, by taking this bold step.’ The aor. is ingressive; by entering upon this to/lma. Again the time of the partic. is independent of the verb.
tau=ta which some edd. construe as object of pei/qesqe, goes with the partic., because of the order.
ta)=lla . . e(toima/zein—sc. pei/qesqe: it is not unusual to find two constructions after a verb in this way. Cf. note on c. 1, 1.

parasth=nai panti/—this infin. is by some explained as= an imperative, but it is more natural to supply pei/qesqe, which in passing through e(toima/zein has assumed a somewhat different meaning. (parasth=nai often has this sense: c. 68, 3; 95, 2.
Andoc. I. 54 ei)/ tw| pare/sthke gnw/mh toiau/th) Cf. II. 39 perigi/gnetai h(mi=n . . mh\ proka/mnein, kai\ .mh\ a)tolmote/rous . . fai/nesqai, kai\ e)/n te tou/tois th\n po/lin a)ci/an ei)=nai qauma/zesqai kai\ e)/ti e)n a)/llois, where also, when ei)=nai is reached, the meaning of perigi/gnetai is lost. This is a good example of thuc.'s polu/nous braxulogi/a.

katafronei=n tou\s e)pio/ntas—Thomas Magister quotes this passage for katafronei=n with accus. In only one place has Thuc. the gen. of direct objeet with katafr.—viz. VII. 63 katafronh)santes *korinqi/wn.

e)n tw=n e)/rgwn th=| a)lkh=|—ef. Herod. VII. 49 a)nh\r ou(/tw a)\n ei)/h a)/ristos ei) bouleuo/menos me\n a)rrwde/oi e)n de\ tw=| e)/rgw| qrasu\s ei)/h: ‘resistance in action’; a)lkh/, robur, is found in Herod. and Xen., but not elsewhere in prose.
to\ d' h)/dh—take to\ d' h)/dh w(s e)pi\ kindu/nou pra/ssein together, ‘to act at present as in time of danger.’
e)n plw=| . . ei)si/—cf. e)n o(dw=| ei)=nai, e)n teixismw=|, e)n paraskeuh=|, e)n kinh/sei, e)n sta/sei, etc.
e)n pollh=| e)/ridi h)=san, w(s—cf. II. 54 e)ge/neto e)/ris toi=s a)nqrw/pois mh\ loimo\n w)noma/sqai.
ou)d' a)lhqh= e)stin a(\ le/goito—for the dependent verb in opt. in O.O. when the leading verb retains the indic., M T. § 690. See crit. note, and Intr. p. xxiii.

oi( de/—the sentenee proceeds as if e)/legon in place of e/n e(/ridi h)=san were the verb. On the MSS. reading toi=s de/ Stahl notes that whereas there are examples of a passing from an oblique case into the nom. (e.g. c 24, 3 n.; and not unfrequent in tragedy), there are no other examples of a passing from the nom. into an oblique ease. The difference ean be appreciated by comparing Eur. Phoen. 1474 (Poppo) h)=n d' e)/ris strathla/tais, | oi( me\n pata/cai pro/sqe *polunei/khn dori/, | oi( d' w(s qano/ntwn ou)damou= ni/kh pe/loi.
ei) kai\ e(/lqoien—the brevity of the form finely expresses the keenness of the e)/ris.
au)tou/s—more regularly sfa=s.
e)s ge/lwta e)/trepon—Aristoph. Wasps 1253 ei)s ge/lwn to\ pra=gm) e)/treyas.

to\ pisteu=on—the neut. is often so used by Thuc colleetively for the masc. plur.; cf. c. 69, 3 to\ u(phkoon tw=n cumma/xwn, and with adverb without partic. to\ mh\ e)kpodw\n teti/mhtai II. 45; pa=n to\ e)c e)nanti/as, kai\ ei) fi/lion ei)/h tw=n feugo/ntwn VII. 44.

*)aqhnago/ras—nothing more is heard of him, but, from the mention of his name and the description given of him, he must
have been famous. He would, however, as leader of the popular party and opposed to Hermocrates, be promment only in time of peace.

dh/mou prosta/ths—cf. c. 28, 2 dh/mou proesta/nai. The phrase is often applied to unofficial leaders of a popular party, and in Ath. Pol. is interchanged with dhmagwgo/s, and is contrasted with tw=n gnwri/mwn, eu)po/rwn, e)pifanw=n, prosta/ths. He was ‘the man whom the multitude expected to come forward as their champion—e)n tw=| paro/nti, as long as they eontinued to trust him’ (Freeman). Of course he might be a strathgo/s, as Pericles, but was not necessarily in any official position. The speech that follows is very remarkable; like the Funeral Oration (II. 35), it does not apply only to the matter immediately under consideration, but has a wider range as illustrating the politics of Syracuse, and indeed of all democracies. It shows how ‘it is much easier to draw up a democratic constitution than to work it, when drawn up, in a democratic spirit’ (Freeman).
tou\s me\n ktl—a chance hexameter.
ou(/tw—as my opponents describe.
to/lmhs—i e. their boldness in trying to raise such scares, oi(/per a)ei\ ta/de kinou=si. (The word is not sarcastic here, as some edd. think.)

dedio/tes i)di/a| ti—‘those who have some private anxiety of their own’—i.e. as explained in c. 38, 2 boulo/menoi kataplh/cantes to\ u(me/teron plh=qos au(toi\ th=s po/lews a)/rxein: they are afraid that unless they raise a scare they cannot conceal their designs.
to\ sfe/teron—not ‘their fear,’ but ‘their design to get the control of things,’ ‘their secret.’ See crit. note. e)phluga/zomai—h)lu/gh=sko/tos: and see L. & S. under lu/gh.

tou=to du/nantai—Classen makes this apply to what precedes, and is therefore obliged to insert ai(/ after du/nantai. But all that preceded was a general statement: at kai\ nu=n begins the application to the particular case. ‘So (kai/) now these reports mean this: they are . . the work of men who are always trying to disturb us’ (with ulterior motives). For
ta/de cf. c. 34, 3.
e)k before a)ndrw=n is for u(po/, an Ionic and poetical use.
e)c w(=n=e)k tou/twn a(\ . .
w(/sper . . a)ciw=—sc. dra=sai a)/n, and a/ciw==nomi/zw.
a)gapa=n . . o(/ti—so with ei), e)a)n.

au)tou\s . . e)kei/nous—apply to the same persons, as often; cf. c. 61 kate/gnwsan au)tou= kai\ tw=n met' e)kei/nou. Sometimes e)kei=nos
is first, as Plat. Resp. p. 343 C eu)dai/mona e)kei=non poiou=sin u(phretou=ntes au)tw=|.
th=s . . e)piou/shs=th=s nu=n e)piou/shs s. Thuc. often places an attributive partic. after a noun when there are other modifications.
oi(=s ge—antecedent stratia=s.
ou)/q) . . ou)d' . . ou)/q) o(pli/tas . . th/n te a)/llhn—this series really consists of ou)/te . . ou)/te . . te, with an ou)de/ clause inserted as a climax to the first.
