o(pli/tas—sc. a/kolouqh/sontas. They will not have a large force of hoplites, as the hoplites will have come by sea.
au)tai=s—‘alone’;
kou/fais ‘without lading.’

para\ tosou=ton gignw/skw—the Schol. explains ‘So much do I differ from my opponents.’ But lit. ‘to such an extent I know,’ i.e. ‘so confident am I’ that they are inferior to us. Cf. § 1 i(kanwte/ran h(gou=mai *sikeli/an ktl., and below tosou/tw| th\n h(mete/ran paraskeuh\n krei/ssw nomi/zw.
mo/lis a)/n—with ou)k a)\n diafqarh=nai.

ei) po/lin . . e)/lqoien e)/xontes—‘if they brought with them a city great as Syracuse, and set it up upon our borders, and carried on the war from it, scarcely so could they escape utter ruin.’ By po/lis he means, of course, the men and the things necessary to make a permanent hostile settlement.

oi)ki/santes for oi)kh/santes is necessary, because the sense required is not ‘settle in’ a place already existing, hut ‘found’ a new settlement. With this change there is no need to bracket e)/lqoien or e)/. e)/xontes.
h)= pou/ ge dh\ ktl—(the ge only adds further emphasis to h)= pou dh/—‘of course, then’;) sc. mo/lis dokou=sin ou)k a)\n diafqarh=nai.
e)n pa/sh| polemi/a|—cf. c. 21, 2 e)s a/llotri/an pa=san.
custh/setai ga/r—‘for Sieily will unite’ against them.

stratope/dw| te—‘and in (sc. e)n from above) a camp which they form with what their ships bring.’ stratope/dw| is in contrast with po/lin above, i(druqe/nti with oi)ki/santes. Stahl gets into endless difficulties (1) by supplying ei) po/lemon poioi=nto to e)n pa/sh| p. *sikeli/a|, (2) by rendering te ‘both’ instead of ‘and,’ (3) by totally misunderstanding e)k new=n i(druqe/nti.
kai\ e)k skhnidi/wn ktl—‘and when they depend on mere tents and supplies of the barest, while our cavalry prevents them from moving for any distance.’
to/ te cu/mpan—sums up the whole argument.

krath=sai . . th=s gh=s—i.e. obtain possession of so much
land as is necessary for the strato/pedon. Cf. c. 23, 2 eu)qu\s kratei=n th=s gh=s.
a)/ndres—quidam, hinting, as that word sometimes does, at definite opponents.
kai\ de/doika me/ntoi—‘and I really fear lest their repeated efforts may at last be crowned with success’ (Wilkins). This is the affirmative me/ntoi, as in answers of assent.
h(mei=s de\ kakoi/—‘we show no spirit in taking precautions before we suffer, or in stopping such men when we detect them.’
ai)sqo/menoi is opposed to pri\n e)n tw=| paqei=n w)=men—for which see c. 10, 5.
di' au)ta/—going back to ta/de kinou=si e. 36, 2. ‘Hence it is that such sehemes allow our state but seldom to rest.’
turranni/das—such as Gelon and Hieron:
dunastei/as— such as the power of the aristocratic party of Hermocrates.
w(=n—with ti below.
periidei=n gene/sqai—the infin. after periora=n occurs only in Herod. and Thuc.; the verb then=e)a=n. M.T. § 903, 6.

u(ma=s me\n tou\s pollou/s—contrasted with tou\s d' au)= o)li/gous, who are also meant in tou\s . . . mhxanwme/nous. Weil's conjecture (see crit. note) is necessary because there is no distinction between the plotters and the oligarchs, and because only the people can be said kola/zein.
au)tofw/rous—correspouds to ai)sqo/menoi e)pezelqei=n above, and w(=n bou/lontai me\n ktl. to profula/zasqai.
w(=n bou/lontai—after kola/zein. Cf. II. 74, 3 th=s a)diki/as kola/zesqai. So
w(=n dra=| and
dianoi/as depend on proamu/nesqai.
ei)/per kai/—‘inasmuch as.’
ta\ me\n e)le/gxwn—‘now by convicting them (when they have formed a design), now by watching them (to keep them from forming one), now by counselling them (to change their methods).’
kai\ dh=ta—he proceeds to give an instance tou= dida/skein. The use of dh=ta is in emphatic statements, questions, and appeals.
new/teroi—the younger members of the oligarchic party.
po/teron—there follows an example of u(pofora/, altercatio, in which an orator puts words into an opponent's mouth and supplies the answer.
a)tima/zein—infin. of purpose, ‘to keep out of office.’
i)sonomei=sqai—liberty and equality, e)leuqeri/a and i)sonomi/a, were the cardinal principles of Greek democracy.
tou\s au)tou/s—members of the same state.

fh/sei tis ktl—‘I shall be told that democracy is neither a wise nor a fair principle, that the owners of property are at the same time the best qualified to govern well. But I answer first that a whole community is termed a people, whereas only a section bears the name oligarchy; further, that though the rich are the best guardians of property, the wise are the best counsellors, and the many after hearing arguments are the best judges, and that these (three) classes, whether they act in parts or as a whole, have under democracy an equal share.’
bouleu=sai d' a)\n ktl—cf. II. 40 h)/toi kri/nome/n ge h)\ e)nqumou/meqa o)rqw=s ta\ pra/gmata

kai\ kata\ me/rh kai\ zu/mpanta—‘these whether in seetions or together,’ i.e. as separate me/rh of the dh=mos and as together making it up. The words are introduced for the sake of the reference to zumpan and me/ros above—a point missed by edd.
tw=n d' w)feli/mwn—‘of the advantages it not merely claims an excessive share, but appropriates them all.’

a)felome/nh e)/xei—cf. I. 38 e(lo/ntes bi/a| e)/xousi, and c. 76, 2. ‘From this use of e)/xein it comes to be employed with the partic aor or perf. as a periphrasis for those tenses, but expressing strongly the maintenance of the result attained . . frequent in the tragic poets, particularly Soph.’ (Morris).
u(mw=n . . proqumou=ntai—with ‘partitive’ gen. 1st or 2nd pers., the verb is generally in the 3rd person.
oi(/ te duna/menoi=oi( o)ligarxikoi/ (Schol.).
a)du/nata—sc. o)/nta, ‘whereas it is impossible to attain such hopes.’
a)ll)—repeated below in a)ll) h)/toi, on account of the long parenthetie vocative w)= a/zunetw/tatoi . . h)\ a)dikw/tatoi.
to\ th=s po/lews zu/mpasi koino/n—‘the interests of the state that are shared by all’; still referring to his definition of democracy above.

tou=to me)n—i.e. to\ au)/zein to\ th=s po/lews koino/n, as Stahl; not to\ th=s po/lews koino/n merely, because ei) d' a)/lla boulh/sesqe clearly means h)\ to\ au)/zein to\ th=s p. k. ‘That this share which the good citizens among you will receive will be equal or even greater’ than that borne by others. tou=to is internal aceus. to meta-
sxei=n, as in ou)de\n tw=nde mete/xw II. 40, ou)k e)/lasson . . polu\ plei=on metei/xete VII. 63. [h)/per . . plh=qos]—see crit. note.
w(s pro\s ai)sqome/nous—‘assured that you are dealing with men who . .’
e)/rxontai—‘are on the way.’
au)ta)—‘the matter,’ i.e. the details of the defence.
kai/—‘and,’ not ‘even.’
au)tw=n=tw=n a/ggeliw=n. With
pro/s cf. II. 64, 6 pro\s ta\s zumfora\s lupou=ntai.
doulei/an—here the bondage incurred in democracy by giving power to a dangerous person. In c. 78 of political dependence of one state upon another.
au)th\ d' e)f) au(th=s—‘without reference to others,’
a)f) u(mw=n—‘words that come from you.’ The art. is not necessarily repeated with prepositional phrases after verbal nouns. Cf. on c. 6, 3.
a)kou/ein—sc. tou\s lo/gous a/f) u(mw=n.

e)k tou= e)/rgw| ktl—‘by taking precautions in action not to permit that,’ i.e. to\ a)faireqh=nai th\n e)leuqeri/an. Thus she will take notice of the words ‘as if they were deeds’; and the ‘deeds’ meant are of course efforts to obtain control of the government; c. 36, 2.
tw=n de\ strathgw=n—presumably that one of the (15) Syr. generals who was presiding over the assembly.
pro\s ta\ paro/nta—‘with reference to the situation’
tina/s—masc.

kosmhqh=nai . . a)ga/lletai—both metaphors from bright clothes. II. 42 ai\ tw=nde a)retai\ e)ko/smhsan (th\n po/lin): II. 44 ai(=s (eu)tuxi/ais) pote kai\ au)toi\ h)ga/llesqe. Much the same is lampru/nomai c. 12, 2. Cf. e)gkallw/pisma plou/tou II. 62. (Corstens de Translationibus p. 38.)
h(mei=s—sc. oi( strathgoi/.
diapompw=n—still depending on ou)demi/a bla/bh. The art. alludes to the recommendations of Hermocrates.

e)/s te kataskoph/n—‘to collect information’ as to the feeling and resources of the cities. (Valla wrongly understands it qui explorent hostium adventum et consilium. The information is such as may prove useful if the enemy are not coming, h)\n mhde\n deh/sh| sc. paraskeua/zesqai a)mu/nesqai.)
h)/n ti a)/llo=e)s a)/llo ti o(\ a)/n, such as the arrangement of alliances.
ta\ de\ kai\ e)pimemelh/meqa—‘some precautions of that nature we have already taken.’ ta\ de/ is internal accus.; cf. c. 40, 1.
e)s u(ma=s oi)/somen—a common meaning of fe/rwin tragedy, but rare in prose. Eur. Phoen. 1086 h)= pou cumfora\n h(/keis fe/rwn.
e)pece/tasin—‘a final muster’ of all the contingents.

o(rmiei=sqai/ te kai\ strat—See crit. note. The two tenses recur with me/llw in c. 99, 2 e)/mellon a)/cein kai\ . . gi/gnesqai: but there the infins. are separated, and gi/gnomai is in its nature inceptive, and can appropriately be combined with a fut. infin. In Demosth. 21, 55, quoted by Stahl, we have o(/ te me/llwn nika=n kai\ o( pa/ntwn u(/statos o(rmiei=sqai: but again the infins. are much more distinct than here. Hence, unless it be possible to draw a distinction between me/llw with pres. and fut., it is best to read stratopedeu/sesqai.
tri/a me/rh—internal accus., ‘into three parts.’
e)n tai=s katagwgai=s—‘whenever they landed.’
proapanta=n—before the main body put into any port.

*(rodi/oin—almost all MSS. give the -oin form for fem. here. Yet in c. 104, 1 all have the -ain form twice. The form du/o is joined with plural far more often than with dual in Thuc.; it is used several times as gen. or dat., always with plur. (Hasse, Dual in Thuc. and Xen. p. 17). Though du/o, duoi=n is generally added to a dual (see Rutherford, New Phryn. p. 290), it is omitted when a pair is referred to (Meisterhaus, p. 163).
penthkonto/roin—on these things see Gardner and Jevons, p. 652.
ai( me\n e(c—article with numerals designates them as parts of a total.
taxei=ai—see c. 31, 3.

*xi/wn—only Chios and Methymna among the cu/mmaxoi u(ph/kooi were au)to/nomoi and still furnished contingents to the fleet. Probably Corcyra also sent some ships. She was a/po\ cummaxi/as au)to/nomos.

o(pli/tais de\ ktl—the numbers are as follows: (1) Hoplites, 1500 Athenian, 500 Argives, 250 Mautinean and (other) mercenaries, 700 marines, and (therefore) 2150 subject allies, total 5100, (2) Archers, 480. (3) Slingers, 700. (4) Miscellaneo)us, 150.
e)k katalo/gou—see on c. 26, 2.
e(ptako/sioi—of these, 600 would be required for the 60 A. fast triremes. Hence, among the 24 triremes supplied by the allies, 10—requiring the remaining 100 marines—must have been fast.
qh=tes—their names never appeared in the kata/logos. The marines were usually qh=tes.
*)argei/wn—the alliance between Athens and Argos had been renewed in June 417. kai\ <a)/llwn> misqofo/roi Stein.
*mantine/wn—in VII. 57 Thuc. speaks of *mantinh=s kai\ a)/lloi *)arka/dwn misqofo/roi among the forces. The Arcadians are heard of as mercenaries in the Persian wars. Herod. VIII. 26.
*megareu=si—expelled in the party struggle of 424 B.C., when Brasidas saved Megara from falling into the hands of Athens.
i(ppe/as—they are not again heard of.
prw/th—for in 414 stratia\n a)/llhn e)yhfi/santo pe)mpein.
o(lka/des me\n . . ploi=a de\ e)c a)na/gkhs—transports and smaller vessels requisitioned from private owners. Cf. c. 22.
cundie/balle—see c. 30, 1 n.
hu)po/rhsan—sc. prosbalei=n.
a)gora=| ou)de\ a)/stei—‘not admitting them to a market, nor even into the citv, but only granting water and anchorage.’
*(rh/gion—Athens had made a treaty with R. in 433 B.C. On the meaning of ‘Italy’ see c. 2, 4n. The modern name, Reggio di Calabria, curiously illustrates *(rh/gion th=s *)it.
parei=xon—oi( *(rhgi=noi.
lo/gous e)poih/santo—‘made overtures to.’
*xalkideu=si—see c. 3, 3. The refusal of Rhegium was the greatest blow, as it had supported Athens before in Sicily.
pro\s ta/—with prosoi/sontai.
w(s e)pi\ tou/tois—cf. VII. 45 w(s e)pi\ tou/tois pareskeua/- zonto, ‘under these circumstances.’
e)/nqa me/n=pro\s tou\s u(phko/ous.
pro\s de\ tou/s=pro\s tou\s au(tono/mous. Cf. Isocr. 2, 18 i(/na ta\s me\n feu(gwsi, pro\s de\ ta\s proqumo/teron e)/xwsin. The de/ generally follows the preposition.
peripo/lia in Italy and Sicily=frou/ria in Attica.
e)n th=| xw/ra|—i.e. in the territory belonging to Syracuse
e)k th=s *)ege/sths—attraction of the preposition to the verb.
fai/netai—‘are forthcoming’)(a)fanh\s ei(=nai.
oi( *(r. ou)k e)qelh/santes—sc. a)ntekekrou/kesan. Cf. IV. 26 ai)/tion de\ h)=n oi( *lakedaimo/nioi proeipo/ntes e)sa/gein si=ton.
prw=ton h)/rcanto—often combined to emphasise the moment of beginning.
pei/qein—of attempt.
ei)ko\s h)=n—sc. custrateu/ein, as also with pei/qein.
prosdexome/nw| h)=n—this idiom is found also with gi/gnomai. The same in Lat. with volenti esse, and once with other words, viz. Tac. An. I. 59 ut quibusque bellum invitis aut cupientibus erat.

kai\ a)logw/tera—‘even more incomprehensible’ than it was unexpected. The antithesis clearly implies ou) prosdexome)nois h)=n. (These words are explained in various ways: (1) ‘even more incomprehensible than the defection of the Rhegians,’ Stahl, Jowett; (2) ‘even more unexpected than it was expected by Nicias,’ Fr. Muller, etc.; (3) ‘upset their calculations all the more because they had believed the reports of the envoys,’ Classen; (4) ‘somewhat disconcerting,’ Hertland, Journ. Philol. XXIV.) Stein reads a/porw/tera.
to/te o(/te—both this and to/te o(/tan are fairly frequent.
oi( prw=toi p—c. 6, 3; 8, 1.
e)/s te—answered by kai\ i)di/a|.
to\ e)n *)/eruki—founded, according to legend, by Aeneas. Aen. V. 759.

o)/nta a)rgura=—Grote and Freeman understand ‘silver-gilt,’ but this can hardly be right, unless e)pa/rgura ‘overlaid with silver,’ or u(pa/rgura ‘silver overlaid with gold,’ be read. With a/rgura= the sense must be that, being silver, the number was imposing, though the value was comparatively small.
ai)thsa/menoi—‘borrowing.’ Lys. 24 § 12 after a)llotri/ois i(/ppois xrh=sqai speaks of oi( h)|thme/noi i(/ppoi.

parei=xe—sc. au)ta/, the spectacle, the gen. abs. being used in conjunction with pa/ntwn . . xrwme/nwn, though strictly polla\ faino/mena is required. The substitution of the gen. abs. for a dat. is not very rare, but the substitution for a nom. is unusual; cf. VII. 48, 2 xrhma/twn a/pori/a| e)ktruxw/sein, a)/llws te kai\ . . qalassokratou/ntwn (for -es). Livy XXIII. 24 pontem fluminis petentes, obsesso ante ab hostibus ponte.
ai)ti/an ei)=xon u(po/—see c. 14, 1 n.
*niki/ou . gnw/mh—(1) to reconcile Selinus and Segesta, (2) then to sail round the coast—but to risk nothing.
e)f) o(/per—‘for which object.’ Thuc. often uses the neut. thus in a parenthesis.
ma/lista—the primary object, at least nominally. In VII. 11 Nicias says *surakosi/ons e)f) ou)\s e)pe/mfqhmen. h)th/santo—*)egestai=oi. See c. 8, 1.
di) o)li/gou—of time; c. 11, 4.
th=| po/lei—with kinduneu/ein, which depends on h)=n gnw/mh.

*)alkibia/dhs—(1) to form alliances with the Siceliots and Sieels, and encourage the subjects of Syracuse to revolt; (2) then attack Syracuse and Selmus, unless they complied with the demands made of them.
e)/xwsi—‘obtain’ from them. See crit. note. ?sxw=si.
*messhni/ous—c. 4, 6.
po/rw| ‘passage,’
prosbolh=| ‘approach.’
e)fo/rmhsin—a point from which to watch the enemy.
katoiki/zein—subject ‘the Athenians.’ Observe that the plan of Alcibiades would afford him great opportunities for the employment of diplomacy, in which he excelled.
*la/maxos—it is generally agreed that his advice ought to have been followed: (1) to attack Syracuse at once, (2) to make the site of Hyblaean Megara their head-quarters.
a)/ntikrus—with plei=n. 2
pro\s th=| po/lei—‘to fight the battle under the walls of the city.’
h)\n de\ xroni/sh|—‘if it delay before making itself seen, men gradually recover their spirit, and when they actually see it, are inclined to despise it.’
th=| o)/yei is dat. of circumstance.

sfei=s—that sfa=s (see crit. note) is equally correct is certain: when a plur. subj. of infin. includes the subj. of the main verb, whether in whole or part, it is put either in nom. or accus. at will. But plei=stoi below makes sfa=s mtolerable.

ei)ko\s de\ ei)=nai—‘Many, not fully believing that the Athenians were coming, would not yet have sought shelter in the city. They would be made prisoners in the open country, and their property would be useful’ (Freeman). Stahl makes e:skomizome/nwn au)tw=n apply to the Syr. in general, placing ei)ko\s . . h(/zein in parenthesis, but the difficulty is imaginary.

h)\n pro\s ktl—this is the plan for the army: they would win a victory under the walls, and then take up a strong position there. The superfluous men with the ships would seek the nearest convenient harbour, and Megara would be a better site than Alcibiades's Messene for this e)fo/rmhsis.
*me/gara—see c. 4, 2. On Lamachus see Intr. p. xiv.
diapleu/sas—from Rhegium.
a)\n ou)—unusual order.
pasw=n—the fleet had previously been in three divisions, c. 42, 1.
decame/nwn—thus they gained their first ally.
*thri/an—north of Leontini.
to\n me/gan lime/na—it contained docks, probably built by Gelon.

a)pie/nai—for the change from o(/ti to infin., where the infin. contains an exhortation, cf. Andoc. 1, 41 ei)pei=n h\ma=s o(/ti dedogme/non ei)/h . . e(/na au)to\n h(mw=n ei(=nai, ‘he was to be one of us.’ Thuc. IV. 50 pe/myai=mitterent. This use of the infin. is also common in O.R. in the terms of laws, prayers, and the like, the subject being accus.: this must be distinguished from the rare use of the infin. as imper. with nom. subject, as in v. 9 su\ . . e)pekqei=n. It must probably be admitted that this infin. with accus. depends in O.R. and O.O. alike on the general idea of an order, or agreement, or prayer, and is identical with the infin. after le/gw in the sense of ‘order’; cf. II. 2 a)nei=pen o) kh=ruc . . ti/qesqai. But with the nom the infin. is independent, as in our own use on notices. a/pie/nai here is clearly connected with khru=cai, as e)pei\ e)khru/xqh shows.
tou\s lime/nas—the Great, the Little, and Trogilus.
polemhte/a—the construction with the plur. verbal is ‘essentially Ionic and poetical’ (C. F. Smith). It occurs several times in Thuc., but seldom in other Attic prose.

pro\s th\n e). tetramme/nwn—‘had their attention oc cupied with’; tre/pesqai pro/s of persons is ‘to concentrate one's attention on,’ or ‘to appeal to the help of,’ ‘resort to.’ The aor. is e)trapo/mhn, e)treya/mhn being trans.

e)nw|kodomhme/nhn kakw=s—sc. tw=|tei/xei: ‘not built firmly into the wall.’ The meaning is explained by Eur. Phoen. 114 a)=ra pu/lai, klh/|qrois xalko/det' e)/mbola, laine/oisin *)amfi/onos o)rga/nois tei/xeos h(/rmostai;—i.e., according to Bernadakis, ‘are the gates, the brass-bound barriers (e)/mbola) in the gate-ways (klh/|qrois), fitted firm in the holes (o)rga/nois) in the stone of Amphion's wall?’ so that o)/rgana are the dowels into which the bar (mo/xlos) was fitted. Now in the present case the o)/rgana were so worn, or badly made, that though the bar was across the gate and was fastened, it could be removed without the key (balana/gra).

h)go/razon=e)n a/gora=| die/tribon (Schol.), ‘to learn what was going on’ (Arnold), just as at Athens it was customary to loiter there, especially before and after a meeting of the
Ecclesia. The people coming from the Ecclesia would find the army in the Agora.
ou) polloi/ tines—c. 1, 1 n.
kai\ o(/ti—instead of kai\ e)k *surakousw=n o()ti.
au)=qis—as before from Catana to Syr., so now from Syr. to Camarina.
sxo/ntes—Livy's tenere.
ai)gialo/s is Ionic.
ta\ o(/rkia—probably the reference is to the treaty of Gela arranged by Hermocrates in 424. Camarina became an ally of Syracuse.
mia=| nhi/—so that there could be no possibility of hostile action.
kata/ ti—some point in Syr. land.
i(ppe/wn—the difficulty that Nicias had expected.

th\n *salamini/an—one of the two state ships. Aristoph. Birds 147 refers to this mission: a)naku/yetai | klhth=|r' a)/gous' e(/wqen h( *salamini/a. A third state ship, the Delias, is mentioned in inscriptions.
keleu/sontas—i.e. tou\s e)n th=| nhi/.
met' au)tou(\—the order clearly implies that Alc. had not even now been accused of mutilating the Hermae.

zh/thsin—alluding to the zhthtai/: see c. 29. A metic named Teucrus had, after the departure of the armament, given information about both Mysteries and Hermae. He received the reward of 1000 drachmae. Plut. Alc. 20 quotes Phrynichus Com. (Hermes loq.) fula/comai: *teu/krw| ga\r ou)xi\ bou/lomai | mh/nutra dou=nai tw=| palamnai/w| ce/nw|. After his information the Commissioners judged that the crimes ‘were due to a large number, e)pi\ dh/mou katalu/sei, kai\ xrh=nai e)pizhtei=n kai\ mh\ pau/sasqai’ (Andoc. 1, 36).

ou) dokima/zontes tou\s m—the action of the Commissioners encouraged one Dioclides to give false information about the Hermae, saying that he saw a crowd of about 300 on the night, and he denonnced 42 persons, among whom were the orator Andocides and several of his relatives. Dioclides subsequently admitted that he had given false information, and was put to death. Plut. Alc. 20 quotes Phryn. Com. w)= fi/ltaq) *(ermh=, kai\ fula/ssou mh\ pesw
 | au(to
 parakrou/sh| kai\ para/sxh|s diabolh
 | e(te/rw| *dioklei/da| boulome/nw| kako/n ti dra=n. About the same time a woman named Agariste and Lydus gave information about the Mysteries, inculpating Alcibiades.
tina/—masc.
u(po\ *lakedaimoni/wn—in 510 B.C. under K. Cleomenes. Herod. vi. 123; Ath. Pol. c. 19.

to\ ga/r—the introduction of this episode causes great surprise to modern critics. There are discrepancies in the account of the affair as given here and in the Ath. Pol.: ‘we cannot tell which story is the truer, and the probabilities which may be alleged on either side are not decisive’ (Forbes, Thuc. i.). Thuc. makes reference to the story in I. 20. We must remember that the matter was of first-rate historical and political interest to the Athenians, and that Thuc. writes for students.

to/lmhma—the conspiracy was in 514, but H. and A. were popularly regarded as heroes who had actually destroyed the tyranny. The famous scholium of Callistratus quoted by Athenaeus (e)n mu/rtou kladi\ to\ ci/fos forh/sw ktl.) is earlier than Thuc.
cuntuxi/a=‘adventure.’
teleuth/santos—527 B C
oi( polloi/—as distinguished from students.
e)/sxe—‘received.’ Thuc. does not use
a)sto/s sing. 12
me/sos poli/ths—belonging to the middle class, like Solon.
*(ippa/rxou—the Ath. Pol. makes Thessalus, younger brother of Hipparchus, the cause of the dispute.
w(s a)po\ th=s u(. a)—‘as best he could with such influence as he had,’ me/sos w)/n.
pareskeua/zeto prophlakiw=n—the omission of w(s with paraskeua/zomai is very rare except in Thuc., who has it several times. Xen. Hel. IV. 1, 41 pareskeua/zeto poreuso/menos.
th\n a)/llhn a)rxh/n—‘his rule generally was mild’; he was not tyrant, but, as Ath. Pol. c. 18 says, both he and Hippias h)=san ku/rioi tw=n pragma/twn dia\ ta\ a/ciw/mata.
a)nepifqo/nws katesth/sato—sc. th\n a)rxh/n, ‘he maintained it without exciting ill-feeling.’
kai\ e)peth/deusan ktl—‘and as tyrants they for the longest time displayed virtnous principles and good sense,’ i.e. politikh\ a)reth/ such as Plato speaks of.

ei)kosth/n—Pisistratus had levied a tax of 10 per cent on produce: Ath. Pol. c. 15 sune/bainen au)tw=| kai\ ta\s proso/dous gi/gnesqai mei/zous e(rgazome/nhs th=s xw/ras: e)pra/tteto ga\r a)po\ tw=n gignome/nwn dekath/n. The tax was thus rednced by his sons.

kalw=s dieko/smhsan—e.g. they are said to have adorned with columns the spring Callirhoe, and to have set up Hermae. No doubt they continued the building of the Olympieium, begun
by Pisistratus; and they greatly added to the importance of the worship of Apollo, Athena, and Dionysus.

die/feron . . e)/quon—two of the most important duties of the sovereign: they carried through their wars and attended the temples to offer sacrifice. With the brachylogy e)s ta) i(era/ cf. II. 4 e)/klh|se sturaki/w| . . xrhsa/menos e)s to
 moxlo/n, and II. 49 e)/drasan e)s freata. Aristoph. Plut. 741 h)fa/nisen au(to
 ei)s to
 ne/wn.
au)th/—i.e. without interference from the tyrants.

toi=s pri\n keime/nois—the Solonian constitution. The phrase o( e)pi\ *kro/nou bi/os, Golden Age, was applied to the period both of Pisistratus and of Hippias. What Thuc. says of the sons the Ath. Pol. says of the father, and of the sons sune/bh diadecame/nwn tw=n ui(e/wn pollw=| gene/sqai traxute/ran th\n a/rxh/n.
a)rxai=s—especially the archons. Cf. Aristoph. Wasps 682 e)n a/rxai=s ei)=nai.
*)aqhnai/ois—the dat. is frequent, and does not imply inferiority like the gen. It is official.

tw=n dw/deka qew=n bwmo/n—this altar stood in the new Agora, as instituted by the Pisistratids, who made the Cerameicus the centre of Athens instead of Cydathenaeon (S. of the Acropolis). The altar marked the completion of their changes (Curtius, Stadtgeschichte von Athen, pp. 79 f.).

to\n e)n . . *puqi/ou—‘in the precinct of the Pythian Apollo,’ i.e. the Pythium (close to the Olympieium), which was the work of the Pisistratids. As archou, Pisistratus celebrated the Thargelia in honour of Apollo.
nu=n—the inscription was discovered in 1877 near Callirhoe (C.I.A. IV. 373).
a)mudroi=s—Classen remarks that the letters are mostly clear enough at the present day. But it is very likely that the inscription was restored later.

a)kribe/steron—that this alludes to some tradition in the family of Thuc. is clear, but it is not certain that he was related to the Pisistratids, as stated by Hermippus (3rd cent. B.C.) ap. Marcellin. 3

au)tw=| tou/tw|—the arguments are: (1) on a certain monument only Hippias's children are mentioned; (2) on the same the name of H. immediately follows that of the father; (3) it is unlikely that if Hipparchus had been tyrant Hippias could have secured the power on the day of the murder. The tyranny would have come to an end. (This evidence does
not amount to much, but it scarcely deserves the contempt Junghahn pours on it)

tw=n gnhsi/wn a)delfw=n—apparently Hippias, Hipparchus, and Thessalus, also named Hegesistratus (Ath. Pol. c. 17; cf. Herod. v. 94). Thessalus is called no/qos by Herod., because he was son of a ce/nh. The Ath. Pol. mentions a fourth son, Iophon (Plut. Cat. m. c. 24, and so the Schol. on Wasps l. 502), but nothing is known of him.
h( sth/lh—one of the pillars on which were inscribed the names of criminals condemned to death or banishment.
presbeu/ein—‘was the eldest next to him and became tyrant.’
au)to\s de\ . . kaqi/stato—‘and he had attempted to make himself ruler,’ sc. e)s th\n a)rxh/n.

to\ pro/teron cu/nhqes . . fobero/n—c. 34, 4: ‘but on the one hand (kai/), partly because the citizens had become accustomed beforehand to fear him, and partly becanse of the strict discipline he had enforced on his body-guard, he retained his power with abundant security, whereas on the other hand he was not at a loss, as he would have been had he been a younger brother so circumstanced that he had not constantly been used to govern.’ pro/teron is adverb, and dia\ to\ pro/teron cu/nhqes goes both with the me/n and the de/ clause. Cf. II. 44 to\ d' eu)tuxe/s, oi(\ a(\n th=s eu)prepesta/ths la/xwsin, w(/sper oi(/de me\n nu=n teleuth=s, u(mei=s de\ lu/phs, where the epithet belongs to both nouns.

e)pikou/rous—is specially used of mercenaries and bodyguards. Pisistratus had instituted a body called korunhfo/roi. Cf. Plat. Rcp. p. 566 to\ dh\ turanniko\n ai)/thma . . ai)tei=n to\n dh=mon fu/laka/s tinas tou= sw/matos.
pollw=| tw=| perio/nti—‘with a superabundance.’

ou)x . . h)po/rhsen e)n w(=| ktl—‘was not in difficulties in-asituation-in-which he had not previously grown accustomed to rule.’ The phrase e)n w(=|, quo statu, has at times a vague reference to what precedes, and here=‘(in the sitnation of a younger brother) in which.’ Cf. c. 92 n. to/ te filo/poli ou)k e)n w(=| a)dikou=mai e)/xw. For a)porei=n e)n=‘to be in difficulties in circumstances,’ cf. Aeschin. 1, 159 a)porei=n e)n tw=| lo/gw|. (Most edd. connect e)n w(=| ... w(milh/kei with ou)x w(s a)delfo\s new/teros w)/n, but then Stein's w(s <a)/n> would be necessary; and the above explanation is simpler than taking e)n w(=| as for e)n tou/tw| o(/ti or o(/ti e)n tou/tw|, as some propose.)
tou= pa/qous th=| dustuxi/a|—‘through his tragic fate.’

o)nomasqe/nta=o)nomasto\n geno/menon (Schol.). The accus.
when a dat. (*(ippa/rxw|) or gen. precedes is very common, though it is not necessary.
to\n d' ou)=n—return to the story.
pei/rasin—for pei=ran, Thuc. being fond of abstracts in -sis.
e)paggei/lantes—subject, Hippias and Hipparchus.

kanou=n oi)/sousan—cf. Ath. Pol. c. 18 me/llousan au)tou= th\n a)delfh\n kanhforou=n *panaqhnai/ois e)kw/lusen. The two authorities thus disagree about the occasion of the insult, which in the Ath. Pol is immediately followed by the revenge, whereas in Thuc. there is an interval.
mh\ a)ci/an—the kanhfo/roi were, according to Philochorns ap. Harpocration, ai( e)n a)ciw/mati parqe/noi tw=n a)stw=n kai\ tw=n eu)genw=n.

*panaqh(naia—Gardner and Jevons, p. 287. e)n o(/plois—cu\n o(/plois is often used in this sense. According to Ath. Pol. this story about the arms is wrong, ou) ga\r e)/pempon to/te meq) o(/plwn, a)ll) u(/steron tou=to kateskeu/asen o) dh=mos.
au)tou/s—Harmodius and A. )(
e)kei/nous ‘their confederates.’
ta\ pro\s tou\s d—accus. of respect.
e)/xonta/s ge—causal.
e)ph=lqen—cf. Aeschin. 2, 62 e)ph/|ei xro/nos.

e)/cw—outside the gates, i.e. in the (afterwards) outer Cerameicus, outside the Thriasian gate, later Dipylon, or double gateway through which the Sacred Way passed. At a later time the Pompeium, a building in which the things used in the Panathenaic procession were kept, stood just inside the gate. There seems to be no distinction between ‘outer’ and ‘inner’ Cerameicus before the walls of Themistocles were built. Thuc. describes Hippias as marshalling the procession outside; the conspirators rush inside and kill Hipparchus. The Ath. Pol, however, says that Hippias was waiting to receive the procession on the Acropolis. Thuc. in 1, 21 says that Hipparchus was marshalling the procession when he was killed, and with that account the Ath. Pol. agrees. The route of the procession was from the gate through the inner Cerameicus to the temple of Athena Polias.
e(/kasta—‘the details.’
tw=n cunwmotw=n sfi/si=tw=n cunomosa/ntwn s.
dialego/menon oi)kei/ws—Ath. Pol. l.c. filanqrw)pws e)ntugxa(nonta.
w(/sper ei)=xon—‘forthwith’: several times in Thuc.; but later Attics use ou(/tws Stein reads <ta\> pa/nta e)kin.
w(/rmhsan—the proper use of the act. of this word, ‘to rush.’

para\ to\ *lewko/rion—a verb of motion is not necessary with para/ in this use. It denotes what one sees when one goes past a place. The use is not common, but well established. to\ *lewko/rion—e)n me/sw| tw=| *kerameikw=| (Harpocration). The story was that the three daughters of King Leos were sacrificed to avert famine from Athens. The chapel is connected with the worship of A pollo as god of purification.
w(s a)/n—sc. prospe/soien.
e)/tupton kai\ a)poktei/nousin—the historic pres. is often combined with imperfect. <e)s>to\ au)ti/ka Stem.

ou) r(a|di/ws diete/qh—a characteristic instance of the manner of Thuc., who never dwells on the details of outrages. In Ath. Pol. the story of Aristogeiton's torture and stabbing by Hippias is given at length. Thuc. says only ‘he was harshly treated.’
to\ geno/menon—‘the scene of the act.’
tou\s p. tou\s o(pli/tas—i.e. those in the procession who were armed.
pro/teron h)/—for pro/teron . . pri/n, a very rare construction, except in Herod., Thuc., and Antiphon.
ai)sqe/sqai—sc. to\ geno/menon.

a)dh/lws th=| o)/yei plas—‘he assumed an air of mystery with his expression, i.e. let them see that something had occurred, but without giving any hint of its nature. (The Schol.'s explanation u(pokrina/menos faidro\s ei)=nai, h)/goun a)su/gxuton th\n e(autou= o)/yin thrh/sas, though generally accepted, appears erroneous. The men thought he would give some reason for the sudden interruption of the preparations.)
pro\s th\n c—‘with reference to the disaster.’
oi)o/menoi/ ti e)rei=n—the arms were piled when an address was given.

h( a)lo/gistos to/lma—‘the reckless venture,’ in con trast with the a)rxh\ th=s e)piboulh=s which had been carefully planned. With this only goes e)k tou= paraxrh=ma perideou=s: it was only the reckless venture ‘which arose out of the sudden alarm’ that the conspiracy had been revealed.
xalepwte/ra—Herod. and Ath. Pol. agree.
pollou\s e)/kteine—Ath. Pol. c. 19 dia\ to\ pollou\s a)nh| rhke/nai . . pa=sin h)=n a)/pistos.
pro\s ta\ e)/cw—i.e. for a safe refuge abroad.
metabolh=s—the word is common in the sense of a political change. The gen. abs. goes with u(pa/rxousan ‘ready in the event of . .’ For oi( see Index.
gou=n—‘at least,’ ‘certainly,’ giving the reason in support of the previous remark.
du/nasqai—infin. is rare after ai)sqa/nomai. M. T. § 914. The epitaph is ascribed by Aristotle, Rhet. I. 9 to Simonides of Ceos. Ath. Pol. c. 18 says that Hipparchus was an admirer of Simonides.
u(po\ *aak—see c. 53, 3.
*si/geion—Pisistratus had placed Hegesistratus in charge of it (Herod. v. 94).
w(=n—neut.
mimnh/|skomai here takes accus. neut., (e)kei=na) o(/sa: otherwise the relative would be o(/swn, attracted as always in a rel. sentence replacing a noun.
w(s au)tw=n ktl—cf. Andoc. 1, 48 e)peidh\ e)dede/meqa pa/ntes e)n tw=| au)tw=|.
e)fai/neto—sc. to\ pra=gma. Andoc. l.c. th\n po/lin e)n kakoi=s ou)=san toi=s megi/stois kai\ u(poyi/an ei)s a)llh/lous e)/xontas.
ei(=s—viz. Andocides. He was persuaded by a cousin named Charmides to give information. See crit. n.
ei)/te . . kai\ ta\ o)/nta . . ei)/te kai\ ou)/—a remark thrown in by Thuc., ‘which may equally well have been true or false.’ The double kai/ only serves to balance the two phrases.
e)p' a/mfo/tera—‘both opinions are held conjecturally.’ With
to/te supply ei(=xen: so I. 86, 2; III. 40 The speech of Andocides de Mysteriis was not delivered till 399 B.C.; and it looks as if the account of Thuc. had been written before that event.

ei) mh\ kai\ de/draken—‘if he is not really guilty.’ Cf. II. 11 ei) mh\ kai\ nu=n w(/rmhntai=‘if they have not started already.’ It is generally assumed that kai/ is out of place; but there is no need for this, since kai\ de/draken is properly contrasted with au(to\n a)/deian poihsa/menon sw=sai, which clearly implies au(tou= kathgorei=n.
a)/deian poihsa/menon—‘obtaining for himself a free pardon.’ See c. 27, 2. According to Andocides the a)/deia was afterwards cancelled in his case.
bebaiote/ran ktl—so Andoc.: toi=s me\n ou)de/pw be/baios h)=n h( swthri/a . . ei) mh/ tis e)rei= *)aqhnai/ois ta\ geno/mena.

o(mologh/santi—this cannot belong to dia\ di/khs e(lqei=n
because Andocides was immediately released. Hence strictly either o(mologh=sai or e)lqo/nti is required.
kaq) e(autou=—that Andocides did inculpate himself is clear from the speech de Reditu, and is shown by implication even in the de Mysteriis.
kat' a)/llwn applies, if Andoc. speaks the truth, to four persons only who had not been included in Teucrus's list.
w(s w)/|eto—with to\ safe/s.
deino\n poiou/menoi—imperf. partic.; cf. ou)k a)na/sxeton poiei=sqai. deina\ poiei=n is to declare a thing intolerable)(d. poiei=sqai to think it so.

kri/seis poih/santes—this no doubt is a brief statement to imply that the persons informed against generally were tried, excepting the victims of Dioclides. Cf. [Lys.] 6, 23. They were not all tried as the result of Andocides's information. The proceedings were under the no/mos ei)saggeltiko/s, and the trials were before the heliasts

e)panei=pon a)rgu/rion—their goods were confiscated, C.I.A. I. 274; Hicks n. 55; [Lys.] 6, 18 tou)s feu/gontas zhtei=te sullamba/nein, e)pikhru/ttontes ta/lanton a)rguri/ou dw/sein tw=| a)pago/nti h)\ a)poktei/nanti. So Philochorus ap. Schol. on Aristoph. Birds 766.
perifanw=s—antithesis to a)dh/lws. He means because the panic was allayed. The rewards to informers were then distributed at the Panathenaea.
e)nago/ntwn—esp. Androcles and Thessalus, son of Cimon.

meta\ tou= au)tou= lo/gou . . dh/mw|—the edd. who retain the text explain kai\ th=s cun. (1) as hendiadys with tou= au)tou= lo/gou, (2) ‘with the same plan as the conspiracy,’ which supposes an unparalleled attraction of case in th=s cunwmosi/as, (3) kai/ explanatory, ‘that is to say’; and repeat meta/. It is, however, better to take kai\ th=s cun. e)pi\ tw=| dh/mw| together=tw=n cunwmotw=n e(pi\ tw=| d.: the outrage is done (1) with the same object, viz. the destruction of the constitution, (2) in collusion with the conspirators. The omission of the second meta/ is not without parallel, VII. 60, 4 e)c a)nagkai/ou te kai\ toiau/ths dianoi/as, and c. 37, 2 e)k skhnidi/wn kai\ a)nagkai/as paraskeuh=s, where the two nouns are dissimilar. e)pi/ ‘against’ w. dat. is poetical.

kai\ ga/r tis—Andoc. 1, 45 also says that the Boeotians were astir on the frontier. What was feared was a concerted attempt to subvert the democracy by force. The proximity of hostile forces was no doubt due to a wish to know the meaning and extent of the Athenian preparations, and had nothing to do with the outrages.
e)/tuxe . . parelqou=sa—‘happened to come.’
pro/s—‘with,’ of negotiation.
h(/kein—often used of coming by appointment. According to Andoc. this scare happened before he gave his information.
tina mi/an—c. 31, 4.

e)n *qhsei/w|—Andoc. says a)nakale/santes tou\s strathgou\s a)neipei=n e)ke/leusan (1) tou\s me
 e)n a)/stei oi)kou=ntas i)e/nai ei)s th
 a)gora
 ta\ o(/pla labo/ntas, (2) tou\s d' e)n makrw=| tei/xei ei)s to\ *qhsei=on. The Theseum alluded to by Thuc. contained the relics of Theseus; kei=tai e)n me/sh| th=| po/lei para\ to\ nu=n gumna/sion (Plut. Thes. 36), that is, in the Agora near the Gymnasium of Ptolemy, now Stoa of Attalus. But the Theseum alluded to by Andoc. (2) is not this building, but another by the Long Walls. It must therefore be assumed that Andoc. (1) alludes to to\ *qhsei=on to\ e)n po/lei. It is well known that the Theseum of Thuc. was used as a place for mustering in arms. Ath. Pol. c. 14 speaks of Pisistratus e)coplisi/an e)n tw=| *qhsei/w| poihsa/menos. (The famous building now called the Theseum is now believed not to be a temple of Theseus.)
oi(/ te ce/noi—friends whom he had made during his expedition to the Peloponnese.

u(pwpteu/qhsan . . e)piti/qesqai—personal construction: lit. ‘were suspected to be making an attack on.’ This pres. inf. is usually explained as being used for the fut.; but the verb is used in its metaphorical sense, not meaning that the political action was more than begun.
tou\s o(mh/rous—300 Argives belonging to the oligarchs had been placed by the Athenians under Alcibiades himself in various islauds in 416.
dia\ tau=ta—because of their supposed connexion with Alcibiades's friends.
perieisth/kei . . e)s—‘gathered round.’ With the construction e)s, which is unusual, cf. tre/pein th\n o)rgh\n ei)/s tina. The same construction is used in I. 78.
ou(/tw—‘with this intention.’
w(=n pe/ri a)/llwn=e)pi\ tou\s a)/llous peri\ w(=n.

qerapeu/ontes—as though ei)rh/kesan preceded. See II. 53, 2. For qerapeu/w=e)pime/lomai with inf. cf. VII. 70 e)qera/peuon . . mh\ lei/pesqai. to/ goes with pro\s tou\s e)n th=| *s.: mh\ qorubei=n is final: the length of the sentence accounts for

boulo/menoi instead of a new object to qerapeu/ontes: ‘being anxious not to cause a disturbance among their troops and their enemies in Sicily.’ Before polemi/ous (noun) repeat pro\s tou\s e)n *sikeli/a|.
It is less well, as in Intr. p. xxiv., to take to/ with qorubei=n. The above trans, is in agreement with Stein.
*mantine/as—see c. 43, 2.
th\n e(autou= nau=n—apparently his private property. It does not seem to be a pecuhar circumstance. Plut. Per. 35 tou= *perikle/ous a)nabebhko/tos e)pi\ th\n e(autou= trih/rh.
*qouri/ois—the name of the people, as often, for the name of the place. The town was on the site of Sybaris, and was colonised by the Athenians in 443.
ou) faneroi/—‘could not be found.’ They hid until the state ship departed.
e)pi\ diabolh=|—‘with a prejudice against him,’ e)pi/ giving the condition under which he would return.
h)/dh—‘from that time.’
e)rh/mh| di/kh|—‘by default.’ The trial had been instituted already before the Salaminia left, by Thessalus.
qa/naton—his goods were confiscated, and the Eumolpidae, in which family the pricsthood of the Mysteries was hereditary, invoked a curse upon him. His goods were confiscated.
e)/pleon—it was a grave blunder after showing them selves at Syracuse to sail away to Segesta. Nicias now took np his own plan of action, for which see c. 47.

e)pi\ *selinou=ntos—they would come first to Segesta; but Stahl wrongly doubts the reading, for places are not uncommonly mentioned in Greek in the reverse order, the ultimate destination being given first: II. 7, 3; 93, 1. The opening lines of the Bacchae (13 f.) proceed on the same principle.
ta\ dia/fora—‘the points of difference.’ Thuc. says nothing further about this matter.

paraple/ontes d' e)n a)riste/ra—‘coasting along S. on the left,’ i e. along the north coast. Usually e)n a)riste/ra| (deci/a|) e)/xontes, or labo/ntes, but Stahl, followed by Classen, notices that the partie. would mean that they were sailing with some other destination in view than the north coast itself.

*(ella\s po/lis—for *(ellhni/s: for this, and not *(ellhnikh/, is Thuc.'s ordinary adj. with po/lis. The form *(/ellhn as an adj. can probably only be used with persons, *(/ellhn po/lemos in II. 36 being open to doubt. The use of these forms as adj. is poetical and Ionic.

ai(rou=sin *(/ukkara—‘by this time some horsemen from Segesta had come . . It was from them, doubtless, that the A. learned that the people of H. were enemies of Segesta’
(Freeman). Thuc. ‘subjoins po/lisma *sikaniko/n etc., because, from the circumstance of the town heing of Sicanian origin, it might be expected that the Hyccarines should be on friendly terms with Egesta, which was of the same origin, or nearly such’ (Bloomfield). See c. 2, 3.
au)toi\ de/—the army now marches back through the heart of Sicily to Catana. They thus left room in the ships for the prisoners.

ai( de\ nh=es—the fleet is for a very short time divided, Nicias going on with part to the harbour of Segesta, while the other part prepares to sail for Catana. Nieias then rejoins the rest of the fleet, and with it parh=n e)s to\ stra/teuma, joins the army at Catana.
perie/pleusan—sc. e)s *kata/nhn.
eu)qu/s—without waiting for the prisoners to be got on board and for the army to start; possibly also without waiting for the fall of Hyccara. (The narrative is obscure here.)

a)pe/dosan—the act. (see crit. note) certainly cannot= ‘sold,’ but must mean ‘gave back’ or ‘paid’ or ‘delivered.’ Grote says it ‘seems to mean that the prisoners were handed over to their fellow-countrymen, the natural persons to negotiate for their release, upon private contract of a definite sum,’ but this does not suit parh=n e)s to\ stra/teuma. Bloomfield thinks ‘exposed for sale’is a possible meaning of the active. The difficulty really comes from the obscurity of the passage that precedes. If Nicias left Hyccara before it fell, and rejoined the main fleet on the way back to Catana, a)pe/dosan may mean ‘they delivered the prisoners to Nicias.’ e)ge/nonto e)c au)tw=n is enough to show that they were then sold.

e)ge/nonto—the plur. verb with neut. subject, not persons, appears in all MSS. only in v. 75 *karnei=a e(tugxanon o/nta, v. 26 a(marth/mata e)ge/nonto, and here. In I. 126 e)ph=lqon *)olu/mpia CEG read e)ph=lqen, and in II. 8 lo/gia e)ge/nonto CG read e)ge/neto. a)pe/lusan for a)pe/dosan Argyriades.

tou\s tw=n *sikelw=n cumma/xous—the gen. here is elearly partitive, and this is the only passage in Thuc. in which the partitive gen. is placed between art. and substantive: in all other passages that resemble this the last word is either a partic or an adj.; cf. cc. 87, 2; 102, 1. In Herod. the same order is found, almost always with adj. or partic.; the order is not found in Attic. (This passage is defended by H. Kleist, N. Jahrb. 143 p. 110, O. Diener de sermone Thuc. p. 77, and by Darpe de verb. ap. Thuc. collocat. p. 25.)

perie/pleusan—if this is the right word, the meaning is
that the fleet again sailed along the north coast, as Freeman and Holm explain. (It is strange that apparently the whole fleet should go on such a mission. But see Intr. p. xxiii.)
*(/ublan—see c. 2, 5. They attempt to take the city by storm.
pareskeua/zonto—has a double construction here, as also in VIII. 4.
i)o/ntes—the moods of ei)=mi are generally present, except in O.O.
pro/s—‘in accordance with,’ ‘as they had at first feared and as they expected.’
kata\ th\n h(. e(—the art. is either inserted or omitted at will. The insertion makes the expression more formal: ‘as each day passed.’ The addition of the partie. is unusual.
ple/onte/s te—answered by kai\ . . e)lqo/ntes. See crit. n.
ta\ e)p' e)kei=na—Classen makes this adverbial; others internal accus. to ple/ontes=ple/ontes to\n e)p' e)kei=na plou=n. ta\ e)p' e)kei=na ‘on the far side’)(ta\ e)pi\ ta/de ‘on the near side.’
peira/santes—sc. au)th=s, an Ionic use of the act. of peirw= in this sense.
katefro/nhsan—‘came to despise them,’ ingressive. So qarsh/sas.
e)kei=noi—often used of the enemy.
e)fu/brizon=meq) u(/brews h)rw/twn.
ei) . . h)/—‘whether . . or,’ and
ma=llon=‘by prefcrence.’

sfi/sin=the Syraeusans, who are contrasted with the Leontines. It is possible that Plutarch read cunhkh/sontes au:toi=s ma=llon, as he has ei) *katanai/ois sunoikh/sontes h)\ *leonti/nous katoikiou=ntes h(/kousi.
a)/gein . . o(/ti plei=ston—‘draw them as far as possible.’
e)n tosou/tw|—‘in the interval gained’: here of a considerable time; in Aristoph. Eq. 420 of a short time. Demosth. 4, 37 e)n o(/sw| tau=ta me/lletai.
e)n e)pithdei/w|—‘in some suitable spot.’
kaq) h(suxi/an—‘undisturbed,’ as often.
ou)k a)\n o(moi/ws—Thuc. often nses ou)x o(moi/ws as a meiosis for an absolute negative.
kaqi/sai—see erit. note; sc. to\ stra/teuma, as with e)kbiba/zoien.

tou\s ga\r . . o)/xlon—object of bla/ptein, tw=n *s. tou\s i(ppe/as
being subject. o)/xlon=camp-followers, turbam castrensem. The ground between Catana and Syraeuse is mostly flat, so that cavalry would have a great opportunity.
ou(/tw de/—i.e. by the method proposed.
o(/qen—Stahl regards this as an instance of the rare attraction of the adverb,=e)kei=qen o(/pou. Rather o(/qen=o(/qen o\rmw/menoi.
bla/yontai (pass.).
a)/cia—‘will not suffer any considerable injury.’ The neut. plur. is very common with bla/ptw.
pro\s tw=| *)olumpiei/w|—the temple of Zeus and its precincts south of the city. Two pillars still stand. See plan.
o(/per kai\ kate/labon—there could not be attraction of the rel. here, as the remark is parenthetic.
*surakosi/wn fuga/des—political exiles. For the party in Catana favourable to Syracuse see cc. 50, 3; 51, 2.
ou)=n—resuming after the parenthesis, as in e.g. VII. 6, 1. So igitur, sed, autem.
pro\s a(\ e)—‘in order to realise their wish.’
pe/mpousin—asyndeton after the demonstrative toio/nde. VII. 73, 3 is a very similar instance.
th=| dokh/sei—‘as they thought.’
kai\ h)pi/stanto—the relative not repeated. Cf. c. 4, 3 n.

a)po\ tw=n o(/plwn—‘“apart from their place of arms, or encampment” . . as at I. 111. This name was given because it was, as Dr. Arnold observes, the place where the spears and shields were kept piled’ (Bloomfield). o(/pla is used for one or more camping stations as distinct from the fortifications—ta\ tei/xh—whether the stations are inside or outside a town. The word might be applied to such buildings at Athens as the Theseum and the Anaceum (see c. 61, 2 n.).

e)pi\ to\ stra/teuma—esp. that part of the army which was not sleeping in the city. This must have been represented as considerable, else it would have been absurd to suggest that they should come pandhmei/. Still the prospect put before Syr. is that of capturing the whole army. The stau/rwma round the o(/pla must be on the side of Catana away from the sea, and the ships are represented by the messenger to be drawn up on shore, as would be natural in winter.
au)toi/—for the case see nn. on cc. 4, 2; 48, 2.

to\ stra/teuma . . ai(rh/sein—‘would capture the (whole) army,’ including those in the city (tou\s para\ sfi/si)—for the gates would be shut and the ships would be burnt—‘after attacking the palisade’ that surrounded the camp.
h(toima/sqai ktl=e(toi/mous ei)=nai tou\s a)/ndras par' w(=n au)to\s h(/kei (Schol.).

meta\ tou=—‘with the confidence that they otherwise felt, and the resolve even without this message to attack C., believed the man far more inconsiderately (than they would have done otherwise).’ meta/ with infin. is rare: it occurs only in I. 6, II. 43, both gen., and here. Demosth. 5, 5 meta\ tou= prosoflei=n ai)sxu/nhn . . e)/gnwte th\n tw=n tau=ta peisa/ntwn kaki/an.

kai\ au)toi/—edd. do not agree about au)toi/: (1) Classen says it is contrasted with the Catanaeans, of whose help they were confident; (2) Stahl says it is contrasted with the allies referred to in the parenthesis. Both explanations are poor. au)toi/ means oi( strathgoi\ tw=n *s., and in c. 63, 2 we have read h)ci/oun tou\s strathgou\s . . a)/gein sfa=s e)pi\ *kata/nhn. But now, after the message, the generals no longer need to be urged, but of their own accord order the whole force to be ready to march out, being further encouraged thereto by the arrival of allies.
kai\ tw=n c—‘some of their allies too.’
e)pei\ de\ e(toi=ma au)toi=s—this now resumes from c. 63, 1 oi) *surako/sioi pareskeua/zonto w\s e)p' e)kei/nous i)o/ntes, all that has intervened being an explanation. 11
ai( h(me/rai—‘the time.’ The affair was to occupy more than one day.
*sumai/qw|—the largest river in Sicily, the Giaretta. Being in Leontine territory, it is in the hands of Syracuse.
*sikelw=n—see c. 62, 5. The Syr. had been utterly ignorant of the A. preparations to attack them.
e)ce/bainon e)s—‘landed in the district near the O.,’ the temple remaining in the hands of Syr.
to\ strato/pedon—the camp referred to in c. 64, 1.
a)potrepo/menoi—imperf. representing the time taken.
au)toi=s—the Syr.
kaqi=san—notice the angment of kaqi/zw as it is used in old Attic.

e)s xwri/on e)pith/deion—the position is determined by the description, and recent authorities are in substantial agreement. South of the Anapus lies a plateau, bounded on the west by the marsh round the Cyane, on the east by the harbour. The camp lay on this plateau, SE. of the Olympieium. On one side —the west and north-west—it was covered by the marsh round the Cyane and the trees and buildings that intervened between the camp and the temple, which was held by the Syracusans;
north, it was protected by the cliffs running from the temple to the sea.
ma/xhs a)/rcein—‘be the first to fight,’ i.e. give battle only when he chose.
e)n tw=| e)/rgw|—‘during the engagement.’
para\ de\ to/—see c. 45 pro\s de\ tou/s.
stau/rwma—a palisade stretching out from the shore into the water.
e)/ruma—somewhat SE. of the camp.
eu)efodw/taton—i.e. open to an attack by sea and land.

li/qois loga/dhn=e)pilelegme/nois li/qois (Schol.): the adv. does not occur in other Attic writers, and the adj. loga/des for prose only in Herod., Thuc., and in late writers, Thuc. has a way of placing an adv. next a noun so that it belongs to it rather than to the verb, as in VII. 7 o(/pws stratia\ e)/ti peraiwqh=|, ‘remforcements.’ The same occurs in Tacitus and in Lat. poetry.
ge/furan—the Helorine road crossed the Anapus (Alfeo) by this bridge.
paraskeuazo/menwn—sc. au)tw=n, the subject often being omitted when it can easily be supplied in the gen. abs. The same occurs in Tac. in the abl. abs. frequently.
e)/peita de\ u(/steron—frequently used together. So meta\ tau=q) u)/steron several times in Demosth.
diaba/ntes—‘that is, they withdrew into the precinet of the temple, or at least into its immediate neighbourhood’ (Freeman). The Syr. must have previously erossed the road to get at the A.
w(s e)s ma/xhn—the site of the following battle was somewhere S. of the Anapus and E. of the Helorine road.
to\ me\n h(/misn—half the army is in front, eight deep, half behind, covering the camp, in a hollow square, the baggage being inside the square. The A. face E., the Syr. W.
ponh=|—the word is used also of disabled ships.
e)forw=ntas—‘watching.’
tw=n e)pita/ktwn—cf. § 2.
eu)nai/=‘sleeping-places.’
e)poih/santo—the usual phrase is e)nto\s poiei=sqai, but e)nto\s poiei=n (ta/cin) is also found, used of the general.
e)f) e(kkai/deka—sixteen deep.
ma/lista—prob. a numeral has fallen out after this word.
e)pi\ tw=| deciw=|—because here the ground was smooth, being on the platean. Nicias had no force to oppose to the eavalry.
prote/rois e)pixeirh(sein=a)/rcein th=s ma/xhs.
e)pipariw/n—‘passing along the lines.’ e(/kasta is direct obj. to this, while kata\ e)/qnh and cu/mpasi are objects to parekeleu/eto.
oi(/—‘seeing that we.’
e)pi\ to\n au)to/n—contrasted with pollh=| paraine/sei). The same remarks will do for all, and they need not be long.

kalw=s lexqe/ntes—‘plausible,’ not without a side reference to the Sicilian rhetoric. It is the habit of Thuc. to represent a general as answering the arguments of the enemy's leader, as though they were contending in an assembly.
pandhmei/—whereas the A are chosen katalo/gois xrhstoi=s (c. 31, 3). pandhmei/ is the contrary of e)k katalo/gou.
w(/sper kai\ h(ma=s—attraction with w(/sper, as in I. 69, etc Cf. the attraction of oi(=os as in VII. 21 pro\s a)/ndras tolmhrou\s oi(/ous kai\ *(aqhnai/ous.
u(perfronou=si . . u(pomenou=si—paronomasia. u(pome/nein is the regular word of soldiers who stand their ground.
dia\ to/ . . —‘because they have less knowledge than courage.’ Their e)pisth/mh is small because they are not pieked men.
parasth/tw de/ tini—‘one should remember too that we are far from our own home and in the neighbourhood of no friendly country, unless indeed you mean to gain one by the sword.’ Stein thinks
ou)demia=| f=pa/sh| a)llotri/a|.
kai/—‘in fact.’
tou)nanti/on . . h)/—Herod. IX. 56 h)/isan ta\ e)/mpalin h)\ *lakedaimo/nioi: Thuc. VII. 80 a)pa/gein . . tou)nanti/on h)\ oi( *surako/sioi e)th/roun.
u(pomimnh/|skw—‘suggest’: ‘I offer you a suggestion which is the reverse of the encouragement that the enemy are without doubt offering to one another.’
oi( me\n ga/r—sc. parakeleu/ontai. e)lw\ de/—sc. u(pomimnh/|skw o(/ti e)/stai o) a)gw(n.

ou)k e)n patri/di=e)n gh=| ou) patri/di ou)/sh|. This order of the neg. is common with prepositions. e)c h(=s kratei=n dei= h)\ mh\ r(. a)poxwrei=n—e)c h)=s really depends on a)poxwrei=n, ‘from which it is difficult to retreat unless we win.’ Cf. II. 88 ai)ei\ au)toi=s e)/lege (kai\ propareskeu/aze ta\s gnw/mas) w(s ou)de\n au)toi=s plh=qos a(\n e)piple/oi. Livy 21, 18 nostra haec quaestio (atque animadversio) in civem nostrum est, nostra an suo fecerit arbitrio.
polloi/—sc. o)/ntes.
a)ci/as=a)ciw/matos.
proqu/mws . . kai\ h(ghsa/menoi—the partic. and adv. are combined, as elsewhere.
th\n parou=san a)na/gkhn—i.e. the obligation to win; whereas a)pori/an is ‘the dilemma’—victory or a difficult retreat.
strato/pedon—often used for an army stationed in a permanent camp.
a)prosdo/khtoi—active: ‘were not at this moment expecting an immediate engagement.’
a)pelhlu/qesan—sc. e)s th\n po/lin.
oi( de/—‘others,’ who were returning from Cataua (c. 65, 3), or coming from Syracuse. There was no time to form up regularly.
e)s o(/son . . a)nte/xoi—iterative opt., referring to several battles (ou)/t' e)n tau)th| ou(/t' e)n tai=s a(/llais).
tw=| de\ e)llei/ponti au)th=s—‘owing to its short-comings they unwillingly abandoned their inteutions as well.’

o(/mws de/—answering a)prosdo/khtoi me)n. ou)k a)
 oi)o/menoi . . a)mu/nasqai is concessive, the a)/n belonging both to e)pelqei=n and a)mu/nasqai: ‘though they did not think that the A. would make an attack on them and that they would suddenly be forced to defend themselves.’ (According to this version oi)o/menoi a)
 a)mu/nasqai a)nagkazo/menoi is the construction. The edd. make a)nagkazo/menoi govern a)mu/nasqai, and Stahl, seeing that by that construction a)nagkazo/menoi a)mu/nasqai ought to be causal, not concessive, is reduced to bracketing ou)k a)
 oi)o/menoi . . kai/ as spurious.)
a)nagkazo/menoi—‘by compulsion.’ They had thought to choose their own time
oi( liqobo/loi—Wasse and Bloomfield quote several passages to show that these men threw stones and are therefore distinct from slingers.
oi(=a—sc. poiei=n. Cf. II. 54 oi(=a ei)ko\s a)nemnh/sqhsan, and w(s ei)ko/s.
e)poi/oun tropa/s—‘put one another to flight.’ poiei=n troph/n is to ‘cause a flight’ where the enemy returns to fight; poiei=sqai t. is ‘to defeat’ outright.
ma/nteis—some are known to have gone with the A. to Sicily.
o)tru/nw and its cmpds. are Ionic.
th=s i)di/as—governed by peri/, and applying to swthri/as and e)leuqeri/as. See II. 44, quoted on c. 55, 3.
to\ me\n au)ti/ka, to\ de\ me/llon—‘present . . future.’ With to\ me/llon cf. to\ a)rxai=on, to\ palaio/n, to\ loipo/n.

peri/ te th=s a)llotri/as—sc. maxou/menoi, on which also depends sxei=n, the addition being due to the contrast with th\n oi)kei/an mh\ bla/yai. Cf. I. 50 pro\s tou\s a)nqrw/pous e)tra/ponto foneu/ein ma=llon h)\ zwgrei=n.

oi( au)to/nomoi—see c. 68, 2. The force of the distinction between the independent and dependent allies is this: for the former love of country was a principal object; for the latter the chief object was safety at the moment, and it might be that by a victory their country would become more worth living in.
a)nelpi/stou=h(\ a)ne/lpistos h)=n.
e)/peita de/ ktl—‘and a secondary motive was the possibility that by helping to subdue others they might find their subjeetion to Athens (au)toi=s) less oppressive.’
a)/llo ti is object to cugkatastreya/menon, to which supply to\ u(ph/koon. The return to the neut. sing. is influenced by ti a)/llo, which stands for tinas a)/llous.
genome/nhs e)n xersi/—so e)n xersi\ geno/menoi. In Lat. too both ad manus veniunt and ad manus pugna venit are found.
toi=s me)n—dat. incommodi.
kai\ tou=to—as well as their inexperience. cunepilabe/sqai—ai)/tion fo/bou gene/sqai (Schol.).
kai\ w(/ra e)/tous—‘merely the result of the season,’ which was late in the autumn. w(/ra e)/tous may refer to any season, but is most often used of the hot season.
tou\s de\ a)nqestw=tas—‘the circumstance that the enemy did not give way.’ Cf. c. 46, 2.
to\ kata\ sfa=s au)tou/s—viz. to\ me/son, c. 67, 1. For the kata/ cf. Demosth. 57, 2 pro\s th\n kat' e)kei/nwn ai)ti/an, ou) pro\s to\ kaq) au(to\n e(/kastos a)gwnizo/meqa.
o(/son a)sfalw=s ei)=xe—with e)pakolouqh/santes. pa/lin =back to their lines.
w(s e)k tw=n p—‘as well as they could.’
o(/mws—‘though defeated.’
sfw=n au)tw=n . . tw=n xrhma/twn—partitive gen.
to\ i(ero/n—Plutarch says that the A. army was anxious to seize the spoils of the temple, and that Nieias prevented the sacrilege, and purposely permitted the Syr. to occupy the Olympieum.
cugkomi/santes—to burn them. nekrou\s sugkomi/zein is the regular phrase for preparing the dead.

e)pi\ pura\n e)piqe/ntes—it was the custom to burn the bodies on the field of battle, then to collect the bones and send them to Athens to be buried in the outer Cerameicus. In the case of Marathon, however, the bones were buried on the field of battle, this being regarded as a special honour. It is noticeable that Thuc. in describing this first battle of the expedition puts down the occurrences—such as the preliminary sacrifices and the details of burial—that are a part of all battles.
au)tou=—on the battle-field.
a)pe/pleusan e)s *kata/nhn—a strange thing to do after gaining a victory. Nicias surely ought to have attacked Syracuse: for this purpose cavalry would not have been needed.
au)to/qen poiei=sqai—i.e. from the position which they now occupied. But it is strange that they did not discover all this before taking up the position.

i(ppe/as te . . kai\ xrh/mata de/—here te is answered by de/, for kai/ strictly=‘as well.’ te . . de/ is quite common, esp. in tragedy. kai\ . . de/ occurs several times in Thuc. Notice the chiasnius in e)k tw=n *)aqhnw=n . . e)k tw=n au)to/qen . . au)to/qen . . kai\ par' *)aqhnai/wn. Chiasmus is very common in Thuc.
metape/mywsin—the act. means to summon to one's aid. Cf. c. 52, 1.
xrh/mata—serves as object of one verb and subject of another.
kai\ si=ton—explanation of ta\ a)/lla, so that kai/ = ‘both.’
e)s to\ e)/ar—expressing the time in the fnt. when the thing is to occur. Frequent in Aristophanes.

e)s th\n *na/con kai\ *kata/nhn—the order is the same as in c. 61, 2, the more remote place being mentioned first. For the stay of the fleet at Naxos see c. 74, 1. Thuc. here gives in summary the action of the A. during the rest of the winter before passing to the action of the Syr. during the same time.
e)poi/oun—‘called,’ of the authorities.

a)nh\r ktl—as this is the third interposition of Hermocrates (IV. 58 and VI. 32), it is rather strange to find him lishered in with this eulogy; but Thuc. means to mark the increase of his reputation kata\ to\n po/lemon.
cu/nesin—the dat. is commoner.

e)mpeiri/a|—i.e. the experience he had gained in previous
wars was of service to him in this war.
kata\ to\n po/lemon is not general, but refers to this particular war.
ou)k ei)/a—‘urged them not to take the result seriously.’
gnw/mhn—‘spirit,’ virtus.
ei)=nai—attraction of rel. sentenee in O.O.; cf. c. 24, 3. See crit. note.
xeirote/xnais—sc. ma/xhs, the contrast being between skilled and unskilled workmen—veterans chosen katalo/gois xrhstoi=s and new levies.
me/ga de\ bla/yai kai\ tw=n s. th\n p—‘they were greatly hampered too by the number of generals in command . . . and the disorganised confusion of the rank and file.’
paraskeua/swsi ktl—‘improve the hoplites, by providing arms for those who had none (i.e. because they were too poor to huy them) . . and by enforcing a thorough system of training.’
a)/llh| means the other details besides the use of arms.
eu)taci/as de/—‘and since they would acquire discipline in action’
prosgenome/nhs is equivalent to a fut. perf.
a)mfo/tera—i.e. th\n a)ndri/an (=eu)yuxi/an) kai\ th\n eu)taci/an.

au)ta/—‘naturally,’ ‘automatically,’ since ‘by association with danger their discipline would be called into practice, and their courage would be bolder than ever by association with the confidence that knowledge gives.’ Cf. II. 40 to\ pisto\n th=s e/leuqeri/as. In
e)/sesqai there is an anacoluthon, e)some/nhn being strictly required to match meletwme/nhn. Cf. c. 35, 1.
o)mo/sai au)toi=s—the whole people were to take this oath. It was not to be confined to the troops
a)profasi/stws—‘with resolution,’ without having to offer reasons for their conduct.
kai/—‘accordingly.’
tou/tous trei=s—‘only these three.’
cummaxi/a=cu/mmaxoi.
to\n po/lemon bebaio/teron p—‘give to the war a more decided and open character.’
a)paga/gwsin—sc. oi( *)aqhnai=oi.
w)feli/an a)/llhn—‘reinforcements.’
e)pipe/mpein is contrasted with metape/mpein in VII. 15.
a(\ me\n e)pra/sseto—‘the design failed, because Alc. . . knowing that he would be banished, gave information about the plot, of which he had knowledge.’
tou/s te a)/ndras—i.e. tou\s mhnuqe/ntas.
pro/teron—before the Athentans arrived.
e)pekra/toun—the subject is suddenly narrowed down from the Messenians at large (oi( de/) to the party favourable to Syr. (oi( tau=ta boulo/menoi).
peri/—as in I. 117 h(me/ras peri\ tessa/ras kai\ de/ka. But this use of peri/ to denote the appioximate period is not common. It does not occur in the orators, nor in Aristoph.
prouxw/rei—a favourite word with Thue. for ‘to succeed.’

o(/ria kai/—on the MSS. *qra|kas see crit. note. o(/ria are, according to Stahl, protected places for the storage of arms and baggage. Hesych. explains o(/ria as tei/xisma, fragmo/s. Others understand o(/ria as ‘docks,’ new/ria.

to\n *temeni)thn—(1) the wall was built so as to en close the T., or precinct of Apollo's temple, which was part of the Neapolis; (2) it was pro\s th=| po/lei, adjoining the city wall; (3) it was para\ pa=n to\ pro\s ta\s *)epipola\s o(rw=n, ‘running all along the ground that looks towards Epipolae.’ This is not clear; but it implies (a) a wall of considerable length, (b) a wall that did not project far to the west. 3
e)nto\s poihsa/menoi—‘taking into it.’

di' e)la/ssonos—‘that the shorter distance (at which the A. would otherwise be able to build) might not render it easy to invest them in case of a defeat’; i.e. the object of the new outwork was to increase the length of wall that the A. would have to build if they attempted to invest Syr. With di' e)la/ssonos ‘at a less distance’ cf. dia\ pollou=, di' o)li/gou, dia\ tosou/tou. It was esp. from the cliff to the harbour that the distance was increased; and from c. 103, 1 it appears that the A. had to cover a distance of some eight stadia in this direction.

ta\ *me/gara frou/rion—‘as an ontpost,’ sc. e)tei/xizon. Cf. II. 32 e)teixi/sqh *)atala/nth frou/rion. Megara was before deserted; see c. 49, 4 and c. 4, 1 n. It now becomes a northern outpost of Syr.: Poppo explains that the object was to prevent the A. from making Megara a naval station.
e)n tw=| *)o.—see c. 70, 4. The palisades were not constructed at Leon and Thapsus (c. 97, 1), and so must have been chiefly for the great harbour (Poppo).

au)tw=n—tw=n *katanai/wn. The camp was of course empty, and the Athenians apparently did not think it worth while to hinder the Syr., though why they allowed the land of Catana to be ravaged is not clear.

th\n e)pi\ *la/xhtos—sec c. 1, 1 n., and cf. c. 6, 1. From c. 52, 1 it appears that Camarina held that this treaty
had been superseded by the treaty of Gela in 424 B.C., and in c. 67, 2 we hear of Camarina sending some slight help to Syr. But now Camarina acts with caution. The treaty of 424 was only spondai/ (IV. 65), a cessation of hostilities, whereas the treaty of 427 between Cam. and Athens was cummaxi/a. In 422 Cam. had sided with Athens. In c. 78, 4 Hermocrates exaggerates the importance of the spondai/ of 424 in the words mh\ malakw=s w(/sper nu=n cummaxei=n: and in c. 79, 1 he mmimises the importance of the cummaxi/a of 427 by treating it as an e)pimaxi/a, or defensive alliance—which it was not. The resnlt of the debate that follows is that Cam. remains nentral. She joined Syr. in 413 (VII. 33).

pe/myai a)\ e)/pemyan—expressive of blame or contempt; cf. Herod. II. 49 poieu=si ta\ poieu=si. mh\ ou)ke/ti b.—u(/poptoi has the construction of a verb of fearing, as also have u(potoph=sai, u(popteu/ein, u(po/noia.
prosxwrw=si—sc. mh/. kata/ = ‘owing to.’
prodiaba/llein—‘prejudice them against the A.’
th\n p. du/namin—obj. of dei/santes, while au)th/n is obj. of kataplagh=te.
kataplagh=te—i.e. that fear may induce Camarina to join the A.

tou\s . . lo/gous—depends on dei/santes. me/llontas is contrasted with parou=san, lo/gous with du/namin. ‘We sent out our cmbassy, not from a fear that . . but from a fear that the words that they intended to address to you before you could hear what we have to say, might persuade you.’ Notice that pri/n ti . . a)kou=sai precedes mh/, and consequently belongs to tou\s me/llontas, not to pei/swsin.

h(=| punqa/nesqe—sc. h(/kein: but h(/n is direct obj. of u(ponoou=men. (So Classen; Kruger and others explain h(=| as attracted for h(/n, and h(/n as left unattracted for the sake of variety, but this is scaicely probable.)
katoiki/sai . . e)coiki)sai—paronomasia, adnominatio; cf. c. 76, 4 a)cunetwte/rou, kakocunetwte/rou: 79, 2 a)lo/gws . . eu)lo/gw|. It is very common in Thuc. See c. 72, 4.
ta\s me\n e)kei = po/leis—Aegina, Scione, and Melos are especially referred to.
*xalkide/wn—see c. 3, 3. The Chalcidians of Euboea are said to be ‘enslaved’ because their independence is gone. doulei/a often denotes the opposite of au)tonomi/a.
doulwsame/nous e)/xein—cf. c. 39, 2 n. There is again an enthymeme here. See on c. 10, 5.
i)de/a|—‘method.’
e)kei=na—i.e. ta\ e)kei=, their possessions in Greece.
e)/sxon, ‘obtamed.’ With

peirw=ntai supply sxei=n, the infin. or partic. being often omitted with verbs that require the completion: e.g. v. 80 ou) me/ntoi eu)qu/s ge a)pe/sth a)lla\ dienoei=to (sc. a)posth=nai) o(/ti kai\ tou\s *)argei/ous e(w/ra (sc. a)posta/ntas).

h(gemo/nes ga/r—the likelihood that the view expressed is correct is shown by an example from previous events. This is the argument known as to\ ei)ko/s supported by paradei/gmata. There is another instance in c. 79, 1.

e(ko/ntwn tw=n te *)iw/nwn—cf. I. 95 e)n th=|de th=| h(gemoni/a| h)/dh biai/ou o)/ntos (sc. Pausanias) . . ou)x h)/kista oi( *)/iwnes . . foitw=ntes pro\s tou\s *)aqhnai/ous h)ci/oun au)tou\s h(gemo/nas sfw=n gene/sqai. Herod. VIII. 3 a)pei/lonto th
 h(gemoni)an tou\s *lakedaimoni/ous. Ath. Pol. c. 23 e)pi\ th
 a)po/stasin th
 tw=n *)iw/nwn a)po\ th=s tw=n *lakedaimoni/wn summaxi/as *)aristei/dhs h)=n o( protre/yas. This was in 478-477 B.C. a)po\ sfw=n—tw=n *)aqhnai/wn, i.e. o(/soi a)/poikoi au)tw=n h)=san (Schol.). Poppo quotes I. 12 *)/iwnas *)aqhnai=oi kai\ nhsiwtw=n tou\s pollou\s w)/|kisan (Ionia and the Cyclades).
w(s e)pi\ tou= *m. timwri/a|—this was the primary object of the new confederacy.
tou\s me/n—depends on katestre/yanto. lipostrati/an is obj. to e)penegko/ntes. Plut. Cim. c. 11 of the allies, a)/ndras kai\ nau=s w(s e)ta/xqhsan ou) parei=xon.
e)p) a)llh/lous strateu/ein—sc. e)penegko/ntes: others were charged with making war on one another. This occurred in the case of Samos and Miletus (I. 115).
toi=s de/—governed by e)penegko/ntes, in accordance with custom where a common object of a partic. and verb is near the partic. Cf. c. 77, 2.
ei)=xon—sc. e)penegkei=n. Cf. I. 99 ai)ti/ai a)/llai te h)=san tw=n a)posta/sewn kai\ me/gistai ai( tw=n fo/rwn kai\ new=n e)/kdeiai.
katestre/yanto—cf. Ath. Pol. c. 24 labo/ntes th\n a)rxh\n toi=s summa/xois despotikwte/rws e)xrw=nto.

kai\ ou) peri\ ktl — ‘so, it seems (a)/ra ironical), Athens was not contending for the freedom of Greece nor Greece for her own when they resisted the Persians: Athens resisted them in order to substitute dependence on herself for dependence on them; Greece resisted to secure a change to a new master, who had not less sense, but made a worse use of his cleverness’; i.e., as Freeman says, ‘the other Gks. had simply exchanged the Mede for a master of greater understand
ing, but of understanding used only for mischief,’ as they found afterwaids.
oi( d' e)pi/—strictly this should be oi( de\ d. metabolh=s, still depending on peri\ de/.
despo/tou m.—cf. c. 18, 7 n. The artificiality of this passage is censured by Dion. Hal.

e)/xontes paradei/gmata—the ‘examples’ are of two kinds: there aie (1) the experience of the subjects of Athens; (2) the repetition of the deception. Both of these demonstrate the folly of not combining. Hence tw=n te e)kei= *(e. is answered by kai\ . . sofi/smata, in apposition to paradei/gmata. Then katoiki/seis and e)pikouri/as are the explanation of sofi/smata— ‘tricks such as the restoration of L.,’ etc.
custrafe/ntes—‘combining’; cf. Demosth. 9, 60 sustrafe)ntes a)/nqrwpoi polloi/.
ou)k *)/iwnes ta/de—‘here are no Iouians.’ ta/de ‘usitatum ubi dicere volunt: haec quae hic vides circum te jacentia’ (Goller). ei/si/n is constructed to suit the complement.

*)/iwnes . . *(ellhspo/ntioi . . nhsiw=tai—three of the districts into which the citics of the Athenian Empire were grouped. Cf. I. 89 oi( *)aqhnai=oi kai\ oi( a)po\ *)iwni/as kai\ *(ellhs po/ntou cu/mmaxoi. For the nhsiw=tai see c. 76, 3.
ai)ei\ metaba/llontes—‘with occasional changes.’ The middle is usual. So Thuc. has metaxeiri/zein for metaxeiri/zesqai, peira=n = peira=sqai, proie/nai = proi/esqai.
doulou=ntai—‘are dependent upon.’
*dwrih=s—they affected to despise the Ionians.
*sikeli/an—Freeman points out that Sicily is here dealt with as h)/peiros (cf. on c. 1, 2), and is contrasted with nhsiw=tai.
h)\ me/nomen—‘what, are we waiting?’ So in colloquial Latin quid ago? is more lively than quid agam?
ei)=dos—the ‘method’ that is explained in what follows.
h(mw=n—depends on tou\s me/n.
cumma/xwn e)lpi/di—‘hy the hope of obtaining allies’—i.e. alliance with the Athenians is the temptation offered.
e)kpolemou=n pro\s a)llh/lous—cf. c. 91, 6 ta\ e)nqa/de xrh\ . . e)kpolemou=n ‘stir up to war.’

toi=s de\ ktl—this depends on le/gontes, being attracted to the dat. by e(ka/stois. Hence the sentence = toi=s de\ w(s e(ka/stois . . le/gontes du/nantai (kakourgei=n), kakourgei=n (au)tou/s), ‘and to injure others in any way they can while using smooth words suited to the case.’ Hermocrates detects three designs on the
part of the A.: (1) to sow dissension by reviving the differences that had been suppressed in the treaty of Gela 424 B.C.; (2) to invite the cities to join Athens against the Dorian states; (3) most insidious of all, to speak fair and play foul. Two examples of the last had occurred already: (a) the entrance into Catana, e. 51; (b) the false message from Catana to Syracnse, c. 64. For
proshne/s see Index s. v.

kai\oi)o/meqa ktl—‘and while our countryman at a distance is perishing do we imagine that the danger will not extend to every one of us?’ The distant countryman is Syracuse; the subject of oi)o/meqa still the Siceliots at large (§ 1 h(ma=s au)tou/s). proapollume/nou is temporal, coincident in time with oi)o/meqa.

ou) kai\ e)s au)to/n tina—this is the inclusive use of tis often found close to a plur., as in VII. 39 o(/sa tis e)/xei, pa/ntas a)nagka/sai pwlei=n. For h(/kein e)s ‘penetrate to’ cf. II. 48 kai\ e)s th
 a)/nw po/lin a)fi/keto (h( no/sos), and for the opinion, I. 120 ka)
 me/xri sfw=n to\ deino
 proelqei=n.

pro\ de\ au)tou= ktl—this stands for ma=llon de\ to\n pro\ au)tou= pa/sxonta kaq) au(to\n d., ‘but rather that he who suffers before one confines the trouble to himself,’ i.e. isolates it, prevents it from spreading. For the order, which is due to the emphasis laid on pro\ au)tou=, cf. II. 7 e)c *)itali/as toi=s e(lome)nois for toi=s e)c *)i. e(.
kai\ ei)/ tw| a)/ra—‘now if by chance it has occurred to any one.’ The sing. is used throughout this section where the plur. would be commoner.

e(auto\n de/—for the accus. in a contrast where the subject is the same as that of the main verb, cf. Andoc. i. 64 ei)=pon au)toi=s . . ou)k e)me\ deino\n ei)=nai, a)lla\ ma=llon au)to\ to\ e)/rgon: ib. 113 u(p) au)toi=n me fhmi\ sesw=sqai.
u(pe/r ge . . peri\ th=s e)mh=s—this variation of u(pe/r and peri/ is very common.
e)n i)/sw|—‘equally’; so e)n o)moi/w|.
th=s e(autou=—sc. peri/.
e)rh=mos—the opposite of cu/mmaxon e)/xwn.

to/n te *)aqhnai=on ktl—‘let him reflect too that the A. do not wish to punish Syr. for her hostility so much as to use nic as a pretext in order to confirm her friendship with him.’ Poppo (see crit. note) objected to this rendering on the ground that there is nothing in the design th
 e)kei/nou fili/an bebaiw/sasqai to cause Camarina (to
 deino
 h(gou/menon u(pe tw=n *surakousw=n kinduneu/ein) to suspect Athens. But (1) three courses that are open to Camarina are dealt with here: (a) alliance with Syracuse (kai\ th=s e(autou= . . a)gwniei=tai); (b) friendship,
i.e. alliance with Athens (to/n te *)a. . . bou/lesqai); (c) neutrality (all of § 2). What (b) entails, in the speaker's opinion, has been clearly explained in c. 76, 3. (2) Euphemus in reply repeatedly refers to this fili/a and what it entails in the opinion of Athens; c. 83, 4 ta\ e)nqa/de h(/komen meta\ tw=n fi/lwn a)sfalw=s katasthso/menoi, c. 84, 3 (cu/mforoi) ta\ e)nqa/de . . oi( fi/loi . . au)tonomou/menoi, and c. 85, 1 throughout. (I do not see that there is irony here in fili/an, as some edd. say.) th=| d' e)mh=| profa/sei—th=| profa/sei th=s e)mh=s e)/xqras.
ou)x h(=sson = ma=llon.
a)mfo/tera—sc. fqo/non kai\ fo/bon which are meant by au)ta/ below.

ta\ mei/zw—‘greatness.’ The argument is well put by Freeman: ‘It was vain to say that it was the interest of any other cities that Syr. should be, not destioyed, but so far weakened as no longer to be dangerous to her neighbours. That was not the way in which human affails could be managed; none of them conld undertake that Syr. should lose just as much strength as suited him, and no more.’ swfronisqw=men—tapeinwqw=men (Schol.).
ou)k a)nqrwpi/nhs ktl—‘his desire is a wish that it is beyond the power of man to realise.’ bou/lhsin is internal accus.

ou) ga\r oi(=o/n te ktl—‘it is not possible for one and the same man to be at once arbiter of his wishes and of fortune alike’ —i.e., as Bloomfield explains, a man cannot regulate his own wishes and at the same time the event of the actions resulting from those wishes. ‘You may,’ says H., ‘prefer to remain neutral in the hope that we may suffer a moderate blow: but how are you to regulate the sevcrity of the blow? Your design will perhaps be frustrated by tu/xh, which crosses the purpose of man.’ With tami/an gene/sqai cf. tamieu/esqai, c. 18, 3.

ei) gnw/mh| a(ma/rtoi—gnw/mh, as often, is contrasted with tu/xh. What if Syr. should be destroyed as the result of your neutrality? gnw/mhs a(marta/nein is also found, as in I. 33. So gnw/mhs and gnw/mh| sfalh=nai.

o)lofurqei/s—the rendering of this as middle, ‘having come to sorrow through his own troubles’ (Schol.), is open to the objection that the middle form is used elsewhere by Thuc., as by other authors. Henee Classen and Stahl, following Elmsley, render ‘brought into a lamentable condition through his troubles.’ II. 46 has a(polofura/menoi, VII. 30 o)lofura/sqai. But the form w)lofu/rqhn occurs nowhere else, so that it is impossible to settle the qnestion, and the evidence of the Schol. e)pi\ tai=s i)di/ais sumforai=s o)lofuro/menos is all that we have.

ta/x) a)\n i)/sws—cf. c. 10, 4; 34, 2. The tendency to redundancy in the use of adverbs is noticeable both in Gk. and Lat.—e.g. unde domo, po/qen oi)ko/qen, au)tou= e)kei=. In Lat. comedy it is very common.

kai\ toi=s e)moi=s a)gaqoi=s—i.e. he may wish that Syr. still had power to defend him in his trouble, may have reason to regret that she has no longer prosperity for him to envy. ‘In ta/x) a)\n i)/sws . . fqonh=s ai we have a refined turn occasionally resorted to by thetoricians, of which the purpose is to set forth the value of anything present by adverting to its absence or loss’ (Bloomfield).

a)du/naton de\ ktl—sc. toi=s e)moi=s a)gaqoi=s au)=qis fqonh=sai. The speaker employs the argnment from to\ du/naton: cf. Intr. p. xlviii. and Index under fines. ‘That is impossible if he abandons us and refuses to take his share of the common dangers, in which are involved not allegations but realities.’

ou) peri\ tw=n o)noma/twn . . e)/rgwn—this depends on kindu/nous, and ki/ndunos peri\ tw=n o)noma/twn = a danger in which are concerned the phrases (that will be used); as we say ‘to fight for a name.’ The o)no/mata which they would not be fighting for, but which would naturally be used, are instanced in h( tw=n *surakousw=n du/namis: the e)/rga for which they would be fighting are instanced in h( au(tw=n swthri/a. Hence the whole = tou\s au)tou\s kindu/nous ou) peri\ th=s h(mete/ras duna/mews a)lla\ peri\ th=s e(autw=n swthri/as. Cf. II. 42 mh\ peri\ i)/sou h(mi=n ei)=nai to\n a)gw=na. u(pe/r and e(/neka are also used with such words. The use of the plur. o)noma/twn . . e)/rgwn is rhetorical, and is a very common device of language, being found even with proper names.
lo/gw| me\n ga\r ktl—this explains ou) peri\ . . e)/rgwn.
ta\ deu/tera kinduneu/s ontas = to\n deu/teron ki/ndunon k.: cf. c. 57, 3.
au)ta/—‘the facts’; cf. c. 40, 2.
cummaxei=n—see note on c. 75, 3.
au)tou/s—‘of your own accord.’ In
