a(/per ktl the order is fai/nesqai parakeleuome/nous tau=ta a(/per deo/menoi a)\n e)pikalei=sqe, ‘you ought to be openly encouraging us, so that we may not give way, exactly as you would have appealed to us and called for our help.’ tau=ta is obj. of parakeleuome/nous, a(/per of deo/menoi.
e)pekalei=sqe—‘to call to one's aid,’ as often.
e)k tou= o(moi)ou = o(moi)ws, adverbial phrases with e)k being very common in Thue.—as e)k tou= profanou=s, tou= fanerou=, tou= eu)qe/os, tou= ei)ko/tos, tou= eu)prepou=s, tou= dikai/ou, etc.

o(/pws mhde\n e)ndw/somen—this explains a(/per and tau=ta, and
the construction is on the analogy of that which follows verbs of precaution, o(rw=, e)pimelou=mai, etc. The note in Jowett says that ‘there is a slight flaw in the double reference of the words, which apply better to the actual than to the supposed case.’ But in the supposed case—that Athens had attacked Camarina instead of Syracuse—it would still have been in point for Camarina, while calling in the aid of Syr., to urge her not to give way before Athens, viz. for the sake of the other Siceliot cities. To refrain from supporting Camarina would have been a surrender to Athens. There is, in fact, only a different nuance in the meaning of e)ndw/somen as applied to the two cases. Precisely the same happens in VII. 61, where the one word patri/dos is applied to the Athenians and Syracusans with a different implication.

deili/a| de\ ktl—‘perhaps from cowardice you will regard your duty in relation to us and to the invaders by saying.’ Stahl and Fr. Muller think to\ di/kaion is ironical, since the plea of cummaxi/a with Athens would not be justice to Syr. But Meyer points out that it would be just to both sides for Camarina to nrge ‘we have a cummaxi/a with Athens, and only spondai/ with Syr.’ See n. on c. 75, 3. The speaker contemplates Camarina supporting Athens on this ground of duty.
h(/n ge—restrictive: ‘you only entered into it.’
e)pi\ toi=s fi/lois = kata\ tw=n f.: cf. c. 61, 1.

tw=n de\ e)xqrw=n h)/n tis—‘but in case an enemy,’ the order being due to the antithesis. toi=s ge *)a.—ge restrictive; bohqei=n of purpose: ‘to help the A. only when.’ The order is again modified to bring toi=s *)a. into contrast with toi=s fi/lois: otherwise o(/tan ge u(p) a)/llwn a)dikw=ntai bohqei=n toi=s *)a.
o(/tan u(f) a)/llwn—sc. a)dikw=ntai from the a)dikw=sin following. Bauer compares II. 11 th\n tw=n pe/las dh|ou=n ma=llon h)\ th\n e(autw=n o(ra=n, sc. dh|oume/nhn.
*(rhgi=noi—see c. 44, 3.

kai\ deino
 ei) e)kei=noi me
 . . u(mei=s de/—the two inconsistent thoughts are frequently so placed after deino/n, ai(sxro/n, deino
 a)
 ei)/h, deino
 a)/n moi dokei= ei)=nai, etc. The tense and mood are not necessarily the same in the two clauses as they are here —swfronou=sin . . bou/lesqe—and when a neg. is required either ou) or mh/ can be used in the ei) clauses. (Cf. Shilleto on I. 121; Gentsch in Com. Phil. Jcn. iv. p. 299.) The former clause must be made subordinate with ‘whereas.’

to\ e)/rgon tou= kalou= d. u(popteu/ontes—‘suspecting the
real meaning of the specious claim’ to their help on the ground of kinship. kalou= is ironical. dikai/wma is a claim just in the eyes of those who put it forward, dikai/wsis the act of putting it forward. Cf. e)pith/deuma, e)pith/deusis: a)ci/wma, a)ci/wsis.
a)lo/gws—‘without reasonable cause,’ ‘show an unreasonable prudence,’ because abstract reason would require that as kinsmen they should help the Athemans.
eu)lo/gw| profa/sei—‘urging a logical pretext,’ viz. that you have a cummaxi/a with Athens. eu)lo/gw|, like a)lo/gws, is ironical, the contrast throughout being between logic and prudence.
fu/sei polemi/ous—they are only lo/gw| or cummaxi/a| fi/loi.
e)/ti ma=llon—becanse besides being Dorians they were also close neighbours.
a)ll) ou) di/kaion—sc. diafqei=rai ktl. Notice the commonplace argument from to\ di/kaion.
a)mu/nein de/—sc. di/kaion toi=s fu/sei cuggene/si.
o(/per ou(=toi\ s—cf. c. 10, 4.
ta/nanti/a is adverbial.
pro\s h(ma=s mo/nous—alluding to the previous battle, c. 65 ff.
a(qro/ous—sc. h(ma=s, both Syr. and Camarina, which are also meant in i)e/nai e)s th\n cummaxi/an.
i)e/nai de\ e)s th\n c—this describes entering into a ncw relation (cf. v. 30, 5); it shows that the spondai/ are to be changed into a cummaxi/a.

proqumo/teron—this applies strictly only to Camarina (cf. c. 67, 2); but it is quite necdless to assume a change of subject between a)qumei=n and i)e)nai as some edd. do, explaining a)qumei=n sc. h)ma=s, i)e/nai sc. u(ma=s.
oi)/—the plur. after a)po\ *peloponnh/sou: cf. cc. 32, 2; 35, 1; 94, 1.
ta\ pole/mia = ta\ polemika/, an Ionie use.

e)kei/nhn th\n promhqi/an ktl—sc. ei)ko/s: ‘nor should any one think that that caution which consists in refusing to help either side, on the ground that you are allies of both sides, is alike fair to us and safe for you.’ (Why many edd. say that e)kei/nhn th\n promhqi/an = ‘that boasted prudence of yours’ is not clear. The speaker deals with the third plan that Camarina may adopt. In c. 78, 4 he developed the first coursc which C. ought to have adopted already—ei)ko\s h)=n u(ma=s ktl. In c. 79 he deals with the second course—a resolution to help Athens. In c. 80 he discusses the third course—neutrality.)
dh/—explanatory. (Many explain this, after Bauer, as ironical.)
ou) ga\r e)/rgw| i)/son—‘this course is not in reality fair. as the plea of justice represents it.’

di) u(ma=s mh\ cummaxh/santas—for this construction see on c. 3, 3. It is amusing to notice how the inaccurate use of the word cummaxi/a in this speech—see on c. 75, 3 n.—leads to a confusion here between cumma/xous, used in the loose sense above to include spondai/, and cummaxh/santas, used in the strict sense here. mh\ cummaxh/santas (mhdete/rois) is here substituted for mhdete/rois bohqh/santas.
o(/ te paqw/n = the Syracusans. The aor. has the force of the fut. perf., = qui victus fuerit (Baner).

ou)k h)mu/nate . . ou)k e)kwlu/sate—the aor. is here substituted for the fut. for the sake of bringing the inevitable result vividly before the hearers. M.T. § 61. The speaker looks forward to the time when the defeat has actually taken place. Cf. St. James Epistle c. v. e)qhsauri/sate e)n e)sxa/tais h(me/rais, with Mayor's note. For the perf. so used see II. 8, 4.
swqh=nai—inf. of purpose, in which the use of the pass. is somewhat rare.
kai/toi—‘and surely,’ resuming the main thought that the right course is to aid Syr.
ka/llion—than neutrality, with its consequences. Observe the argument from to\ kalo/n.

th
 koinh
 w)feli/an—‘the common welfare,’ = th
 e)leuqeri/an tw=n *sikeliwtw=n (Schol.).
fi/lous dh/—ironical, ‘your good friends.’
ou)de\n e)/rgon—‘no need,’ used also with a genitive.
deo/meqa de/—answering e)kdida/skein me/n, ‘we entreat you’ to act on your knowledge, that being more to the purpose than e)kdida/skein.

kai\ marturo/meqa a(/ma . . o(/ti—‘we solemnly declare, if we fail to persuade you (by our speech), that while the Ionians our inveterate enemies are plotting against us, you our fellow Dorians are betraying us.’

ei) mh\ pei/somen—it is difficult to say whether this is protasis to marturo/meqa or to e/pibouleuo/meqa me\n . . prodido/meqa de/. (1) We might understand prodido/meqa u(po\ u(mw=n ei) mh\ pei/somen, the pres. being used—as esp. often with di/dwmi and gi/gnomai and compounds—for an action only beginning. (The clause e)pibouleuo/meqa me/n is in sense subordinate to prodido/meqa de/.) (2) But it is better to understand marturo/meqa ei) mh\ pei/somen. For the syntax cf. Lysias 24, 13 ei) tou=to pei/sei, ti\ me kwlu/ei klhrou=sqai; (where Frohberger reads kwlu/sei, as Hude pei/qomen
here), and esp. Andoc. 3, 21 ei)/ tis u(mw=n a)xqesqh/setai, paraitou=mai, where the pres. is exactly parallel to marturo/meqa.

kai\ ei) katastre/yontai—Classen thinks that the whole section depends still on marturo/meqa. But Stahl is probably right in regarding the sentence as a transition to the O.R. Thus krath/sousi is parallel to marturo/meqa, and we have to supply ei) mh\ pei)somen. ‘(If we fail to persuade you, then,) in case they conquer us, their victory will be due to your decision’ (gnw/mais, like sententiis vestris, the resolution resulting from the votes).
tw=| d' au(tw=n o)—‘the honour will fall to their own name,’ not to yours. For this use of o)/noma cf. VII. 64 to\ me/ga o)/noma tw=n *)aqhnw=n.
timhqh/sontai—rare for timh/sontai. So w)felhqh/s omai is rarer than w)felh/somai.
a)=qlon—‘prize,’ neut., predicate to a)/llon tina/.

th=s ai)ti/as ktl—lit. ‘you will equally pay the penalty of being the cause of our dangers.’ Edd. do not agree on the meaning of these words. (a) Recent edd. follow Portus and take th=s ai)ti/as as the charge for which the penalty will be exacted— i.e. ‘we shall punish you for having caused our dangers.’ (b) Arnold and Bloomfield understand th=s ai)ti/as as defining the timwri/a, ‘you will suffer the penalty of (having been) the cause of our dangers,’ by refusing to help us; and of course that position would be an unpleasant one. According to (a) the woids convey a threat; according to (b), only a hint of unpleasantness.
h)/dh—‘without hesitation.’

th\n au)ti/ka a). doulei/an—Wilkins, following Bauer, renders ‘slavery with its temporary immunity from danger,’ so that au)ti)ka qualifies a)kindu/nws. But the sense is ‘immediate (and certain) dependence which involves no risk,’ in contrast with the hope of avoiding subjection to Athens by facing the risk involved in fighting with Syracuse. ‘If you refuse to join, you escape danger but accept dependence: if you consent, you accept danger but escape dependence.’ Hence both au)ti/ka and a)kindu/nws qualify doulei/a. Cf. I. 22 h( a)/ntikrus e)leuqeri/a, VIII. 64 h( a)/ntikrus e)leuqeri/a, and perhaps stratia\ e)/ti = ‘remforcements,’ though when no art. is present the adv. belongs in some measure to the verb.

doulei/an—opposed to mh\ despo/tas labei=n below. The speaker in this section talks as though only two courses were open— either to join the Athenians (= doulei/a), or to join Syr. He adroitly leaves out the third course—neutrality, which accord
ing to § 4 is out of the question. On doulei/a and despo/tai see c. 77, 1.

h)\ ka)\n ktl—lit. ‘or else (choose) not to submit disgracefully to these men and to avoid our enmity—which would not be small—in which case you would share in our victory.’ I agree with Stahl that ka)/n belongs to perigeno/menoi only, and that labei=n and diafugei=n depend directly on ai(rei=sqe: there is nothing hypothetical about the choice; it is immediate (h)/dh) and fiual, being either doulei/a or mh\ labei=n ti kai\ diafugei=n ti. perigeno/menoi a)/n is in apodosis, implying ei) ai(roi=sqe, perige/noisqe a)/n. Others take a)/n either with the infins. only or with the partic. and the infins. The placing of a)/n before a partic. frequently produces difficulty.
th\n pro\s h(ma=s e)/xqran—‘enmity with us’; cf. fanera\n e)/xqran pro\s *korinqi/ous kth/sasqai I. 42.

mh\ a)/n—with genome/nhn only = h(\ mh\ a)\n braxei=a ge/noito, i.e. the generic or characteristic mh/ piobably. We might, however, say that the passage implies a warning or command; it is solemn and emphatic. Cf. c. 102 nomi/santes mh\ a)\n e)/ti i(kanoi\ gene/sqai. (There is difference of opinion about this mh/. Goodwin (M. T. § 688) views it as an ‘irregularity’; Bohme-Widmann say that ‘mh/ with potential inf. or partic. after verbs of saying and thinking is common’; Fr. Muller says the mh/ is ‘under the influence of the inf. diafugei=n.’ This lends point to Prof. Gildersleeve's remark that ‘to understand ou) and mh/ a certain mobility is necessary.’ A.J.P. July 1892, p. 259.)

braxei=an—probably ‘small,’ a common meaning in Thuc., though some passages are certainly ambiguous. In VII. 14 braxei=a a)kmh\ plhrw/matos, the Schol. and Plutarch understood braxei=a as ‘short-lived,’ whereas modern edd. render ‘the efficient part of a crew is small.’
a)fiko/meqa—our intention when we came was to renew the treaty (see c. 75, 3), but we now find it necessary to defend the imperial policy of Athens.
e)pi\ th=s pro/teron . . a)nanew/sei—cf. c. 33, 1 peri\ tou= e)pi/plou th=s a)lhqei/as. The art. is often omitted with the governing noun.
e)/xomen—sc. au)th/n.
martu/rion—sc. w(s ei)ko/tws a)/rxomen. It is necessary for us, as hereditary enemies of the Dorians, to secure ourselves.

e)/xei de\ kai\ ou(/tws—‘moreover the case stands exactly as follows.’ Classen and others explain this ou(/tws as referring to what precedes, which is further dealt with in what follows. But the de/ forms an antithesis to what precedes. The general
principle, says the speaker, is enough to justify us; but there is besides the following special circumstance. ou(/tws e)/xein often refers to what follows.

*)/iwnes o)/ntes *peloponnhsi/ois—‘being Ionians in the eyes of the P., while they were Dorians and superior in numbers and near neighbours of ours.’ In § 2 he has said oi/ *)/iwnes pole/mioi toi=s *dwrieu=si/n ei)sin. So now, instead of saying pole/mioi o)/ntes *peloponnhsi/ois, he ingeniously says *)/iwnes (=pole/mioi) o)/ntes *peloponnhsi/ois. (The edd. have, I believe, missed the meaning of this sentence. For the alterations of the text see the crit. note. The old explanation, that au)tw=n is a repetition of *peloponnhsi/ois in a different case by anacoluthon, is quite untenable. Herbst believes there is an ellipse of pole/mioi, but I do not see the need of this.) This sentence admirably expresses the contempt of the Dorians for the Ionians (cf. c. 68), who were only fit in their view to be their subjects.
vau=s kthsa/menoi—this refers to the building of a fleet, which was due to the advice of Themistocles, probably in 483. Hence meta\ ta\ *mhdika/ belongs to a)phlla/ghmen rather than to kthsa/menoi.

th=s me\n *lakedaimoni/wn ktl—the speaker has to represent Athens as an upholder of liberty, and yet he cannot say that she strove to get free from a doulei)a, as that word has been used against her. He therefore admits that Sparta, so long as she was superior in power, had justly led the confederacy (h(gemoni)a) and exercised dominion (a)rxh/).
plh\n kaq) o(/son—cf. c. 54, 6.
e)n tw=| paro/nti—‘for the time being.’

oi)kou=men—the edd. explain this as intrans., meaning either ‘live’ (for e)sme/n, dia/gomen) in the position of h(ge/mones, or ‘find ourselves’ in that position. For the conjectures see crit. note. It is much more likely that the verb is trans., sc. ta\ u(po\ b. pro/teron o)/nta= ‘manage their (external) affairs,’ as though he said oi)kou=men ta\ tw=n cumma/xwn, the word being used here metaphorically, like tamieu/esqai and tami/as (cc. 18, 3; 78 2). This forms a good antithesis to a)phlla/ghmen th=s *a. a)rxh=s, and is in keeping with the context. It also contrasts well with e)pita/ssein. See Intr. § 21. <a)sfalw=s> oi)kou=men Stein.
ou(/tws—i.e. oi)kou=ntes tou\s . . o)/ntas.
e)s to\ a)kribe/s—‘accurately.’ Cf. c. 104, 2 n. e)s ta\ ma/lista.
ei)pei=n—absolute: M.T. § 777.
e)f) h(ma=s—‘that is against us.’ The prep. is not often repeated before an apposition.

ou)k e)to/lmhsan ktl—‘conld not bring themselves to revolt (sc. tou= *mh/dou) and sacrifice their property, abandoning their city as we did,’ or ‘whereas we abandoned our city.’ This sort of attraction with ou)x w)/sper is very common (see e g. Shilleto on Thuc. II. 42, Kock on Aristoph. Eq. 784, or DeuschleCron on Plat. Gorg. 522 A). doulei/an de\ . . e)bou/lonto—bou/lomai only here with a subst. as obj.: Bohme-Widmann compare th\n au)th\n du/natai dou/lwsin I. 141. We should also expect e)boulh/qhsan, if the sense is ‘they chose slavery.’ Heibst understands e)negkei=n to e)bou/lonto from e)penegkei=n, but such an ellipse is surely impossible. douleu/ein of the inferior MSS. is very tempting. See crit. note.
to\ au)to/—after the fem. doulei/an, by a common change. With e)penegkei=n supply e)bou/lonto

a)/cioi/ te—this is answered not by kai/ but by a(/ma de/ below; cf. I. 25 kata/ te to\ di/kaion . . a/ma de\ kai\ mi/sei: VII. 81 qa=sso/n te ga\r o( *niki/as h)=ge . . o( de\ *dhmosqe/nhs. Generally where te is not answered by kai/ there are many intervening words, sometimes a parenthesis.
e)s—‘towards,’ the prep being accommodated to proqumi/an: cf. Hyperid. 4, 14, 42 a)ndragaqi/an parasxe/sqai ei)s th\n th=s po/lews e)leuqeri/an, Andoc. 1, 50 proqumo/tatos ei)s se/.
kai\ dio/ti kai/—‘and also because.’
tou=to drw=ntes—sc. nautiko\n kai\ proqumi/an parexo/menoi. It is the regular phrase for referring to an action just described.
tw=| *mh/dw| is accommodated to the construction of the original verb, parexo/menoi, exactly as in II. 49 polloi\ tou=to e)/drasan (i.e. sfa\s au)tou\s e)/rriyan) e)s fre/ata.
ou(=toi—i.e. oi(/ te *)/iwnes kai\ nhsiw=tai.
a(/ma de\ . . o)rego/menoi—having disposed of the right, he now comes to ‘the inducement by which they were to he led to take the dominion, and now hold it—namely, their own security’ (Bloomfield).

ou) kalliepou/meqa—‘we do not use fine words.’ Plat. Apol. p. 17 B contrasts lo/goi kekalliephme/noi with ta\ e)pituxo/nta o)no/mata, and Aristoph. Thesm. 48 applies kallieph/s to the tragic poet Agathon, who, we know, was extremely fond of using the figures of language (sxh/mata le/cews), especially antithesis. As these ‘fignres’ were associated with the name of Gorgias, Euphemus is meant to contrast the plain, even blunt, language in which the Athenian defends his right to rule with the studied subtleties of Sicihan objectors, esp. of
Hermocrates. Then he states two grounds on which Athens does not claim empire over the Ionians and islanders.
mo/noi kaqelo/ntes—this is dealt with at length in I. 73 ff., not that the Athenians claim even there to have overthrown the Persians mo/noi.
tw=nde—Ionians and islanders.

pa=si de\ a)nepi/fqonon—‘no man can be reproached if he provides for his security as circumstances require.’ h( prosh/kousa s. is the safety that suits the character of a man and the circumstances in which he finds himself, and requires different measures at different times. ‘It was swthri/a that obliged us to reduce the Ionians, etc. to subjection: it is swthri/a that brings us here.’ prosh/kousan means something more than de/ousan: it means what suits the character as well as the circumstances.

kai\ nu=n ktl—‘so now it is regard for our safety (a)sfalei)as = swthri/as) that brings us here, and we see that you have just the same interests as we. We base this statement on the calumnies that they utter against us, and which you with excessive anxiety regard with suspicion—in that we know that when men are anxious and suspicious they are pleased for a moment by statements that humour their feelings, but afterwards when they take action they follow their interests.’

e)c w(=n diaba/llousi—i.e. we admit the statement that we reduced the Ionians: that was required by our swthri/a then. But now our swthri/a requires that we help our friends here, and so our interests are identical with yours.
e)pi\ to\ foberw/teron = w)/ste foberw/tera u(mi=n fai/nesqai. Cf. on c. 34, 7 init.

ei)do/tes—causal: we know that it is easy for Syracuse to use the fact that we reduced the Ionians to prejudice and alarm you; but when it comes to taking action you will consider your interests, and will realise that the same motive that led ns to reduce the Ionians leads us now to protect you.
lo/gou me\n h(donh=|—i.e. words skilfully used to encourage suspicion and fear of opponents. Here the argument was that Athens would act in Sicily as she had done in Greece.
th=| d' e)gxeirh/sei—a good example of a quasi-temporal word used without e)n, as th=| e)sbolh=|, th=| ma/xh|, tw=| pole/mw|.

th/n te ga\r ktl—‘we have told you (c. 82, 3) that apprehension causes us to keep our empire in Greece, and (c. 82 a)fiko/meqa . . a)nanew/sei) that the same motive (viz. apprehension that Syracuse may obtain Sicily and then threaten our empire) has brought us to settle matters here,’ etc.
ga/r—explains the reason for grounding the assertion (a)pofai/nomen) of identity of interests on the diabolh/ of the Syracusans.
h(/kein—see crit. note. This without fame/n is not an accurate reference to the statement with which the speech opened. But cummaxi/as a)nane/wsis possibly implies what is here stated.
a)sfalw=s—‘for our safety.’
doulwso/menoi—sc. ta\ e)nqa/de.
u(pola/bh| de\ ktl—‘let no one suppose that care for you is not our concern.’
gnou/s—‘when he reflects.’
sw|zome/nwn—the partic. is parallel to dia\ to\ . . a)nte/xein.
mh\ a)sqenei=s o)/ntas—‘with a strong resistance,’ circumstantial partic. to a)nte/xein.

h(=sson a)\n ktl—‘we should be less likely to suffer by their sending a force to aid the Pel.’; h(=sson a)/n belong both to pemya/ntwn and to blaptoi/meqa. The argument is that it is the interest of Athens to support the independence of Camarina as a rival power to Syracuse. But, as Freeman asks, what would happen if Athens reduced Syr. to subjection? Would it then be to her interest to maintain the independence of her friends in Sicily?
kai\ e)n tou/tw| . . h)/dh—‘and it is just in this that we are closely concerned in your affairs.’
dio/per kai/—‘this is the reason too why it is logical that we should restore the L., not as subjects.’
tou\s cuggenei=s—attracted to the case of u(phko/ous. toi=sde = the Syracusans.
ta\ me\n ga/r—‘in Greece’)(ta\ de\ e)nqa/de below.
kai\ au)toi/—‘even without aid.’
dn ktl—i.e. dn doulw/sasqai kai\ tou\s e)nqa/de e)leuqerou=n a)/logon ei)=nai/ fhsi.
cu/mforos—i.e. to maintain the dominion of Athens, it was needful that the Euboean Chalcis should be unarmed and tributary (Freeman), and should not contribute ships.
kai\ *leonti=noi—sc. cu/mforoi/ ei)sin.

a)ndri\ de\ tura/nnw|—Sicily was intimately acquainted with the ways of despots. Here the frankest description of the Athenian a)rxh/ is given, as by Cleon in III. 37 turanni/da e)/xete th\n a)rxh/n. 2

ou)de\n a)/logon o(/ ti cumfe/ron—this statement could not be made by a modern imperial power, but it is none the less the
principle on which under diplomatic disguises modern states frequently act.
ou)d' oi)kei=on—‘there is no tie of blood unless there is eonfidence.’ The Chalcidians of Euboea are kinsmen of Athens, but they are distrusted.
pro\s e(/kasta ktl—‘in each case a hostile or friendly attitude must accord with circumstances.’

kai\ h)ma=s—applying the previous doctrine to the present case. ‘Now in our case our interest here is furthered, not by injuring our friends, but if we reduce our enemies to impotence through the strength of our friends.’
tou=to applies to what follows.

a)pistei=n—referring back to pisto/n above. ‘You must not distrust us,’ and we will then trust you, and those that we trust we treat as friends. tou\s e)kei= cumma/xous—e)chgou=mai takes either accus. or dat., but the sudden change from dat. (see crit, note) to accus. (*xi/ous) is scarcely probable. au)tono/mous <e)/xontes> Stein.
*mhqumnai/ous—the only Lesbians who retained their autonomy after Lesbos revolted from Athens in 428.
new=n parokwxh=|—in VII. 57 the Chians are described as ou)x u(potelei=s fo/rou, nau=s de\ pare/xontes, and the Methymnaeans in the same way.
biaio/teron—sc. e)chgou/meqa. Cf. I. 141 ai( bi/aioi e)sforai).
e)leuqe/rws cummaxou=ntas—those who in VII. 57 are called oi( a)po\ cummaxi/as au)to/nomoi, like Corcyra, Zaeynthus, Cephallenia.
pro\s to\ lusitelou=n—‘in accordance with our interest and with the fear of Syr. of which we speak’ (c. 83, 4). With de/os e)s *surakosi/ous cf. Eur. Her. Fur. 66 e)/rwti sw/mat ei)s eu)dai/mona.
u(mw=n—referring to all the Sicilian cities, as opposed to Syr.
e)pi\ tw=| h(. u(po/ptw|—‘on the ground of the suspicion we excite.’
custh/santes=cumma/xous poih/santes, as in c. 16, 6.

bi/a| h)\ kai\ kat' e)rhmi/an—with a)/rcai, ‘to acquire empire for themselves over Sicily by force or else through mere lack of resistance.’ Jowett renders ‘first they must unite you in a common suspicion of us, and then, either by force or through your isolation when we have failed and retired, they will dominate Sicily.’ But (1) bi/a| refers not to a)pra/ktwn h(mw=n a)pelqo/ntwn, but to e)pi\ tw=| h(. custh/santes u(po/ptw|: they want to unite your forces with their own, only that they may force themselves into the position of head of a Sicilian alliance,
which they will turn into empire. (2) Only h)\ kai\ kat' e)rhmi/an refers to a)pra/ktwn h(mw=n a)pelqo/ntwn. If they fail to seeure empire while we are still in Sicily, nevertheless they will secure it when we are no longer here to resist them. (3) That this is so is shown by ou)/te ga\r ktl., where the i)sxu\s tosau/th refers to the means by which Syr. would assure herself of empire bi/a|, and h\mw=n mh\ paro/ntwn means that Syr. would turn against the Siceliots when the Athenians were gone, and would acquire empire kat' e)rhmi/an, through laek of resistance. Thus (4) there is no reference to a struggle with the Siceliots in bi/a|, but only to the struggle between a Sicilian confederation and Athens, in the course of whieh Syr. might assure herself of empire.
kat' e)rhmi/an—se. tw=n kwluso/ntwn (Stahl).

a)na/gkh de/—sc. au)tou\s a)/rcai th=s *sikeli/as. (H. Kleist points out that this ehapter is an example of the e)pixei/rhma, or conclusion based on a major and a minor premiss: (a) major premiss —propositio—a)ndri\ de\ tura/nnw| . . gi/gnesqai: (b) minor premiss —assumptio—kai\ h(ma=s tou=to w)felei=. This is supported by a proof—assumptionis probatio—in a)pistei=n de\ . . *peloponnhsi/ois: (c) conclusion—complexio—w)/ste kai\ ta)nqa/de . . kaqi/stasqai. The e)pixei/rhma differs from the syllogism essentially in that neither of the premisses need be true.)
to\ e)/rgon—i.e. the fact mentioned immediately afterwards.
to\ ga\r pro/teron—in 427.

prosei/ontes fo/bon—the metaphor is from shaking swords or spears at an enemy to alarm him (Bloomfield). Cf. Eur. Her. Fur. 1189 ti/ moi prosei/wn xei=ra shmai/neis fo/bon; and V. 17 h)/dh paraskeuh/ te proepanesei/sqh a)po\ tw=n *lakedaimoni/wn. (The other meaning of prosei/ein, ‘to entice animals’ with food, is not in keeping with the present passage)

mei/zoni pro\s th\n tw=nde i)sxu/n—most edd. render ‘with a force larger (than necessary) in comparison with the strength of S.’ But in the note in Jowett it is pointed out that the speaker's objeet is to minimise the power of Athens in Sieily. Henee mei/zoni=‘greater’ than before, viz. in 427, and pro/s=‘with a view to,’ ‘so as to cope with.’
u(popteu/esqai—sc. h(ma=s. a)pistei=n—sc. u(ma=s.
h(mei=s me/n ge—‘we at least’ are powerless in any case to keep possession of Sieily, or even to obtain a footing in it without your aid.
ou)/te is answered by te. mh\ meq) u(mw=n=a)/neu u(mw=n.
katergasai/meqa—sc. u(ma=s. This is an answer to the argument of cc. 76, 77.
a)pori/a| fulakh=s po/lewn ktl—‘through the difficulty of garrisoning large eities that possess the forces of a continental power’—i.e. cavalry and infantry as opposed to a fleet.
ou) stratope/dw|—sc. w(/sper h(mei=s.
th=s h(mete/ras parousi/as—‘than the force we have here.’
e)poikou=ntes—the proximity of Syr. is as bad as a permanent hostile settlement.
kairo\n . . e(ka/stou—‘an opportunity for any particular attempt.’ e(ka/stou is best taken as nent., and not as masc., ‘an opportunity for attacking each of you.’
a)/lla—internal accns., ‘in other cases.’

tolmw=sin ktl—‘they have the boldness to ask for your aid against the men who try to prevent this and hitherto have saved Sicily from falling into their power—as though you were blind’ and could not see through their design. From Athens really proceeds the opposition (kwlu/ontas) that saves Sicily from being subject to Syracuse.
th\n u(pa/rxousan ktl—‘the safety that we and you alike gain from each other.’ a)mfote/rois belongs to u(pa/rxousan. ‘Nous ne pouvons sauver les uns sans les autres’ (Tanaquil Faber).
parasxh/sein—impersonal, commonest in the form parasxo/n: an Ionic use of pare/xei.
tw=| u(po/ptw|—‘through suspicion.’ e)/ti boulh/sesqe—e)/ti is often so used in threats and prophecies.
o(/te—‘at a time when.’ o(/te is the regular particle for introducing a reference to a date.
a)lla/—w(/ste, ou)=n, and a)lla/ are the commonest particles for introducing a new division of a speech.
e)n kefalai/ois—such a recapitulation is especially appropriate to the peroration.
u(p' au)tw=n blaptw/meqa—for the result of their joining Syr. see c. 84, 1.

polla\ d' a)nagka/zesqai—‘the expression here, polla\ pra/ssein, is susceptible of both a bad and a good sense: and such is its use in Eur. Sup. 576, where the Theban herald says to Theseus pra/ssein su\ po/ll' ei)/wqas h(/ te sh\ po/lis, and Theseus replies toi/gar ponou=sa polla\ po/ll) eu)daimonei=’ (Bloomfield). polupragmosu/nh was characteristic of Athenians and was thought a reproach to them. In II. 40 Pericles says that at
Athens o( a)pra/gmwn, the man who held aloof from public affairs, was thought a)xrei=os—of no use to the state.
polla\ fulasso/meqa—‘we have to guard against many dangers.’

ou)k a)/klhtoi, paraklhqe/ntes de/—Bloomfield quotes Aesch. Choeph. 825 h(/kw me\n ou)k a)/klhtos, a)ll' u(pa/ggelos. The figure is a common one. Cf. Lys. 13, 19 a)/konta . . kai\ mh\ e(ko/nta mhnu/ein.

d xalepo/n—refers to a)potre/pein, which does not mean, as is usually thought, ‘to divert us from our scheme’ or enterprise, but ‘to divert us from our fixed, settled course of action’—i.e. tw=n h(mi=n poioume/nwn, as in c. 38, 4 a)potre/pein th=s kakourgi/as. See below on tro/pou. We are not submitting our general conduct to your judgment, but are claiming your votes in this particular case. In dikastai/ and swfronistai/ there is a reference to the coming division, which Hermocrates wished to make a vote of censure on Athenian poliey and charaeter. As for the construetion ta\ h(mi=n poiou/mena, Thuc. by no means confines the dat. of the agent to perf. pass.: he is as free as the poets in the matter. In the orators any other tenses than perf. very rarely has the dat. See on c. 1, 2.

th=s h(. polupragmosu/nhs kai\ tro/pou—depending on ti. ‘as far as any phase of our intermeddling, or rather our character, is of service to you as to us (u(mi=n . . to\ au)to/, lit. ‘to you in the same way’), avail yourselves of that phase, to the exclusion of the rest.’ The ti refers to the intervention in Sieily, which Camarina may turn to aceount. polupragmosu/nhs refers to polla\ pra/ssein above.

kai\ tro/pou—sc. tou= h(mete/rou. It refers to the personal characteristics of a people, and the mention of it here is to show that it may be substituted for polupragmosu/nh, so that kai/ =immo. There is also a reference baek to a)potre/pein (tw=n poioume/nwn) above, which is thus a)potre/pein tou= tro/pou. The tro/poi of the Athenians are fully dealt with by Pericles in the Funeral Oration. tou/tw| a)polabo/ntes xrh/sasqe—tou=to would be the more ordinary construction; see c 46, 3, but cf. VIII. 87 o)/pws mhdete/rous prosqe/menos i)sxurota/tous poih/sh|. The partic. in such cases may be regarded as absolute.
au)ta/—se. th\n polupragmosu/nhn kai\ tro/pon, subject of bla/ptein.

e)n panti\ ga\r ktl—‘in every place, even where we are not at hand, the man who thinks that he will suffer wrong and he who plots mischief—because they have a lively expecta
tion, the one of obtaining from us a return in the form of help, the other that if we come he will be in danger of suffering for his wrong—are both alike compelled, the one to restram himself against his will, the other to accept safety without taking action.’ In this extremely difficult passage the speaker explains the effect of Athenian prestige—that prestige which arises from her polupragmosu/nh. It is a guarantee of tranquillity in states in which Athens has no footing. And how? Because the certainty of her intervention on behalf of the oppressed prevents attempts at oppression. This theory is similar to the modern theory that great armaments are a guarantee of peace.
e)n panti\ ga\r pa=s—traductio; see c. 11, 2 n.
u(pei=nai—i.e. present in his mind.

e)lpi/da—hope as applied to the one, fear as applied to the other. a)ntituxei=n—a)nti-, as a return for joining our alliance, for frankly accepting our interference. (This is better than Haack's explanation, adopted by Stahl, that a)nti- =‘in redress of the wrong,’ because it is more in accordance with the advice that is being given to Camarina xrh/sasqai th=| polupragmosu/nh|.)

mh\ a)deei= ei)=nai kinduneu/ein—on the reading see crit. note. (a) kinduneu/ein depending on mh\ a)deei=. Stahl rightly objects to Classen's rendering ‘that he will have to fear a conflict with us,’ on the ground that the inf. kinduneu/ein is most unusual in the sense mh\ kinduneu/h|, and that a)deh/s does not mean ‘liable to fear’ but actually ‘afraid.’ Others render ‘that they will not be without fear of danger’; but Stahl says this puts the point very feebly: not the chance that they may be in danger, but only the certainty of danger if the Athenians intervene, would deter men from plotting; kinduneu/ein greatly weakens the passage. (b) mh\ a)deei= ei)=nai depending on kindun eu/ein. Then the rendering given by edd. is ‘will be likely to have reason for fear.’ But (1) nowhere else in Thuc. does kinduneu/ein=‘to be likely’; (2) the sense given to a)deh/s is weak. It remains to give to a)deh/s its legal meaning, ‘exempt from punishment,’ ‘privileged, though guilty,’ for which see c. 27, 2. This suits a)dikh/sesqai and e)pibouleu/ein, and gives a forcible meaning to the passage. See Intr. § 23.

a)nagka/zontai—both parties are compelled to abstain from action; and thus to the stronger comes swfrosu/nh, and to the weaker swthri/a. There is a certain humour in applying a)nagka)zontai to the side that obtains swthri/a. The force in both cases is moral.
o( me/n—corresponding to o( e)pibouleu/wn, o( de/ to o( oi)o/menos a)dikh/s esqai, by chiasmus.
a)pragmo/nws—a verbal reference back to Athenian polupragmosu/nh, which means a)pragmosu/nh for others.
tau/thn ou)=n ktl—‘do not reject the gift of safety open without exception to any who ask it and to yourselves.’

e)cisw/santes—sc. tau/thn th\n a)sfa)leian th\n u(mi=n parou=san: while toi=s a)/llois is a brachylogy for th=| tw=n a)/llwn. Hence lit. ‘making this safety that is open to you equal to that of the rest,’ i.e. ‘availing yourselves of this gift as others do.’ In toi=s a)/llois he alludes especially to Segesta and Leontini. (All edd. previous to Stahl explain e)cisw/santes as intrans.; but there is no need for this, and the passages cited in its support are very doubtful parallels. Stahl, however, takes toi=s a)/llois with a)ntepibouleu=sai, and brackets toi=s *surakosi/ois as a gloss upon toi=s a)/llois.) Stein reads deome/nw| <a)ei\> above.

kai\ a)ntepibouleu=sai/ pote—‘at length change your plan and resolve to plot against the S. likewise in return.’ e)k tou= o(moi/ou, ‘as they plot against you.’ a)ntepibouleu=sai is object of (meta)la)bete, and toi=s *s. of a)ntepibouleu=sai.
e)pepo/nqesan—‘the feeling was as follows,’ already before the speeches.
plh\n kaq( o(/son—‘except in so far as.’ Classen defends ei) after kaq' o(/son, but subsequent edd. rightly reject it.
kata\ to\ o(/moron dia/foroi—‘border enemies’ (Freeman).
tou\s o)li/gous i(ppe/as—see c. 67, 2.
kai\ to\ loipo/n—the policy adopted is to continue to render slight help to Syr., but to answer that they were neutral.
ma=llon—lather than the Athenians.
e)/rgw|—contrasts the actual intention with the diplomatic answer e)n tw=| paro/nti mhdete/rois a)mu/nein.
metriw/tata—of amount. w(s <d'> a)\n Stein.
e)/lasson dokw=si nei=mai—‘appear to have shown less respect to.’
kai\ ou(/tw bouleusa/menoi—‘accordingly after considering the matter in this light.’

a)mfote)rois ou)=si cumma/xois—cf. c. 78, 4. Remember that Camarina really has with Syr. only an e)pimaxi/a—a defensive alliance, a)llh/lois bohqei=n, cunepistrateu/ein de\ mhdeni/ (v. 48); but with Athens a full cummaxi/a. But Hermocrates in his speech adroitly exaggerated the e)pimaxi/a into a cummaxi/a, and (c. 79, 1) minimised the cummaxi/a into an e)pimaxi/a. These two treaties are both, however, ‘treaties of guarantee’ of some kind; and in all history it has been difficult to secure the fulfilment of such
guarantees, especially where there are conflicting treaties, as in the present case.
eu)/orkon—refers to the oaths taken when the treaties were made.
ta\ kaq) e(autou\s e)c=e(autou\s e)chrtu/onto. ta\ pro\s tou\s *s. e)/prasson refers to cc. 48 and 71, 2; cf. Intr. p. XV.
e)n th=| *na/cw|—see c. 74, 2.
pro\s ta\ pedi/a ma=llon—‘the plains’ near the sea ‘rather than’ the inland parts.
a)feisth/kesan—from Syracuse. See crit. note.
au)to/nomoi ou)=sai ktl—‘their settlements, being independent from time immemorial, with but few exceptions immediately joined the A.’

oi)kh/seis=oppidula, kw=mai. plh/n is here constructed as an adverb, and o)li/goi is masc. kata\ su/nesin. Freeman thinks oi)kh/seis a strange word to apply to the Sicels of the interior, who had under Ducetius (died 440 B.C.) reached a high degree of unity. In 451 he had even defeated the combined forces of Syr. and Acragas (Diod. xi. 91). He was aided by another chief, Archonides, against whom Syr. declared war when Ducetius died. Ducetins built Menaenum, still called Mineo; and this was doubtless among the towns that joined Athens. No doubt Thuc. uses oi)kh/seis in contrast with the larger cities of the Siceliots.
kateko/mizon—to the coast from the interior.
ei)si\n oi(/—in the oblique cases Thuc. much more often uses e)/stin (w(=n, oi(=s, etc.); but cf. VII. 25 h)=san tw=n staurw=n ou(/s.
tou\s de/—sc. prosanagka/zein, depending on a)pekwlu/onto.
to/n te xeimw=na ktl—‘for all these purposes Katanê was a better centre than Naxos. They therefore came back to their old quarters for the rest of the winter’ (Freeman).
o(\ katekau/qh—see c. 75, 2.
e)/pemyan me\n . . e)/pemyan de/—cf. I. 85 pe/mpete me\n . . pe/mpete de/. The examples of epanaphora in Thuc. are not very numerous; the me/n is sometimes omitted.

e)s *karxhdo/na—nothing came of this embassy This shows that at least Athens hoped to gain some influence at Carthage. See c. 34, where Hermocrates suggests the possibility of an alliance between Carthage and Syr. against Athens.

*turshni/an—Etruria, north of the Tiber, the south being *)opikh/ (c. 4, 5) (Arnold). In 415 the Etruscans were still powerful. They carried on trade with Athens and Sicily. In 480 they with the Carthaginians had been defeated by Syr.
with Agrigentum at the great battle of Himera. They actually sent help, and are included among the allies of Athens in VII. 57 *turshnw=n tines kata\ (‘owing to’) diafora\n *surakosi/wn.
kai\ au)tw=n—‘of their own accord.’
to\n periteixismo/n—cf. c. 71, 2 init.
o(/sa e)/dei—sc. e(toima/zein.
a)postale/ntes—see c. 73, 2.
e)kei/nois . . e)pibouleuo/mena—‘that the plots were directed equally against them,’ both tau=ta e)pibouleu/etai/ moi and e)pibouleu/omai being used. Nothing seems to have come of these appeals.
lo/gous e)poiou=nto—‘made overtures.’
to\n au)tou= po/lemon—cf. c. 34, 2: ‘to put an end to the uncertain state of things at home by making open war upon Athens’ (Freeman).
meta\ tw=n cumfuga/dwn—see c. 61, 6. to/t' eu)qu/s—to/te is often used to refer back to events already mentioned. See c. 61, 7.
e)/peita u(/steron—often used together.

th\n peri\ tw=n *mantinikw=n pra=cin—see cc. 16, 6; 17, 1; 61, 5. The reference is to the events of 418 B.C. ta\ *mantinika) alludes to the fact that the Athenians and Mantineans attacked and took Orchomenus, and attempted to take Tegea.
tw=n e)n te/lei o)/ntwn—‘the other officials.’ kai/ joins part to whole.
kwlu/ontas—the pres. partic. is very common with verbs of ‘sending.’ The partic. is placed either in nom. or accus. at will—e)/pempon a)gge/llontes or e)/pempon pre/sbeis a)gge/llontas.
parw/cune . . e)cw/rmhse—‘stimulated their passions and their energies.’
a)nagkai=on—the abruptness of the opening is a fine touch. On the dispositio of the speech see Appendix.
peri\ th=s e)mh=s d—‘about the prejudice against me,’ i.e. of being an enemy of Sparta. The pron. is objective gen. e)s u(ma=s—e)s is often used with le/gw in the sense ‘to address an assembly.’
xei=ron ta\ koina\ ktl—‘listen with less impartiality to what concerns the public interest because you suspect me.’ xei=ron is ‘with a bias.’ Lacuna after a)kroa/shsqe Stein.

tw=n d' e)mw=n—‘now,’ etc.; de/ marks the transition
to the details. The grandfather of Alcibiades had dropped the office of pro/cenos, circa 508, and the family was closely connected with the Alcmaeonidae, Alcibiades' mother being granddaughter of Cleisthenes. This connexion throws light on kata/ ti e)/gklhma. The complaint doubtless arose out of the visit of King Cleomenes to Athens to support Isagoras against Cleisthenes.
th\n proceni/an—Gardner and Jevons, p. 599.
au)to\s e)gw/—‘I of my own accord offered to resume it.’ The offer was declined

th\n e)k *pu/lou cumfora/n—he refers to the Spartan prisoners taken at Pylus in 425. Cf. v. 43 of Alc tou\s e)k th=s nh/sou au)tw=n ai)xmalw/tous qerapeu/wn. Aristoph. Eq. 1201 tou\s e)k *pu/lou. Alc. no doubt exaggerates his services.
diatelou=ntos—the only instance of diatelw= with partie. in Thuc. is paraskeuazo/menoi . . diete/lesan VIII. 38. diatelw=, tugxa)nw, and fai/nomai are often constructed with adj. only.

toi=s me\n e)moi=s e)xqroi=s—i.e. Nicias and Laches. The former became very popular in 421 as the result of the Peace that he had promoted. Since Cleon's death in 422 Alc. had opposed peace. In 420 he brought about the alliance between Athens, Argos, Mantinea, and Elis.
a)timi/an perie/qete—esp. by declining his offer to become pro/cenos.

pro/s te ktl—the construction is u(p' e)mou= pro/s te . . trapome/nou e)bla)ptesqe kai\ e)bla)ptesqe o(/sa a)/lla e)nhntiou/mhn, ‘you deserved all that you suffered from me when I looked for help to Argos and Mantinea and opposed you in many other ways’—e.g. by attacking the Peace of Nicias and by invading Epidaurus, an ally of Sparta, to force it to join the new league.
ou)k ei)ko/tws—‘unreasonably,’ because my opposition was deserved.
meta\ tou= a)lhqou=s—so met' a)lhqei/as, occasionally meta\ th=s a). Here m. tou= a)lhqou=s skopw=n is contrasted with ou)k ei)ko/tws.
dio/ti kai/—in addition to opposing you.

tw=| dh/mw| prosekei/mhn—‘I inclined to the popular party’ rather than to the oligarchs. His idea was to draw together all the democratic elements at home and in the Peloponnese against Sparta. But the battle of Mantinea was fatal to the scheme.
ou(/tws—‘on that ground.’
tura/nnois—an ingenious point, because Sparta also opposed the tyranny.
dia/foroi/ e)smen—i.e. the Alcmaeonid family, by which Pisistratus and Cylon had been opposed.

pa=n to\ e)nantiou/menon—‘any power that opposes despotism is called democracy.’ This alludes to popular opinion at Athens, where the opponents of the tyrants were by tradition regarded as dhmotikoi/, since Cleisthenes was the great prosta/ths of the dh=mos. Ath. Pol. c. 20. Cf. Andoc. 2, 26, where the orator boasts that he is a democrat by descent on this very ground.
tw=| dunasteu/onti is neut.

a)p' e)kei/nou—i.e. owing to the fact that the family opposed the tyrants, and that the Athenians regarded that opposition, followed as it was by Cleisthenes’ ‘settlement of the democracy,’ as bestowing a hereditary connexion with the people.
cumpare/meinen—i.e. has remained along with the traditional opposition to tyranny.
h( prostasi/a—i.e. since the days of Cleisthenes.
ta\ polla/—with e(/pesqai. toi=s parou=sin=‘the existing conditions.’
th=s u(parxou/shs a)kolasi/as—‘we (i.e. the whole family) tried to show a moderation in political life that contrasted with the prevailing license.’

a)/lloi d' h)=san—the extreme democrats are meant, including the demagogues of his own day—Cleon, Hyperbolus, and Androcles. As for e)pi\ tw=n pa/lai, this contrast being a mere assertion of Alc., it is hardly necessary to look for a precise reference; but in the Ath. Pol. c. 24 stress is laid on the influence of Aristides in this direction.
ponhro/tera—see Index.
e)ch=gon—see Index.

tou= cu/mpantos—not merely tou= dh/mou: they were for the constitution, and were no mere party leaders. In the case of some of the Alcmaeonidae there is truth in this, but Alc. was not a party leader only because he pursued a purely selfish policy. He is not even mentioned in the Ath. Pol., where the statesmen who held a commanding position are enumerated.
o(/per e)decato/ tis ktl—‘to help to preserve what he had inherited.’
dikaiw= is Ionic.
e)pei\ dhmokrati/an ge ktl—‘though, to be sure, the nature of democracy was quite well understood by every man of insight.’ The
kai/ implies ‘in addition to having received it as an inheritance,’ and the words are sarcastic, meaning ‘we knew too much about it to approve of it.’

kai\ ai)to\s a)
 ktl—i.e. kai\ au)to\s ou)deno\s a)
 xei=ron fronoi/hn, o(/sw| ka)
 loidorh/saimi, ‘and the superiority of my insight (the
insight that you would attribute to me) would be measured by the amount of abuse I might pour on it’; only, he continues, it is impossible to say anything new of a constitution of which the folly is admitted. (It is usual to assume that the text of this much-disputed passage is corrupt. See crit. note. Only Herbst among lecent clities defends it; and he understands ou)deno\s a)
 xei=ron (gignw/skoimi) o(/sw| kai\ (ou)deno\s a)
 xei=ron) loidorh/saimi: but the sense so obtained is by no means clear. The rendering of Wilkins, ‘perhaps, indeed, it was better known to me than any one, as I have had more reason to complain of it than any one,’ does not correspond to the Greek, and is itself obscure.) Alcibiades says ‘I might exhibit the extent of my insight by the amount of knowledge I might show of the nature of democracy, i.e. by abusing it’; but, he says, the task is superfluous. Then, by a common rhetorical trick, he throws in a specimen of abuse (o(mologoume/nh a)/noia). Thus loidorh(saimi corresponds with e)gignw/skomen: the knowledge would be extensive and peculiar, being gathered from experience of the tyranny of democracy, and it would be expressed in a loidori/a. The Scholium is au)to\s a)
 e)gw\ ou)deno\s xei=ron loidorh/saimi, o(/sw| kai\ me/gista u(p' au)th=s h)di/khmai, which gives in a paraphrase the trne meaning, but is incomplete.
o(/sw| kai/—see on c. 11, 6.

loidorh/saimi—this would not have been seemly in a public address at this time. Cf. Ath. Pol. c. 28, of Cleon, prw=tos e)pi\ tou= bh/matos a)ne/krage kai\ e/loidorh/sato . . tw=n a)/llwn e)n ko/smw| lego/ntwn.
o(mologoume/nhs a)noi/as—a phrase made to please his audience. Theognis l. 847 la\c e)pi/ba dh/mw| keneo/froni.

kai\ to\ meqista/nai—goes back to dikaiou=ntes . . tou=to (to\ sxh=ma) cundiasw/|zein. au/th/n=th\n dhmokrati/an. Wilkins quotes Napoleon III.'s Julius Caesar, ‘All political change is fatal in the presence of a foreigner invading the soil of a fatherland.’ And even the desire for political change vanishes in the presence of a war—as the same Napoleon well knew.
ta\ me\n ktl—i.e. all this explains how I came to support democracy: lit. ‘this is how the circumstances came about that bear on the prejudices aroused against me.’
ei)/ ti ple/on oi)=da—this is subject of ei)shghte/on, concerning which ‘I must bring to your notice whatever information I have that is new to you.’
e)pleu/samen—Alc. proceeds to speak of his own schemes as though they were the schemes of the Athenians at large.
au)tw=n—as distinct from their possessions in Sicily, Corsica, Sardinia, etc. (a)rxh=s).
kai\ a)/llous ktl—i.e. kai\ a)/llous o(mologoume/nws nu=n maximwta)tous tw=n e)kei\ barba)rwn, though the position of barba)rwn is awkward.
kai\ *)/ibhras kai\ a)/llous is epexegetic of pollou\s barba/rous. 17

pe/ric poliorkou=ntes—the fleet would blockade the coasts, while the army would invade the Pel. by land. Athens did not herself possess a large enough army to invade the Pel. effectually, and Pericles had taught that she must be content with making descents upon the coasts.
e)k gh=s e)formai=s—‘by attacks on the land side.’ e)formh/, which is rare, is explained by Hesychius as o(/qen a)/n tis pole/mw| e)formh/seien.
e)nteixisa/menoi=periteixi/santes.

eu)porw/teron—adverb: cf. c. 92, 1; VII. 4 r(a=|on au)tw| e)fai/neto h( e)skomidh\ tw=n e)pithdei/wn e)/sesqai. ‘So that they should in every case be forthcoming in abundance.’ ti gives a distributive force, and au)tw=n refers to xrh/mata kai\ si=ton. (So Classen and Sitzler. Others understand by ti au)tw=n ‘our various projects.’)
diarkh=—pred. to xrh/mata kai\ si=ton. a)/neu ‘without touching.’
e)nqe/nde=e)k th=s *(ella)dos.

o(/soi—the edd. all say that Nicias and Lamachus are meant, and Reiske even proposed w\s oi( as a correction; but o(/soi u(po/loipoi means ‘all those who remain now I am withdrawn,’ ‘all the generals left behind, including those who have not gone to Sicily,’ and not ‘those whom I have left in Sicily.’ That this is so is shown by the following facts: (1) the use of u(po/loipos in Thuc.: I. 105 to\ pro\s *ai)gi/nh| stra)teuma is contrasted with oi( e)k th=s po/lews u(po/loipoi: IV. 2 strathgoi\ oi( u(po/loipoi are contrasted with o( h)/dh proafigme/nos e)s *sikeli/an: VII. 64 tou\s e)kei= (i.e. at home) h(mw=n u(poloi/pous: cf. also ib. h( u(po/loipos po/lis and c. 17 u(po/loipon h(mi=n e)sti\n a)nti/palon nautiko/n: (2) in c. 62, 1 the generals left in Sicily are called oi( loipoi\ tw=n *)aqhnai/wn strathgoi\ e)n th=| *sikeli/a|: (3) in II. 65 Thuc. speaks of the support given to the expedition at home after it sailed out; and of course the strathgoi/ in Athens would have to advise about this, and some of them might be sent out to replace Alcibiades: (4) au)ta) = all the schemes including the katapole/mhsis of Peloponnese. It would be absurd to attribute the whole of this work to Nicias and Lamachus alone.
o(moi/ws—i.e. ‘though I have withdrawn.’ ou) perie/stai ta)kei=—ou) swqh/setai ta\ e)n th=| *sikeli/a|.
a)peiro/teroi—sc. tw=n *)aqhnaiw=n. custrafe/ntes—c. 77, 1.
pandhmei/—c. 68, 2.
e)/xetai—‘is in their power.’ The pres. denotes the certainty of the event. Stahl, Q.G.2 p. 12
ki/ndunon e)kei=qen—‘danger from that quarter.’
ou)k belongs to makrou=: cf. c. 15, 4.
w(/ste—‘and thus’; M.T. § 602.

ei) mh\ poih/sete—‘unless you mean to do this.’ With the construction oi)e/sqw bouleu/ein, ei) mh\ poih/sete cf. Lys. 13, 93 ei) ga\r a)poyhfiei=sqe . . th=| au)th=| yh/fw| katayhfi/zesqe, and § 3 above.
strati/an te pe/myete—epexegesis of ta)de poih/sete. For

oi(/tines cf. a)po\ *peloponnh/sou . . oi(/ c. 80, 1. w(s a)\n . . cunta/ch|—w(s a)/n only here in Thuc.; M.T. § 326. The construction is poetical, o)/s with fut. indic. being the ordinary prose form of expression. Several constructions that are familiar in Thuc. are found on examination to be poetical: e.g. the dat. with verbs of motion, expressing interest or the goal, as h)=lqon au)toi=s c. 46, 3; e)pi/ with dat.=against c. 61, 1; and others already noticed. (See C. F. Smith, Trans. of Am. Phil. Association 1894 p. 61 ff.)
cunta/ch—‘organise.’
tou\s mh\ qe/lontas, sc. parei=nai. The form qe/lein for e)qe/lein is regular after mh/.
oi( e)ndoia/zontes—such as Camarina. An Ionic word.
ta\ e)nqa/de—this may be either adverbial, ‘in Greece,’ or direct object of e)kpolemou=n, ‘the Greek states.’
h(=sson . . pe/mpwsi—‘may be prevented from sending.’

teixi/zein de\ xrh/—the passage that follows is written with a knowledge of later events. The chief results of the occupation are to be: (1) the capture or surrender of most of the property, (2) the loss to Athens of the revenue from the mines, (3) the tribute from the allies will not be paid. These are the results that in VII. 27 are actually stated to have followed (Jebb, Hellenica p. 290).

*deke/leian—it commands the road from Athens to Oropus, and thus the route to Euboea, whence came a great part of the corn supplies of Athens. The fort built there overlooked the richest parts of Attica.
o(/per—i.e. to\ teixi/zein. For
au)tou= in place of ou(= see c. 4, 3 n.
tw=n e)n tw=| pole/mw|—the A. had adopted this plan against Sparta at Pylus. ‘The only suffering incidental to the war of which they have not had a thorough experience.’
bebaio/tata d' a)\n ktl—‘the surest way of injuring an enemy is to bring on him that which one ascertains from clear in formation that he fears most.’
ei)ko\s ga/r—‘it is natural that every one should have the most accurate knowledge of the particular dangers that he fears,’ i.e. he realises best the nature and extent of the danger he is in.
kwlu/sete—sc. w)felei=sqai.
au)to/mata—this refers to ‘the desertion of slaves, included in the kataskeuai/ as household chattels or “live stock”’ (Jebb).
h(/cei pro\s u(ma=s—‘will come into your hands.’
tw=n a)gurei/wn m.—Aesch. Persae 237 a)rgu/rou phgh/tis au)toi=s e)sti\ qhsauro\s xqono/s. They were farmed out on hereditary leases. ta\s <a)po\> tou= *l. Stein.
a)po\ gh=s—produce to the tenant and the rent paid to the state.

dikasthri/wn—fees and fines to the state and pay to the dicasts. The business of the courts would be at an end. This may be somewhat exaggerated. In VII. 28 it is explained that all citizens were required for military duty. (The conjecture dekateuthri/wn—see crit. note—is too technical to be satisfactory; and the tithes and taxes on land are included in a)po\ gh=s.) For the omission of the prep. with dikasthri/wn cf. ce. 6, 2; 26, 2.
th=s . . proso/dou—the most important source of revenue. For the change from accus. to gen. with a)posterh/sontai ef. c. 85, 2 n.
h(=sson diaforoume/nhs=‘less regularly transmitted.’ There is no other instance of this sense of diaforei=n, the nearest being in c. 100, 3, where it=‘to transfer.’
ta\ par' u(mw=n . . polemei=sqai—‘that the war is being condueted on your part.’ ta\ pa\r' u)mw=n is prob. subject, not adverbial.
o)ligwrh/sousi sc. tou= diaforei=n th\n p.
gi/gnesqai de\ ktl.—‘the prompt and efficient execu tion of these plans rests with you.’

ou)de\ u(popteu/esqai ktl.—‘nor do I think suspieion should be cast upon my words on the ground that I display the zeal of an exile.’ For e)s the edd. quote VIII. 88 boulo/menos au)to
 e)s th
 fili/an diaba/llein. The gen. mou= separated from to
 lo/gon has the force of an ethic dat., as often in Thuc.

fuga/s te ga\r ktl.—‘an exile, indeed, I am from the villainy of those who banished me, but not from the power of aiding you’ (Wilkins). This refers to e)s th\n fugadikh\n p., but the extreme artificiality of the expression is not redeemed by its ingenuity. fuga/s is used in two senses.

kai\ polemiw/teroi ktl.—referring to meta\ tw=n polemiwta/twn
above. Enemies within are more dangerous (to Athens) than enemies without.

h)/—strictly a)lla/ is required, as ou)x follows polemiw/teroi. For the opposite, a)lla) in place of h)/. cf. II. 43 ou)k e)n w(=| kei=ntai ma=llon, a)ll' e)n w(=| h( do/ca . . katalei/petai. (The Scholiast is wrong in saying ou)x ou(/tws u(ma=s polemi/ous h(gou=mai, w(s *(aqhnai/ous.)
oi( . . a)nagka/santes—referring to his own enemies at Athens.

to/ te filo/poli ktl.—‘love of country consists for me not in suffering injustice, as I now am doing, but in the feeling that I once lived securely as a citizen’ (Hampke, Studien p. 11). e)n w(=|=e)n tou/tw| o(/ti. Cf c. 55, 4. Classen wrongly supplies ei)=xon to e)n w(=| . . e(politeu/qhn. Alc. ‘is not saying that he was once a patriot and had now ceased to be one, but he claims or pretends to be still a patriot’ (note in Jowett), as is shown by what follows.

ou)d' e)pi\ patri/da ou)=san ktl.—‘nor yet do I think that I am now attacking (a city) that is still my country, but rather that I am trying to recover one that is not my country.’ by helping you to defeat Athens, to destroy her power, and to start a new hegemony founded on good will and independence (§ 5).

kai\ filo/polis ktl.—Jebb suggests that in these words, written after the end of the war, Thuc. may have been thinking of Thrasy bulus and the downfall of the Thirty. ‘Just after the restoration of the democracy the point would have been peculiarly effective.’ Cf. Isocrates 16, 14, where the comparison between Alc. and the patriots under Thrasybulus is made.
a)pole/sas, ‘lost.’

dia\ to\ e)piqumei=n—cf. Andoc. 2, 10 ei)sh=lqe/ moi e)piqumi/a th=s meq' u(mw=n politei/as. ‘The true patriot is not he who abstains from moving against the country from which he has been unjustly banished, but he who, in his passionate love for her, strives by all means to regain her’ (Jebb). The whole of §§ 3 and 4 is sophistry.
e)moi/ te—answered by kai\ au)tou/s. talaipwri/a often means the suffering that war or disease brings
proballo/menon—‘put forward’; cf. I. 73 ta\ de\ *mhdika\ . . ai)ei\ proballome/nois (mid.) a)na)gkh le/gein (a passage which is, I think, misundcrstood by the edd.).
ei) pole/mio/s ge ktl.—we should expect rather to have a general statement: the plea is ‘just as I injured you greatly as an enemy, so I should help you effectually as a friend.’
o(/sw|—‘inasmuch as’ (oftener with compar. or superl. following). ‘I only conjectured your intentions, whereas I know those of the Athenians.’
diafero/ntwn—‘interests.’
braxei= mori/w|—‘with a small part of your forces.’

mega/la is considered by Poppo predicative, by Classen proleptic; but perhaps the order is only due to the antithesis between braxei= and mega/la—‘a slender aid to secure great interests’ (Bloomfield’).
th\n me/llousan—referring to the Athenian designs as he had foreshadowed them.
th=s a(pa/shs *(ella/dos—he contrasts the mildness of the coming Spartan hegemony with the oppression of the present Athenian Empire. The contrast is of course imaginary.
kat' eu)/noian—‘in virtue of their goodwill.’
kai\ au)toi/—‘even unasked’ they were thinking of sending an expedition against Athens, but were ‘hesitating and looking about them.’
e)perrw/sqhsan is opposite of a)rrwstei=n: cf. VII. 7 e)s ta)=lla polu\ e)pe/rrwnto: the e)p- denotes addition.
dida/cantos . . kai\ nomi/santes—the participles are timeless. They were encouraged ‘by his explanation and by the thought that he knew.’

prosei=xon h)/dh to\n nou=n—‘from this moment they set their minds on it.’ The plan was not carried out until March 413. The Peace of Nicias was still nominally observed: Sparta shrank from violating it openly.
kai\ to\ parauti/ka—with pe/mpein. which depends on prosei=xon to\n nou=n in a slightly different meaning.
timwri/an= boh/qeian (Schol.), Ionic. No troops were sent immediately.
*gu/lippon—see Freeman, Hist. Sic. III. p. 201. His arrival in Sicily was the turning-point of the war. His father, exiled for taking bribes from Athens, had settled at Thurii in 445 B.C.
prosta/cantes a)/rxonta—Thucydidean expression for the appointment of a commander.
toi=s *sur. is dat. commodi.
met' e)kei/nwn—sc. the Syracusans, though only the envoys are meant, as also in *korinqi/wn.
poiei=n o(/ph| . . h)/cei—‘to devise how help may reach their friends in Sicily most effectually and speedily.’
e)k tw=n paro/ntwn—‘under the circumstances,’ viz. those explained by Alc. in c. 91, 2.
oi(—the only case of the sing. of this pron. at all frequent in prose.

*)asi/nhn—in Messenia, mentioned also in IV. 13. It is strange that it is not more clearly defined, esp. as there is a
place of the same name in Laconia. The further movements of Gylippus are recorded in c. 104.
o(/tan kairo\s h)=|—it was now winter, and so not time to sail.

h( . . trih/rhs—see c. 74, 2. trofh/n is money to pay the troops. The sum is 300 talents (c. 94, 4). Cf. the inscription given in Hicks, p. 79 ‘epi\ th=s *)antioxi/dos o)gdo/hs prutaneuou/shs tri/th| h(me/ra| (this date would be somewhere in March, which fits in with the text here) th=s prutanei/as’: a sum of 300 talents is paid as a loan from the treasure of Athena (cf. II. 13) to Aristocrates, Euonymus, and the other strategi, who pay it over for the army in Sicily. Then follows an account of a further loan of 4 talents, 2000 drachmas, for the ships that were to convey the money to Sicily.
e)teleu/ta—see on c. 7, 4.

*mega/rwn, ou(/s—for the change from place-name to inhabitants, which is very common, cf. cc. 48; 74, 1; 75, 2. Observe that unless gender and number are in agreement with the antecedent, attraction of rel. is impossible. Cf. c. 20, 3 *na/cou kai\ *kata/nhs, a)\s h)/lpizon.
w(/sper kai\ ktl—at c. 4, 2.

e)dh/|wsan tou/s [te] a)grou/s—for the wrong insertion of te see on c. 6, 2. It is improbable that Thuc. would write such a sentence as e)dh/|wsan tou/s te a)grou\s kai\ . . to\ pedi/on e)dh/|oun for e)dh/|wsa/n te tou\s a). kai\ e)dh/|oun to\ pe/dion, for in all other places where te is misplaced the verb in the second clause is different; the second clause refers to the return journey and should not be joined to the first by te . . kai/: if so joined to\ pedi/on ought to refer to a plain at Megara. Herbst, who brackets tou\s a)grou/s as well, says that there is no passage in Thuc. in which te is a real parallel to this. His objections to tou\s a)grou/s are, however, less forcible. By these words we are to understand estates about Megara that were held by Syracusans; cf. II. 13 tou\s a)grou\s tou\s au(tou=, of Pericles' estates.
e)/ruma—‘Thuc. had already twice mentioned Megara as a frou/rion of Syr. in cc. 49, 75. . . This e)/ruma is surely something smaller than ta\ *me)gara frou/rion in c. 75’ (Freeman).
au)=qis—refers to e)dh/|oun, in the sense of ‘next’; cf. c. 90, 2.
parakomisqe/ntes—this goes with pezh=| and nausi/: all returned along the coast, some by sea, some by land. The Terias forms the boundary between Syracusan and Catanean territory.
to/ te pedi/on—i.e. to\ tou= *thri/ou pedi/on. a)naba/ntes applies only to the land forces. Notice the three participles, e(lo/ntes, parakomisqe/ntes, a)naba/ntes. Cf. c. 97, 4.
*kento/ripa—Centorbi, one of the Sicel towns that refused to join the A. It is close to Inessa and Geleatic Hybla.

tw=n *)inhssai/wn—the exact site of Inessa is unknown. In III. 103 it is to\ *sikeliko\n po/lisma. In 426 the Athenians tried to take it and failed. For the attempt to take Hybla see c. 62, 5. Both were overlooked by Centuripa. Freeman notices that the article is wanting to Centuripa, as also to Hyccara c. 62, 3, and thinks that they were much less well-known places than Inessa, which was a famous place in the time of Ducetius.
tou\s i(ppe/as—see c. 93, 4.
tw=n i(/ppwn—‘the required horses’ were to be got in Sicily.
e)p' *)/argos—an ally of Athens. Classen thinks that the purpose was to make a hostile settlement at Cleonae.
seismou=—always a source of great alarm at Sparta.
*qurea=tin—this region was a cause of frequent dispute between Argolis and Sparta. It had been in the possession of Sparta since 495 B.C.
e)/lasson—for the adverb see c. 1, 2 n. The omission of h)/ after it is not very common, but occurs in IV. 72, 2.

o( *qespie/wn dh=mos—Thespiae, like Plataea, refused to submit to the Persians. It was always suspected by Thebes of leaning towards Athens, and in 423 Thebes destroyed its walls. No doubt the government was administered in the interests of Thebes.
ou) kate/sxen—intrans., ‘did not attain their object’; cf. c. 11, 3.
*)aqh/naze—it was part of the tradition of Athens, often alluded to in tragedy, to afford shelter to exiles.
te]—cf. c. 94, 2 n. As Stahl says, there is no parallel in Thuc. to such a ‘trajection’ of te as this for tou\s i\ppe)as h(/konta/s te.
*)epipolw=n—Epipolae includes all the high ground west of Achradina which was not within the fortifications of the city.
sfa=s—should strictly speaking be sfei=s: but the accus. marks the contrast—here with *)aqhnai=oi—more strongly when the pronoun is far from the subject to which it refers.

ta\s prosba/seis—i.e. the approaches at the western end. It is strange that the Syr. had not posted a guard here before; but still stranger that the A. afterwards, when they gained Epipolae, left the approaches open.
au)tw=n=tw=n *)epipolw=n. kata\ tau=ta= ‘by this road.’
dunhqh=nai—sc. laqei=n a)naba/ntes. The reason for this confidenee is given in what follows.

e)ch/rthtai ktl—‘the rest of Epipolae (with the exception of the western extremity) is elevated and slopes down to the city, and inwards (i.e. ab urbe, as Bauer explains) it is exposed to view,’ because it rises gently. (1) e)ch/rthtai= suspensa est. Stahl and others read e)ch=rtai, arguing that the Schol. read it, for his note begins mh\ e)pi\ tou= e)ch=rqai kai\ metewri/sqai a\koue/sqw. But, as Classen says, this does not settle the reading. (2) me/xri th=s po/lews and e)/sw are the opposite one of the other; for e)/sw=landwards from the city.
e)pipolh=s—‘above.’
to\n leimw=na—north of the confluence of the Anapus and Cyane.

e)tu/gxanon . . pareilhfo/tes — with the tenses here contrast e)/laqon sxo/ntes in c. 97, 1, and fqa/nei (historic pres.= e)/fqasen) a)naba/s. See M. T. §§ 144, 146, 147, 887. The aor. partic. expresses time coineident with the aor. of these verbs.

oi( peri\ to\n *(ermokra/th—see cc 72, 5, 73, 1. Freeman thinks that Thuc. gives the names prematurely in c. 73, 1, and that the election had only just taken place. But Thuc. means that the election took place in the winter, and the new generals only entered on office in the spring, with the beginning of the new campaign.
loga/das—see on c. 66, 2. In c. 100 loga/des and e)klektoi/ occur together.
o(/pws . . ei)=en . . paragi/gnwntai—cf. VII. 17 o(/pws . . a)popeira/swsi . . kwlu/oien. ‘As the two forms are equally correct, we sometimes find both in the same sense.’ M.T. § 321.

tau/ths th=s nukto\s ktl—as the passage stands in the MSS., the construe is ‘on the day that followed this night the A. held a review,’ i.e. on the day following the night that preceded the Syracusan review, they having sailed from Catana to Leon during the night. But serious objections to this are the intolerable harshness of the sentence, the absence of kai\ au)toi/ after e)chta/zonto, and above all the absurdity of supposing that the A. would hold a review at Leou while the Syr. were doing the same on the Anapus, instead of making the best of their way to Euryelus, their whole object being to seize the height unknown to the Syr., as the night voyage shows. And § 2 below, e)xw/rei eu)qu/s dro/mw|, is inconsistent with the supposition. Again, the review cannot have been held at Catana, as then the voyage must have been made when day was well advanced. The choiee lies between inserting h(=| with Poppo
before th=| and striking out kai/ with Madvig, so as to refer e)chta/zonto to the Syr.; and with Kruger regarding th=| e)pigignome/nh| . . e)chta/zonto as an adscript on tau/ths th=s nukto/s, intended to explain its meaning. This has then been attached to the text by kai/.

to\n *le/onta—the site is not known. All that is certain is that it was within a nule of the point of ascent sxei=n kata/, as distinct from e)ce/bainon e)s to\ kata/ in c. 65, probably shows that it was on the coast, though Arnold, Grote, and Freeman thought not. Holm points out that the A. would land at a point south of Thapsus.
*qa/yon—now Magnisi. The naval force protected itself by a stockade across the narrow isthmus.
e)n stenw=| i)sqmw=|—cf. IV. 45 i)sqmo\n . . e)n w=| h( *meqw/nh e)sti/: IV. 113, 2.

kata\ to\n *eu)ru/hlon—the ‘Broad Nail’ extends in its widest sense from Mongibellisi, where stands the Dionysian Castle, to the Belvedere Hill, which forms the head of the nail and is the western extremity of the hill. The point meant here is the former, where the northern wall of Dionysus springs from his castle. The same path was used by Gylippus afterwards, and again by the A. general Demosthenes in the night attack on Epipolae. For
pezo/s see Index.
e)k tou= leimw=nos kai\ th=s e)—with paragene/sqai.
ta/xous—the gen. denotes the sphere in which lay their power.
prosmei=zai—sc. toi=s *)aqhnai/ois. The Syr. of course ascended Euryelus by the south side.
e)pikataba/ntes—the A. march down the hill and then back again. For the succession of participles cf. c. 4, 1.

e)pi\ tw=| *labda/lw|—east of the point of ascent, on the north brink of the cliff, ‘on the extremity’ (a)kroi=s). This site would be convenient with the fleet stationed at Thapsus. Its disadvantage was that it was not visible from the ku/klos which the A. presently built. It was subsequently taken by Gylippus. When he took it there were apparently no stores there; these were apparently removed to the ku/klos: cf. c. 102, 2. (See Heitland in Jour. of Phil. '94 p. 57.) ‘A safe place was needed for their money and stuff, while they themselves went forth to fight with the enemy, or to hem in his city by a wall across the height which was now their own’ (Freeman).

kai\ ou) pollw=| ktl—though expressed paratactically,
the section consists of two causes and a result—each introduced by kai/—so that kai\ cu/mpantes=‘and thus in all.’

*sukh=n—this name is found only in Thuc., and the position is unknown. Arnold, Grote, Stahl, Holm, and Freeman place it on the middle of the slope of Epipolae. But Leake and Conradt place it farther south, and this view is probably correct. See c. 101, 1 on e)tei/xizon to\n krhmno/n.

e)tei/xisan to\n ku/klon—recent authorities agree that this means ‘built (and completed) the (necessary, cf. c. 100, 1) fort,’ and not ‘built the (whole) circle of walls,’ which was never completed. This fort was to be the central point of walls running north to Trogilus and south to the Great Harbour, and from it the A. subsequently established communication with the harbour. (The only recent writer who supports the sense ‘circumvallation’ is Conradt in N. Jahrb. fur Phil. '84 p. 534. The passages in which the ku/klos is referred to are cc. 99, 1, 3; 101, 1; 102, 2; VII. 2, 4. Conradt's only strong point is that in VII. 2 tw=| de\ a)/llw| tou= ku/klou pro\s to\n *trw/gilon the sense ‘on the other side of the fortress’ or ‘for the other portion running from the fortress’ cannot be got from the Greek. I read there tw=| de\ a)/llw| <a)/nw> tou= ku/klou. But in all the other passages ‘fortress’ is much more suitable. Heitland shows that the sense ‘circumvallation’ belongs to ku/klos when it is used either (a) of defences. (b) offensive works that run all round a place. The reasons appended to Jowett's translation for preferring ‘circumvallation’ have been refuted by Freeman and Heitland.)
a)ntiparatassome/nwn—with e(w/rwn. diespasme/non, opposite of cuntasso/menon.
makrote/ran—sc. o(do/n. All degrees of makro/s are found thus in the fem. accus.
ski/dnasqai is an Ionic form
fulh/=ta/cis. Gardner and Jevons, p. 637. e(\n ta/gma a)po\ fulh=s mia=s, Schol.

to\ pro\s bore/an tou= ku/klou tei=xos—either ‘a wall to wards the north of the fort,’ or ‘the wall north of the fort.’ It is not clear whether to\ pro\s b. agrees with tei=xos or not. Thuc. distinguishes ku/klos from a)potei/xisma.
ai)ei/—with pare/ballon.
braxu/taton—the distance from the ku/klos to Trogilus (e)pi\ th\n e)te/ran qa/lassan) would be about a mile and a half, and the same from the ku/klos to the harbour.
e)gi/gneto=e)/mellon e)/sesqai, Schol.

u(poteixi/zein—‘build an intercepting wall’; cf. u(pomo/sai.
a)poklh/|seis gi/gnesqai—a)poklh/|seis is subject of (e)/mellon). The plur. may allude to the fact that, as the A. were building two walls, Syr. would be shut in in two directions.
e)pibohqoi=en—sc. oi( *)aqhnai=oi. ‘If they sent to prevent them while they were building.’
a)ntipe/mpein au)toi=s—sc. e)do/kei a)/meinon ei)=nai. At kai\ fqa/nein a)/n the passage is continued in O.O.

ta\s e)fo/dous—either ‘attacks’ on the wall which would be ‘checked’ by a stockade, or else the ‘approaches’ which would be ‘occupied’ before the wall itself was built. In either case the sense is the same: the stauroi/ are to protect the builders, and are a temporary shelter.
a)po\ th=s s. po/lews—from some point in the wall of Temenites.

ka/twqen tou= ku/klou—‘south of the fort.’ The reasons for the choice were—(1) the A. would be prevented from reaching the Great Harbour, (2) the north was unsuitable, because the A. fleet was at Thapsus, and a counterwork there would be exposed on two sides to an attack, (3) the A. were busy at the north, and their attention was withdrawn from the south. (Leake, Arnold, Grote, Holm, and Classen place the wall at the south. But Göller, Dunbar, Didot, and Stahl place it north of the ku/klos, rendering ka/twqen ‘on lower ground than.’ But (1) c. 100, 2 kate/fngon e)s to\ protei/xisma to\ peri\ to(\n *temeni/thn is against this. (2) If the wall was north of the ku/klos, why did the A. leave off building at the north wall after destroying the counterwork? They would have pressed on in that direction to prevent the Syr. from repeating their attempt to traverse the north wall. But if the Syr. built south, between the ku/klos and krhmno/s, Nicias had a good reason for building at once across this space, instead of continuing on the northern wall. (3) As ka/twqen can mean ‘south of,’ it is unlikely that Thuc. would have used it to describe a wall north of the ku/klos, as such a description would certainly mislead.)
e)gka/rsion—at right angles to the A. wall.
tou= teme/nous—i.e. in the Temenites, for which see c. 75, 1.
pu/rgous culi/nous—probably on the south side of the wall.

ai( de\ nh=es ktl —this explains on the one hand how it was that the Syr. were not open to attack from the harbour, on the other why the A. were able to get provisions in spite of the Syr. counterwork and possession of the harbour.

o(/sa te e)staurw/qh kai\ w)|kodomh/qh—i.e. the u(potei/xisma consisted partly of palisading and partly of stone-work. The exact relations between the stau/rwma and oi)kodo/mhma cannot be
determined. Thuc. himself is not clear, for he speaks presently of fu/laka tou= oi)kodh/matos, and farther on alludes to part of the same people as oi( e)n tw=| staurw/mati fula/ssontes. Observe that te is misplaced.
ma/xwntai—sc. oi( *surako/sioi. th\n kaq) au(tou/s—at the north.
tou/s te o)xetou\s . . die/fqeiran—the elaborate aqueducts of Syr., of which there are many remains, were partly open, partly underground.
potou= u(/datos—belongs to o)xetou/s, but is attracted into the rel. clause.
tou/s te a)/llous—i.e. those of the fulh/ who were not e)n tw=| staurw/mati fula/ssontes.
e)capinai/ws—this and e)capi/nhs, for e)cai/fnhs and ai)fnidi/ws, are Ionic. For
ei) e)pibohqoi=en see Index s. ei).

h( de\ . . to\ para\ th\n puli/da—while a body of 300 picked men was making for the u(potei/xisma, or that portion of it that consisted only of palisading, a division of the army marched to another stau/rwma—viz. ‘that by the postern gate’; but whether this puli/s was in the walls of the city or in the u(potei/xisma is not stated. On the one hand there may well have been a gate in the u(potei/xisma to admit from one side to the other, and this may be one of the e)/fodoi alluded to in c. 99, 2. But the 300 picked men would be sufficient to attack this, and it ought to be some gate through which help might come to those at the counterwork. Hence most probably it is a gate in the wall of Temenites, south of the point where the counterwork sprang from the wall; so that one division of the A. army marched north, the other south of the u(potei/xisma.
to\ stau/rwma—sc. tou= u(poteixi/smatos. CavallariHolm seem to identify this wrongly with to\ stau/rwma to\ para\ th(n puli/da.

to\ protei/xisma—see c. 75, 1. The Syr. probably rushed through the puli/s, and the pursuers ran in after them, accompanied by some of the division that was marching on the stau/rwma there. Among these last were some Argives (§ 3), who, being hoplites (c. 43, 2), were not among the e)klektoi/ of § 1.
th\n . . u(potei/xisin = to( oi)kodo/mhma of § 1. On
diefo/rhsan see c. 91, 7

e)tei/xizon to
 krhmno/n—‘they proceeded to build a wall on the cliff,’ not ‘built a wall along the cliff,’ as Classen. This is the short piece of wall that ran from the ku/klos to the Portella del Fusco, and is more accurately described in § 3 as
to\ pro\s to
 krhmno/n. (Arnold, Grote, and Freeman understand ‘they fortified a point on the cliff,’ and assume that Nicias subsequently filled in the space between this new fort and the ku/klos with a wall which Thuc. does not mention. They increase the difficulty by placing the ku/klos too far north. Lupus, Stahl, and Fr. Muller read <e)s> to
 krhmno/n, but this is not necessary when the ku/klos is rightly placed, the distance now built being so short that the wall ‘to the cliff’ can be fairly called a wall ‘on the cliff.’)
u(pe\r tou= e(/lous—Lysimeleia, now Pantanelli.
tw=n *)epipolw=n depends on tau/th|.
dia\ tou= o(malou=—a lower level than Epipolae, but not so low as the marsh.
au)=qis—again they built out westward, and made another effort to prevent the A. from reaching the harbour, but this time on the lowest level. Probably the palisade and ditch were not completed.
to\ pro\s to\n krhmno/n—see on § 2.
e)k th=s *qa/you— it was a mistake to abandon Thapsus altogether.

peri\ o)/rqron—cf. IV. 110 nukto\s e)/ti kai\ peri\ o)/rqron. Phrynichus says o)/rqros e)stin h( w(/ra th=s nukto\s kaq) h(\n a)lektru/ones a)/dousin. a)/rxetai de\ e)na/ths w(/ras kai\ teleuta=| ei)s diagelw=san h(me/ran.

kai\ dia\ tou= e(/lous—Classen takes this with diabadi/santes, so that h(=| phlw=des . . e)piqe/ntes is parenthetical; whereas Krüger joins it with e)piqe/ntes, which makes an awkward expression. Stahl renders ‘in fact over the marsh,’ apparently regarding it as an explanation of e)s to\ o(malo/n: but to\ o(malo/n and to\ e(/los are different levels. Classen is probably right.

to\ decio\n ke/ras—the Syr. line was facing towards the north, so that the right wing made for the city, the left ran along the left bank of the Anapus to the bridge by which the Helorine road crossed it (the Syr. had restored it since the incident mentioned in c. 66, 2); they hoped to reach Polichna, which was in the hands of the Syr.
oi( . . loga/des—see c. 100, 1.
h)=san ga\r ktl—this gives the reason for what follows, not for what preeedes.
au)toi=s=the Syr.
cunefobh/qh—‘was also put to confusion,’ like the 300. Observe the correction fulh/ for fulakh/ of the MSS. In Xen. Hel. IV. 2, 19 there is a false variant, fulakai/ for fulai/.
*la/maxos—see Intr. p. xiv.
e(autw=n—the plur. is often so used where one general among several is mentioned.

eu)qu\s kata\ ta/xos — an instance of the tendency to multiply words, esp. adverbs, in order to obtain emphasis—e.g. po/qen oi)ko/qen: au)tou= e)kei=. The same tendency is seen in Latin, esp. in comedy.
au)tw=n—depends on oi( katafugo/ntes. See c. 62, 5 n.
tou\s kata\ sfa=s—means the left wing of the A.

to\ me\n deka/pleqron protei/xisma—this outwork, 1000 feet long, is probably a curving wall in front of the portion of the ku/klos that faced towards the city. It may also have run in front of the short piece of wall that joined the ku/klos to the krhmno/s (see c. 101, 1 n.), the effect of which arrangement would be that ultimately all the lines from the ku/klos to the Great Harbour, including the ku/klos itself, were double. The protei/xisma was probably rebuilt afterwards. (Conradt thinks that the protei/xisma is a fort at the north end of the line of circumvallation; but what could be the object of a fort there, when the A. were occupied in building at the north and meant to continue to Trogilus?)
diekw/lusen—sc. e(lei=n kai\ diaporqh=sai. Nicias had only the soldiers' servants with him.
ka/twqen — from Anapus.
w(/sper ei)/rhto—‘in accordance with instructions.’ See c. 101, 3.
kai\ h( cu/mpasa—i.e. not only the two divisions that had advanced from the city, but the left wing also that had fled to the bridge, returned. For
mh/ see M.T. § 685.

au)to/n—‘the general.’ The A. now stopped build ing north of the ku/klos, and built a double wall from Portella del Fusco towards the Great Harbour. Now that the fleet was in the harbour, it was necessary to secure communication with the ku/klos. The object of the wall being double was partly that provisions might come safely from the harbour, and partly to guard against an attack from two sides, as Polichna was in the possession of Syr.
periewrw=nto—as in c. 93, 1. For
*turshni/as see c. 88, 6.

kai\ ta)=lla ktl—the next sentences consist of a telling contrast between the prospects of the two sides just before the arrival of Gylippus. Then come the progress and arrival of the latter, the passage lasting down to the end of VII. 2. The whole passage is one of the finest examples of the sombre pathos of which Thuc. is such a master.

prouxw/rei e)s e)lpi/das—‘the progress was such as to rouse hopes’ of success. Cf. VIII. 81 e)s e)lpi/das au)tou\s tw=n mello/ntwn kaqi/sth, though the resemblance is more apparent than real. This use of e)s is to express the end or consequence towards which the action of the verb is directed. Cf. pra/ssein ti e)s a)nabola/s VII. 15, ‘to act so as to produce delays.’ (Classen reads e)s e)lpi/da with the Vatican,=‘according to their hope.’)
ou)de/—from Peloponnese they had especially looked for help, because of their tie with Corinth and the Spartan hatred of Athens.

tou\s de\ lo/gous—‘the proposals they made whether among themselves or to Nicias were for peace.’ These proposals must have come from persons opposed to Hermoerates, and are a violation of the oath taken a few months before (c. 75, 2). They are the outcome of the vigorous prosecution of the siege.
oi(=a—sc. le/gesqai
u(po/—‘under the weight of.’
*(hraklei/dhn—not the same as the one mentioned in c. 73, 1.
*gu/lippos—see c. 93, 2. He assumes, in accordance with the statements of Alcibiades, that the A., having secured Sicily, will proceed to attack Italy.
th\n de\ *)itali/an—for the meaning of this see on c. 2, 4. For
to\n *)io/nion (ko/lpon) see on c. 13, 1.
*qouri/an—see on c. 61, 6.
presbeusa/menos—not ‘went on a mission,’ but ‘sent an embassy,’ and ‘renewed the citizenship that his father Cleandridas had enjoyed there.’ See c. 92, 3.
au)tou/s—the people for the place, as constantly. 20

kata\ to\n *terinai=on ko/lpon — as this gulf, now di S. Eufemia, is on the north-west side of the Bruttii, this seems to be a mistake: he ought to have said the Scyllacian gulf (di Squillace), which is opposite to it on the south-east, the land being here at its narrowest.
me/gas ktl—‘stiffly when it sets at north.’
pa/lin xeimasqei/s—‘being driven by a violent storm.’
e)s ta\ ma/lista —as in Demosth. 21, 212 ei)si\n ei)s ta\ ma/lista plou/sioi.
u(perei=de—‘despised the small number.’
fulakh/n— sc. new=n. He presently sent out four ships, but they failed to intercept Gylippus.

*lakedaimo/nioi—see c. 95. The A. now openly
break the Peace of Nicias and the alliance that followed by attacking places in Laconia.
e)k *pu/lou—the A. had occupied Pylus in 425 B.C. They had formed an alliance with Argos and Mantinea in 420.
o(/son ktl—‘only just to land on L. territory in arms.’ For o(/son mo/n on cf. Aristoph. Vesp. 1288 o(/son de\ mo/non ei)de/nai: IV. 16 o(/sa mh\ a)pobai/nontas, ‘except disembarking.’ The phrase
cu\n o(/plois is an old military expression, this and cu\n (toi=s) qeoi=s being the only phrases with cu/n that are common in Attic, except Xenophou.
*)epi/dauron—ravaged by the A. in 424, and again in 413.
*prasia/s—P. had already suffered severely in the war. Aristoph. Pax 242 i)w\ *prasiai\ trisa/qliai kai\ penta/kis.
eu)profa/siston ktl—‘brought it about that the L. had a better excuse for alleging against the A. that they were defending themselves.’
*fleiasi/an—Phlius was in alliance with Sparta.
